The above records disprove the Wife’s claim that she was “undergoing emotional distress and [had] expressed feelings of helplessness” at the material time.[note: 24] Let me explain.

(a)      First, the records in [21(1)] to [21(9)] above show that the Wife had initiated multiple communication with the Husband in the 20 min period before sending the Threat over WhatsApp. If the Husband had been verbally abusive and harassing her, why did she initiate such communication?

(b)      Second, the messages reveal that the Wife was in fact angry with the Husband at the material time:

(i)       About one minute before sending the Threat over WhatsApp, she had called the Husband “idiot”: see [21(1)] above. At the trial, she explained that she had sent the message because he had talked “nonsense” at the material time.[note: 25]

(ii)       Shortly after being called “idiot”, the Husband texted that he was going to the police station: see [21(11)]. In response to this text, the Wife sent the Threat over WhatsApp. It bears highlighting that she then followed up with a message explaining that she had sent the threat because of his “stupidity”: [21(14)]. The Wife did not make any reference to the Husband’s alleged “pressure” as being the trigger for sending the threat.

(c)      Third, the Wife made it very clear during the trial that she had sent the Threat over WhatsApp and the message at [21(18)] above to get the Husband’s attention – as he was not answering her calls at the material time. She had simply wanted him to play the recording and had no intention to carry out the threat.[note: 26] This shows that the Wife was in fact the one who was exerting pressure at the material time.

Children were present when the Threat at Home was made

22     I find that the children were present when the Wife made the Threat at Home. This is evident from the recording of the incident.[note: 27] In that recording, the following could be heard.

(a)     The children were crying, shouting “Amma” and “Mama”, and pleading, “amma, no amma”.

(b)     The Husband was desperately trying to de-escalate the situation and to get the children away from the Wife.

Meaning of “family violence”

23     The next issue is whether the Wife’s threats constitute family violence. In this regard, s 64 of the Charter states –

“family violence” means the commission of any of the following acts:

(a)    wilfully or knowingly placing, or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt; [Limb A]

(b)    causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt; [Limb B]

(c)    wrongfully confining or restraining a family member against his or her will; [Limb C]

(d)    causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member, [Limb D]

[text in square brackets added]

Family violence under Limb B and Limb C had not been committed

24     Limb B and Limb C are clearly not applicable in the present case.

(a)     In the case of Limb B, “hurt” has been defined under s 64 to mean “bodily pain, disease or infirmity. This definition would not cover the emotional trauma suffered the Husband and the children because of the threats.

(b)     As for Limb C, there is no evidence that the Wife had wrongfully confined or restrained the Husband and children at the material time.

25     This leaves us with Limb A and Limb D to be considered.

Family violence under Limb A had not been committed

26     I start with Limb A. I accept the Wife’s submission that the Threat over WhatsApp and the Threat at Home do not fall within Limb A.

(a)     The Threat over WhatsApp involves a threat to cause harm to the children. However, there is no evidence to show that the Wife had intended the message to be read by the children, or that she would have known that the message would be read by them. Accordingly, the Wife did not wilfully or knowingly place, or attempt to place, the children in fear of hurt.

(b)     Next, the Threat at Home. This involves a threat of self-harm by the Wife. She did not directly or indirectly threaten to harm either the Husband or the children. As such, she similarly did not wilfully or knowingly place, or attempt to place, them in fear of hurt.

Family violence under Limb D had been committed

27     In my view, the Wife had committed family violence under Limb D.

(a)      First, on 2 April 2024, she had sent two messages in which she threatened to commit self-harm and to kill the children: see [21(13)] and [21(18)]. After sending these messages, the Wife repeated her threat to commit self-harm – this time holding a knife in the presence of the Husband and children at home. Such actions had traumatised the Husband and children. In the audio recording of the Threat at Home, the children could be heard crying. The Husband could also be heard trying to calm the Wife down. She clearly knew that her threats had caused anguish to her family members. During the trial, the Wife admitted that it was wrong for her to have picked up a knife at the material time, and that the children ought to have been protected from such trauma.[note: 28]

(b)      Second, earlier in the afternoon of 2 April 2024 (i.e., from 2.26 pm to 7.00 pm), the Wife had also sent to the Husband multiple messages demanding that he must (i) settle “the phone contract” and (ii) meet her at a place and time specified by her for this purpose. The Wife had made these demands despite the Husband informing her that he was busy at work and that he could meet her only after work.[note: 29] The Wife would have known that her barrage of messages, calls, and demands to the Husband while he was at work are likely to cause anguish to him.

22 April 2024 – Hitting and caning the children

28     I now turn to the next incident. It is not disputed that on 22 April 2024 at about 8.40 pm, the Wife had caned the children. A video recording from a CCTV camera at home of this incident was admitted into evidence. The Husband was not at home at the material time.

Parties’ case

29     The issue regarding the 22 April incident centres on whether the Wife’s use of force on the children comes within the correction exception.

(a)     According to the Wife, a day before the incident, she had already warned the children against using violence towards each other and their domestic helper. Despite this warning, the son had hit the helper and the daughter on 22 April 2024. The daughter had also fought with the son that day. Accordingly, she had caned the children to discipline them.[note: 30]

(b)     It is the Husband’s case that the Wife hit the son because of the daughter’s complaint over a minor matter – the son’s refusal to share a toy with her. The Wife had caned the daughter when the son complained that the daughter had hit his buttocks. The Husband submitted that the Wife’s use of force on the children (i) was unnecessarily severe given that the children merely had a “minor sibling conflict”, (ii) was motivated by “frustration and anger”, and (iii) was inflicted without concern for the children’s welfare and had traumatised them.[note: 31]

My decision

30     Having reviewed the video recording, I find that the Wife had failed to prove that the correction exception applies to the 22 April incident.

Reason for the use of force

31     I am unable to accept the Wife’s claim that she had used force on the children because they had been physically violent towards each other and to the helper (in the case of the son).

32      First, such a claim is not supported by the video recording of the incident. The recording reveals the following.

(a)     Before the violence started, the children and the helper were in the living room, while the Wife was in the bedroom.

(b)     For more than a minute before the Wife started to use force on the children, the latter were apparently doing their own things in the living room. The son did not hit the helper and the daughter. Neither did the daughter fight with the son. There was also no verbal altercation between the children.

(c)     The Wife started to use force only after the daughter had gone into the bedroom – apparently to complain to her about the son.[note: 32]

(d)     After the complaint, the Wife went to the living room and began hitting the son. During this period, the son said something to her. The word “pigu” (meaning buttocks in Chinese) could be heard. The Wife then turned her attention to the daughter and began caning her repeatedly.

33      Second, during the trial, the Wife could not recall what was the nature of the daughter’s complaint about the son.[note: 33]

34      Third, given that the Wife did not see what the son was doing in the living room at the material time (because she was in the bedroom), there is no basis for her to claim that he had hit the domestic helper and the daughter.

35     In my view, the misbehaviour by the children, if any, is relatively minor. The Wife had failed to show why it is necessary to use force to punish them for such misbehaviour.

Manner the force was used

36     Additionally, I find that the Wife’s use of force at the material time had been excessive and unreasonable.

(a)     Despite the relatively minor misbehaviour, the Wife had severely punished the children for about 5 mins.

(b)     There are several instances when the use of force is clearly gratuitous.

(i)       The Wife had caned the daughter repeatedly even after the latter (1) had apologised for what she had done, and (2) was screaming and crying in pain from the caning.[note: 34]

(ii)       While the Wife’s initial motivation for the use of force might have been to punish the children for misbehaving, she subsequently used the cane to stop them from screaming out in pain from the caning.[note: 35] Clearly, a more effective way to stop the screaming is to simply stop the caning.

(iii)       Despite the daughter having complied with the instructions to stop screaming, the Wife continued to cane the child. This caused the daughter to further scream in pain.[note: 36] Caning in such circumstances is clearly unnecessary. The Wife’s actions suggest that she was seeking to assert power and control – rather than discipline – over the children through the infliction of pain: XKJ at [32(d)(iv)].[note: 37]

2 May 2024 – Kicking the Husband’s leg

37     I come to the next incident. This took place on 2 May 2024 at about 1.30 am. The incident – which is captured on the CCTV camera recording[note: 38] – occurred after the Wife had just returned home from Malaysia. The Husband was sleeping on the floor in the living room at the material time.

Parties’ case

38     According to the Husband, the Wife had harassed him (a) by kicking his leg repeatedly for about 90 s and (b) by taking away his sling back which contained items such as his wallet and phone.[note: 39]

39     The Wife denied having harboured any intention to harass the Husband at the material time. According to her, she had merely nudged him with her leg as she felt pitiful for him to be sleeping on the floor.[note: 40]

My decision

40     I find that the Wife’s actions did not amount to family violence.

(a)      First, there is no evidence that her actions had caused “hurt” to the Husband. Put in another way, the Husband had failed to prove that he had suffered “bodily pain, disease or infirmity” because of the Wife’s actions. Accordingly, Limb A is not engaged.

(b)      Second, the Husband had also failed to bring his case under Limb D. Specifically, there is no evidence that the Wife had intended to cause, or knew that she was likely to cause, anguish to him at the material time. In the video recording, the Wife can be heard saying repeatedly in a normal tone, “Excuse me”, “I need the room”, “I am talking to you”, and “Hello”. The Husband can also be heard in the recording to have said, “Not now”. If the Wife had intended to cause anguish to him, one would have expected her to be more aggressive and forceful in waking him up – e.g., by shouting harshly at him.

(c)      Finally, the recording shows that after failing to rouse the Husband to get up, the Wife took his sling bag and left. Soon thereafter, the Husband looked up in her direction, glanced at the position where his bag used to be placed, and then returned to his sleep. In my view, the Husband must have been aware that the Wife had taken his sling bag. Yet, he did not raise any issue with this at the material time. Neither did he seem to be distressed by the Wife’s actions. It is not inconceivable that the Wife had taken the bag to retrieve her room key, and the Husband was fine with this.

13 to 14 May 2024 – Harassing the Husband

41     I come to the final incident. It is common ground that the parties had an altercation in the early hours of 13 and 14 May 2024. The altercation revolved around the Wife’s suspicion that the Husband had hacked into her laptop and her phone (“hacking issue”). The parties however gave very different accounts of what had transpired during the altercation.

Parties’ case

42     According to the Husband[note: 41] –

(a)     The Wife had verbally abused him during the altercation over the hacking issue. At one point, she suddenly slapped his left cheek, leaving him stunned. The Husband remained calm and did not want to be provoked into committing violence against her. When he attempted to leave the home to avoid further conflict, the Wife blocked his path. In response, the Husband told her to leave him alone, or else he would punch her. (He did not have the intention to carry out this threat at the material time.) Despite the threat, the Wife continued to harass him. The Husband did not retaliate. She eventually stopped the harassment at about 2.00 am and went to her room.

(b)     On 14 May 2024 at about 6.00 am, as the Husband was getting ready to leave home for work, the Wife resumed her harassment. She refused to let him go to work until the hacking issue was resolved. She followed him when he left the home. When the lift reached the ground floor, the Husband told her that he was going to the police station. At that point, the Wife took his office bag (which contained his laptop) and went home. The Husband did not want to return home to face further harassment. As such, he reported what had happened to the Police.

43     The Wife denied the Husband’s allegations. According to her[note: 42] –

(a)     During the altercation, the Husband had punched her, kicked her, and pushed her against a cupboard and a wall. He eventually told her that he would discuss the hacking issue the following morning. He then went to sleep.

(b)     The next day, the parties left home together to talk about the problems in their marriage. When the lift reached the ground floor, the Husband suddenly ran towards the direction of the police station. In the midst of running, he dropped his office bag in the middle of the road and told her –

“I'm not mentally stable. Don’t make me do stupid things again. I'm going to call the police now and act stupid.”

[emphasis added]

The Wife retrieved the Husband’s office bag and returned home. She later learnt that the Husband had lodged a police report that she had committed violence against him.

My decision

The altercation

44     The Wife submitted that her account of the altercation should be believed for the following reasons.[note: 43]

(a)      First, the Husband did not particularise her verbal abuse towards him during the altercation.

(b)      Second, the Wife’s alleged abuse did not put the Husband in fear of hurt as he was able to sleep from 2.00 am to 6.00 am.

(c)      Third, the Husband’s claim that she had slapped his cheek during the altercation is a bare allegation. He had failed to produce any photographs, medical reports, or persons who had seen him after the altercation to corroborate his claim.

(d)     On the other hand, the Wife’s evidence that the Husband had punched her is supported by an audio recording. In the recording, he could be heard saying, “I’ll punch your face now. Move”. (“Husband’s Remarks”)

45     I am not persuaded by the Wife’s submissions. Let me explain.

(a)     The fact that the Husband did not particularise the Wife’s verbal abuse is not fatal to his case. Based on the parties’ case, the altercation was clearly heated – with both sides alleging that family violence had been committed by the other side.

(b)     The Wife’s submission that the Husband could sleep after the altercation is also a neutral point. A similar argument can be made against the Wife that she was not in fear of hurt by the Husband at the material time. This is because (i) she had remained at home after he had allegedly assaulted her and (ii) she had chosen to leave the home together with him the next morning.

(c)     Regarding the lack of evidence to corroborate the Husband’s account of what had happened during the altercation, again, the same point can be made of the Wife’s claim. Specifically, she had failed to produce photographs, medical reports, or persons who had seen her after the altercation to corroborate her claim that the Husband had kicked her and pushed her against a cupboard and a wall.

46     I accept that the Husband’s Remarks can corroborate the Wife’s claim that the Husband had punched her. That said, I find this evidence to be far from conclusive.

(a)      First, the remarks can also support the Husband’s evidence that the Wife had blocked his path when he attempted to leave the home to avoid further conflict.

(b)      Second, the Husband’s Remarks can be construed to be merely a warning of what the Husband might do if the Wife did not stop blocking his path.

(c)      Finally, it is unclear from the recording whether the Husband did eventually punch the Wife.[note: 44]

47     On the last point, I have doubts regarding the Wife’s claim that the Husband had assaulted her during the altercation. Based on the Wife’s account, the alleged assault would have been extremely violent – she was punched, kicked, and pushed against a cupboard and a wall. Despite this, the Wife did not mention about the assault until recently at the trial. Let me explain.

(a)      First, it is the Wife’s case that she has a habit of texting the Husband’s brother (one S) (“Brother-in-Law”) to help solve her marital issues with the Husband.[note: 45] Yet, there is no evidence to show that she had texted the Brother-in-Law for help soon after the alleged assault.

(b)      Second, the Wife also did not promptly file a police report or PPO application against the Husband for the alleged assault. Instead, she filed her police report and PPO application (SS 1138/2024) only on 20 May 2024 and 18 June 2024 respectively. It bears noting that her report and application was filed after – and apparently in response to – the Husband’s PPO application on 15 May 2024.

(c)      Third, in her police report, the Wife had set out comprehensively her complaint against the Husband. In the report, she accused him of having (1) hacked her electronic devices, (2) stolen her identity card, (3) pawn her jewellery without her consent, and (4) hit her on 26 January 2023. Significantly, there is no mention in the police report that the Husband had assaulted her on in the early hours of 13 and 14 May 2024.[note: 46] If the Wife could recall him having allegedly hit her on 26 January 2023 (i.e., an incident that had occurred about 1½ years before the lodging of the police report), why did she fail to mention the alleged assault during the altercation – which is a more violent and a more recent incident?

(d)      Finally, in her PPO application, the Wife had similarly failed to mention the alleged assault during the altercation.[note: 47] Instead, she referred to (1) the hacking issue, (2) the incidents stated in her police report (dated 20 May 2024), (3) the Husband having allegedly slapped the son in March 2023, and (4) an alleged spousal abuse on 26 January 2023. Given that the very purpose of the Wife making the PPO application is to protect herself from family violence by the Husband, why did she fail (again) to mention in her application about the alleged assault in the early hours of 13 and 14 May 2024?

48     In contrast, I find that the Husband’s account of the altercation to be more coherent and credible. Additionally, his evidence that the Wife was very aggressive at the material time is consistent with her own evidence that she was “particularly distress[ed]” by the hacking issue at the material time as her nursing course assignments and examinations were just around the corner. The Wife had also believed that the Husband was the culprit.[note: 48] In the circumstances, it is probable that she would have been harsh and confrontational towards the Husband over the hacking issue at the material time.

Events when the parties left the home

49     I now turn to the events when the parties left their home in the morning of 14 May 2024.

50     According to the Wife, the Husband had made two statements at the material time. First, that he was “not mentally stable”. Second, that he would pretend to be “stupid” (presumably, meaning pretend to be mentally unstable) in front of the Police.

51     I find the Wife’s evidence regarding such alleged statements to be inherently incredible.

(a)      First, it appears from the Wife’s evidence that the Husband had suddenly behaved in a bizarre manner. This is no evidence to show what had triggered such alleged behaviour.

(b)      Second, if the Husband was “mentally stable” and rational at the material time, why did he make the alleged statements? Put in another way, what advantage did he seek to gain by declaring his mental state and intentions to the Wife?

(c)     Further, it is not disputed that the Husband had left home that morning intending to go to work. In the circumstances, there is no reason for him to suddenly leave his laptop bag in the middle of the road while running to the police station. Without his laptop, how would he be able to work?[note: 49]

(d)      Third, if the Husband was “not mentally stable” at the material time, then I have difficulty accepting that he would still have the presence of mind to declare to the Wife his intention to “act stupid” before the Police.

(e)      Finally, based on the Wife’s account, the Husband would not have known that she had kept his laptop bag at the material time. This is because according to her, the Husband had suddenly left the bag in the middle of the road while running away from her. Yet, it is not disputed that the Husband knew that his laptop bag was with the Wife at the material time. This is because he had complained to the Police that she had taken his laptop bag. It is also undisputed that the bag was later found in her possession by the Police. Such undisputed facts do not square with the Wife’s account.

Summary – Family violence committed

52     To sum-up, I find that the Wife had committed family violence against the Husband and the children. Specifically –

(a)     The Wife had repeatedly caned and hit the son on 27 July 2023. Such use of force was excessive and unreasonable and had gone beyond the limits of the correction exception.

(b)     The Wife had also continuously harassed the Husband on 2 April 2024. Initially, the harassment concerned the “phone contract” issue. Later in the evening, she had repeatedly threatened to kill herself and the children. The Wife’s actions had caused alarm and anguish to the Husband and the children.

(c)     The Wife had repeatedly hit and caned the children on 22 April 2024. Such actions did not come within the correction exception.

(d)     Finally, the Wife had slapped the Husband’s cheek and continuously harassed him regarding the hacking issue in the early hours of 13 and 14 May 2024. On 14 May 2024, she had continued the harassment and had also taken his laptop bag when he was going to work.

Whether PPO is necessary

53     Having found that family violence had been committed, the next issue is whether a PPO is necessary to deter the Wife from committing further violence.

54     On this issue, the Wife made several submissions.

Fact that the Wife loves the children

55      First, the Wife submitted that a PPO is not necessary because she deeply loves the children.[note: 50]

56     While I do not doubt the Wife’s love for the children, this fact alone does not mean that a PPO is unnecessary. The key issue is whether “family violence is likely to be committed” by the Wife against the children in the future: s 65(1) of the Charter.

57     In my view, the answer is yes. The Wife had made it clear during the trial that she did not see anything wrong with her approach to “disciplining” the children. This lack of insight on her part increases the likelihood that she will continue to use excessive and unreasonable force to discipline the children in future. A PPO is needed to remind her to exercise restraint when disciplining them: XKJ at [32(h)].

Propensity to threaten harm to self and the children

58      Second, the Wife had also submitted that the making of the Threat over WhatsApp and the Threat at Home[note: 51] –

... was purely situational in nature and would not arise again. The evidence shows that since April 2024, which was more than a year ago, the [Wife] had not ever threatened nor contemplated suicide again. It will be speculative and against the weight of the evidence to find that the [Wife] would react in a similar fashion in future, when her conduct on that occasion was purely one-off in nature.

[emphasis in original text; text in square brackets added]

59     I am unable to agree with the Wife’s submission.

60      First, the mere fact that she has not made further threats of harming either herself or the children after April 2024 is neither here nor there. One possible reason why the Wife had desisted from making further similar threats is that the Husband had applied for a PPO against her on 15 May 2024.

61      Second, there is ample evidence to show that to get attention and what she wants, the Wife has no qualm about (1) making casual references to death, and (2) threatening to cause harm to herself and/or the children. In addition to the threats made on 2 April 2024, the Wife had also made the following threats.

(a)     During courtship days, there was an occasion where the Wife was hospitalised following a suicide attempt when the Husband wanted to break up with her.[note: 52]

(b)     On 28 July 2023, the Wife had sent the following message to the Husband when he pleaded with her that the son did not deserve to be caned for making mistakes in his spelling:[note: 53]

This is you, u wan us to die at the very last minute ...

[emphasis added]

(c)     On 22 April 2024 (i.e., just three weeks after the 2 April incident), the Wife had again threatened to kill herself and the children.

(i)       On that day, the Wife had sent the following messages to the Brother-in-Law.[note: 54]

“I really mean it mama”

“If he [the Husband] never come back tonight. Ask him to come and collect the 3 bodies at home”

“That’s why almost jump done”

“The [son] hugged me and cried plz plz Amma I want to survive”

“Before I jump down”

“Yest almost mama”

“Today I will make sure it happens”

“I took out the window and etc redy (sic)”

[emphasis added]

(ii)       To emphasise that she was serious in executing her threat, the Wife had also forwarded an image from the home (the unit is located on the 12th floor) with the window and grille opened.

(iii)       The Wife claimed that she was “undergoing emotional distress” and “expressing feelings of helplessness” at the material time. According to her, such feelings arose because (1) the Husband had installed a video recorder in the helper’s room, and (2) he had not returned home for some time.[note: 55]

(iv)       I am unable to accept the Wife’s claim. According to her, she had sent the above messages so that the Brother-in-Law could question the Husband and solve her marital issues.[note: 56] In other words, she had an ulterior motive for sending the messages. During cross-examination, the Wife reluctantly agreed that regardless of the personal issues a parent was facing, the parent should not make threats with a child’s life to get what he/she wanted.[note: 57]

62     At this juncture, I digress to highlight the following.

(a)     The present case is not one involving a threat (i) made in the heat of the moment under extreme emotional circumstances, or (ii) linked to an underlying psychiatric condition. In such cases, the facts may show that the maker of the threat did not intend to cause harm: TDN v TDM [2014] SGDC 143 at [26].[note: 58]

(b)     Depending on the facts, a PPO may still be an appropriate option to deter the respondent from making similar threats in future even if the respondent is mentally unstable: see e.g., UMP v UMQ [2018] SGFC 57 at [23] and [31].

Fact that the Husband is facing charges

63      Third, the Wife had also submitted that a PPO is unnecessary to protect the Husband. The basis for this submission is as follows.

(a)     After the trial had ended, the Wife complained to the Police that the Husband had (on 14 May 2025) breached an expedited order (“EO”) issued against him. Specifically, he had allegedly used his elbow to press onto the back of her neck area and thus caused her pain.

(b)     On 23 April 2025, the Husband was charged in court for (i) breaching the EO, an offence under s 63C of the Charter, and (ii) voluntarily causing hurt, an offence under s 323 read with s 74C of the Penal Code 1871.[note: 59]

64     Arising from the above, the Wife made two submissions.

(a)      First, that I should draw the appropriate “inference” from the fact that the Police and Attorney General’s Chambers (“AGC”) had seen it fit to press charges against the Husband.[note: 60]

(b)      Second, that the Husband is a “violent person ... and therefore cannot be said to require a personal protection order for himself”.

65     I am unable to agree with the Wife’s submissions.

(a)     The Husband’s criminal case has not concluded at the time of this judgement. The fact that he is facing prosecution does not prove that he had committed the acts alleged in his charges. At the risk of stating the obvious, he is innocent until proven guilty.

(b)     In any event, whether the Husband is a “violent person” or not is irrelevant to the issue of whether the Wife should be deterred from committing family violence against him via a PPO.

(c)     In my view, a PPO is necessary. During the trial, it is clear to me that the parties have an acrimonious relationship. The risk of the Wife committing further violence against the Husband is heightened by the fact that they are undergoing divorce. It is likely that they will have conflicts regarding how the marriage is to be dissolved and on matters relating to the children – given their very different parenting styles and attitudes towards the use of corporal punishment: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [21].

Fact that the Wife had moved out of the matrimonial home

66      Finally, the Wife submitted that a PPO is not necessary because the Husband had moved out of the matrimonial home.[note: 61]

67     I am not persuaded by this submission. The fact that the parties are no longer residing together does not mean that family violence in the future is unlikely. In the present case, I note that the Wife appears to have a controlling personality and to tend to make inflammatory remarks towards the Husband over WhatsApp. This is evident, for instance, in the WhatsApp exchanges between the parties on 28 July 2023. The background to this exchange has already been set out in [5] to [16] above.[note: 62] To recap –

(a)     The Husband told the Wife that her punishment of the son was unduly harsh – considering that it was just spelling. He had requested the Wife not to “overreact”.

(b)     Despite the fact that the tone in the Husband’s messages was measured, the Wife responded with a barrage of accusatory statements. This included (i) asserting that the son’s poor performance was “definitely” due to the Husband’s “mistakes” (Message at 10.59 am), (ii) telling him “Don’t be stupid” (Message at 11.11 am), (iii) calling him an “irresponsible father who focus on money alone” (Message at 11.12 am), and (iv) scolding him, “shame on you” (Message at 11.15 am).

68     Another example of the Wife’s tendency to be controlling and to make inflammatory statements can be seen in the WhatsApp exchange between the parties on 2 April 2024.[note: 63]

(a)     At about 2.17 pm on that day, the Wife declared her decision to get a divorce. At about 2.25 pm, she sent several messages with exaggerated claims against the Husband – e.g., claiming that he might “record naked videos of me or our daughter for money”.

(b)     Within a minute after sending the above messages, the Wife asked the Husband to settle her “phone contract” issue. The way that she had engaged with him on this issue is very revealing about the power dynamics between the parties.

(i)       When the Husband replied that he was at a meeting and that he was not free that day, the Wife insisted that the “phone contract” matter must be settled that day. Despite the Husband suggesting that she could check first with the Woodlands and Yishun branches of the service provider and that he would be free to be with her from 7.40 pm, the Wife replied “nope”, “somerset”, “Don’t instruct me to do that and this”, “you have to do – I can pay yr last 2 hours salary”, “need to get this settled”. (Messages from 3.40 pm to 3.41 pm)

(ii)       When the Husband highlighted that the “phone contract” matter was not urgent and that he would make the payment on 2 April itself, the Wife made clear that her demands were non-negotiable, stating that, “im not free”, “need to settle it”, “im planning to move out this weekends (sic)”, “U don’t decide behalf of me whether there is urgency or not”. (Messages from 4.35 pm to 4.39 pm)

(iii)       When the Husband sought to negotiate with the Wife the time and place to meet her to settle the “phone contract” (by asking the Wife to meet him at Somerset at 7.20 pm), she demanded, “u fetch me at 5.30 pm”, “at woodlands”. (Message at 4.45 pm) At this juncture, I digress to highlight that the Wife had set the meeting time at 5.30 pm despite the Husband having told her that he would be free only after 7.00 pm.

(iv)       The Wife had also chided the Husband thereafter by texting, “Don’t behave like an idiot, can? You are very free to do all the recording and nonsense things”. (Message at 5.31 pm)

69     To sum-up, the Wife’s tendency to be controlling and to make inflammatory statements towards the Husband over WhatsApp increases the likelihood of family violence being committed against him in future. In the circumstances, a PPO can remind her to avoid conduct that can constitute continual harassment against the Husband.

Conclusion

70     For the above reasons, I grant the Husband’s PPO application for the children and himself. Additionally, I order the parties to undergo mandatory counselling.

71     Before concluding, I wish to address one point raised in the Husband’s closing submissions. To protect the children, the Husband had requested that (a) a domestic exclusion order be issued and (b) the matter be referred to the Child Protection Specialist Centre (“CPSC”).[note: 64] I do not see the need to accede to these requests.

(a)      First, the Husband has failed to prove that the nature of the family violence committed by the Wife is so severe that it is necessary to take the draconian step of excluding her from the matrimonial home.

(b)      Second, if the Husband thinks that it is appropriate to refer the matter to the CPSC, he is at liberty to do so himself.

html:
XMW v XMX

XMW v XMX
[2025] SGFC 59

Case Number:Divorce No. 4670 of 2022
Decision Date:21 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Azmin Jailani
Counsel Name(s): Sandra Segeram Mahendra (Segeram & Co) for the plaintiff; Defendant absent and unrepresented
Parties: XMW — XMX

Family law – Divorce – Unreasonable Behaviour

Family law – Divorce – Improper Association

Family law – Divorce – Procedure – Effect of party choosing not to participate in proceedings

21 May 2025

District Judge Azmin Jailani:

Introduction

1       The present divorce proceeding (ie, FC/D 4670/2022, or “D 4670”) was commenced by the plaintiff-wife against the defendant-husband. After filing their respective papers, parties appeared for the substantive hearing on 3 February 2025.

2       Before commencing the trial, the Court saw parties in chambers to finalise, among other things, certain housekeeping matters. At that session, both the wife’s counsel, Mr Segeram, and the husband were present. However, as elaborated below, just before the Court was about to commence with the hearing, the husband made the considered decision not to participate further.

3       Notwithstanding the defendant’s deliberate decision not to participate, the trial proceeded. On that basis, after hearing from the wife and her witness, the Court granted the wife’s application and granted interim judgment (vide FC/IJ 500/2025, or “IJ”) to dissolve the marriage.

4       Despite choosing not to participate in the trial, the husband has filed the present appeal against this Court granting IJ in the wife’s favour.

5       I now set out the grounds of my decision.

Background

The Parties

6       Parties were married in India, whereby the marriage was solemnised in October 2006, and subsequently registered in December 2007. Parties were originally from India, and the wife moved to Singapore after the marriage to be with the husband as he was already working in Singapore since 2005.

7       There are two children to the marriage, both girls. The elder daughter (“C1”) was born in November 2009, and the younger daughter (“C2”) was born in November 2012.[note: 1]

Commencement of D 4670

8       I now set out the procedural history of the divorce proceedings leading up to the hearing on 3 February 2025. As noted above, the eventual hearing was uneventful in light of the husband’s decision not to participate in the trial. However, although not directly relevant to the present appeal, I found it apposite to set out some various aspects of the procedural history which, in my view, shed light and insight on the husband’s conduct during the entire course of these proceedings.

9       Following from the breakdown of their relationship, the wife commenced D 4670 in October 2022. In her papers, she sought for an order for the dissolution of the marriage on the ground ‘unreasonable behaviour’ under the then section 95(3)(b) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“WC”).[note: 2] It suffices to summarise at this juncture that the wife asserted, inter alia, that the husband was abusive to her after the birth of C2,[note: 3] had committed family violence against her (including punching her in the face),[note: 4] and was having an improper association.[note: 5]

10     Contemporaneously, in September 2022, the wife commenced FC/OSG 96/2022 (“OSG 96”) seeking orders in respect of the Children. The husband was represented in those proceedings.

11     Whilst the husband was represented in OSG 96, the wife had issues with serving the papers in D 4670 on the husband. Issues arose in part because the husband’s solicitors in OSG 96 had indicated that they had no instructions to accept service of the papers in D 4670 on the husband’s behalf. As such, the wife sought an order for substituted service of the divorce papers.

12     On 11 November 2022, the Court granted the wife’s application for substituted service. On 21 November 2022, the divorce documents in D 4670 were served on the husband.

13     It was only after the wife was able to serve the divorce documents in D 4670 on the husband (by way of substituted service) that the husband filed a notice stating that he had appointed solicitors for D 4670. A review of the court records will show that the solicitors who were appointed for D 4670 were, in fact, the same solicitors representing him for OSG 96.

14     Notwithstanding the issues with service, it bears noting that on 12 December 2022, the wife filed a ‘Request for Setting Down Action for Trial’ for the divorce to proceed on an uncontested basis.

15     Separately, in light of OSG 96, the father himself separately commenced OSG 6/2023 (“OSG 6”) on 5 January 2023, seeking orders for custody and care and control of the Children, as well as maintenance for the Children.[note: 6]

The husband’s 1st stay proceedings (SUM 21/2023)

16     Two days before commencing OSG 6, on 3 January 2023, the husband commenced Summons No. 21/2023 (“SUM 21”) to stay D 4670 on the basis of forum non conveniens. In this regard, the husband had, after the wife commenced D 4670 and OSG 96, commenced his own set of divorce proceedings in India on 29 October 2022 (i.e, Original Petition No. 1318, or “OP 1318”). OP 1318 was commenced in the husband’s home state of Palakkad, India.[note: 7]

17     SUM 21 was initially fixed for hearing in March 2023. As noted earlier, at this time, both the wife and husband were represented in D 4670. At that hearing, it was noted that instead of filing an expert affidavit on foreign law, the husband simply included a letter from an Indian lawyer seeking to comment on aspects of foreign law. Given that the issue of Indian law (as a matter of foreign law) was an essential issue to the determination of SUM 21, directions were given for parties to properly regularise the admission of foreign law expert evidence as part of SUM 21, with a further hearing fixed in May 2023[note: 8].

18     At this juncture, it is worth noting that one of the central planks of the husband’s argument in support of a stay in D 4670 was his claim of the interplay between Singapore’s and India’s laws relating to divorce. As noted earlier, parties’ marriage was registered in India, and the husband had contended that the grounds/facts for divorce in Singapore are dissimilar to those in India, such that any Singapore divorce order may not be recognised in India.[note: 9] That said, the husband also wants to have the divorce heard in India because of his claim that the wife had committed adultery, and assuming that that fact is established, husband has an apparent right to seek damages against the wife and/or the third party involved. Put another way, it cannot be completely discounted that the husband’s desire for the divorce proceedings to take place in India was strategic or tactical in nature. This is because the ‘fact’ of adultery as a basis for dissolving a marriage is also provided for under the WC. In short, the husband would conceivably have gotten the outcome he wanted to in Singapore as well.

19     I turn back to the procedural history. In the lead up to the May 2023 hearing, the husband filed his notice indicating that he was now acting in person. In light of this and as parties were still in the midst of negotiating a global settlement in OSG 96, the hearing fixed in May 2023 was vacated.

20     As parties were unable to reach a resolution on the divorce, the hearing for SUM 21 was fixed for 26 June 2023. Then, on 22 June 2023, the husband wrote in requesting that the June 2023 hearing be vacated. Some of the reasons stated in the request included substantive arguments in support of his application in SUM 21. In light of this, the Court declined the husband’s request, and maintained its earlier directions that the hearing on 26 June 2023 proceed.

21     On the day of the hearing on 26 June 2023, the husband wrote in seeking for the hearing to be adjourned on the basis that the C2 was unwell. Notwithstanding the timing of the husband’s correspondence, I found it appropriate to acknowledge Mr Segeram’s amenability not to proceed in the husband’s absence, in part because parties were still attempting to resolve the matter globally. As such, permission was given to refix the hearing to 24 July 2023. That said, in light of the filing of parties’ respect expert evidence, the Court highlighted the completeness of parties’ documents to be used for the hearing of SUM 21.

22     On 7 July 2023, the husband filed his notice appointing solicitors for the matter. In light of solicitors coming on board, the husband made another request to adjourn the 24 July 2023 to a later date. Needless to say, the wife objected to the husband’s request to refix the matter again. That said, after hearing parties, on 17 July 2023, the Court was inclined to allow one final adjournment of the hearing. After considering parties’ available dates in their subsequent correspondence, the hearing for SUM 21 was fixed for 4 September 2023.

23     At the hearing on 4 September 2023, the Court heard substantive arguments from parties. After the hearing, the Court issued further directions for parties to provide supplemental submissions on a number of areas. This includes supplemental submissions on certain developments which had taken place after this Court had released its decision on WFU v WFV [2022] SGFC 67 (which dealt with, among other things, the interplay between our local laws relating to divorce and the law applying to parties at the time of marriage in the context of a stay application for forum non conveniens).

Events after conclusion of SUM 21

24     After receiving parties’ supplemental submissions and after considering parties’ arguments, this Court dismissed SUM 21 on 26 February 2024.

Husband’s submission of further arguments

25     After the Court released its decision for SUM 21, the husband sought to make further arguments on the matter, which included the wife’s purported submissions to the Indian courts after the Court’s decision in SUM 21. Whilst I was inclined for the husband to make these further arguments, I had specifically indicated to parties’ that in light of the dismissal of SUM 21, parties were to file their remaining pleadings for the divorce. At the time SUM 21 was dismissed, the husband had not yet filed his Defence.

26     I pause here and note, through no fault of the husband’s solicitors, the husband’s decision to delay/refusal the filing of his pleadings after the decision in SUM 21. Despite issuing numerous directions for the filing of pleadings, the husband consistently chose not to file anything. This is in part because of his belief that any filing would prejudice his position in the Indian divorce proceedings.

27     On 20 June 2024, after receiving parties’ submissions relating to the husband’s further arguments, the Court maintained its decision to dismiss SUM 21.

Husband’s continued failure to file his pleadings

28     Further to the Court’s decision, parties’ solicitors appeared before the Court for a case conference of D 4670 on 10 July 2024. At that case conference, the Court noted that the husband had still not filed his pleadings. The husband’s solicitor then, Mr Koh, apprised the Court that after speaking to his Indian solicitors, the husband was advised not to comply with this Court’s directions. This is after the Court had highlighted to Mr Koh the need for parties to file their pleadings. Two important inferences arise from Mr Koh’s submissions – the first is that the husband was aware of the direction to file his pleadings, and the importance of the same. The second is that with that knowledge, and in consultation with the advice of his Indian solicitors, the husband chose not to file his pleadings.

29     In light of the husband’s position, I formally determined that pleadings had closed, leaving the wife’s Statement of Claim (“SOC”) and Statement of Particulars (“SOP”) as the only pleadings for the divorce. Further to this, I issued the relevant directions for parties to file their respective Affidavit-of-Evidence-in-Chief (“AEIC”), the set down date for trial, and the filing of opening statements.

30     The hearing of D 4670 was scheduled to take place on 12 August 2024.

Husband’s filing of SUM 2526

31     On 6 August 2024, the husband filed a notice for a change of solicitors. On 8 August 2024 (ie, the last business day before the Monday of the hearing on 12 August 2024 (in light of the National Day public holiday)), the husband filed Summons No. 2526/2024 (“SUM 2526”). SUM 2526 was the husband’s application for a stay pending (1) the outcome of HCF/OSN 6//2024 (“OSN 6”), and/or (2) the outcome of the husband’s appeal against the dismissal of SUM 21 (in the event OSN 6 was granted). For context, OSN 6 was the husband’s application for an extension of time to file his appeal against the dismissal of SUM 21.

32     As the husband had filed SUM 2526 on the last working day before the hearing of D 4670, Mr Segeram was not in a position to deal with the application. Since SUM 2526 had to be addressed first (as it was an application to stay the proceedings pending the High Court’s determination in OSN 6), the Court was constrained to vacate the hearing of the divorce, and gave directions for the relevant responses to SUM 2526.

Dismissal of OSN 6, discharge of husband’s solicitor, and husband’s further attempt to resolve the divorce

33     On 19 September 2024, the High Court dismissed OSN 6. This meant that the husband no longer could appeal against the dismissal of SUM 21.

34     In other words, D 4670 would proceed in Singapore.

35     Further to the dismissal of OSN 6, Parties attended before the Court on 20 September 2024 to receive the necessary directions to proceed with D 4670. On the same day, the husband filed another notice, this time indicating that he was acting in person, again. Indeed, at the case conference, the husband’s solicitor sought leave to be discharged. I granted leave for the solicitor to be discharged.

36     In light of the dismissal of SUM 21 and OSN 6, the husband sought for more time to further attempt to resolve the divorce globally with the wife. The husband even sought for a further mediation, which I was not inclined to accede to. Instead, I granted the husband time to correspond with Mr Segeram for a final attempt at agreeing on the terms of the existing pleadings. In light of the fact that the husband was now self-representing himself, and perhaps naïvely hopeful, I granted the husband a fairly lengthy period of time for him to be able to find a middle ground with the wife. This is especially given my observations at paragraph 18 above that the husband’s primary complaint would be the wife’s infidelity, and if parties were to come to some consensus (at least on the specific fact of divorce), parties would have been able to better divert their resources to the ancillary matters.

37     However, after receiving updates from parties, parties were not able to reach a comprise. As such, a further case conference was convened on 10 January 2025. At that case conference, the husband sought to rehash the arguments substantively canvassed in SUM 21 as to the purported appropriateness of the divorce proceedings taking place in India. When presented with the reality that the Court was not minded to accede to any such arguments, the husband then shifted tact to say that he wished to file his defence and counterclaim. However, the Court had explained to the husband his specific position at the material time that he did not wish to comply with the Court’s directions relating to the filing of his pleadings. It is at this juncture where the husband asserted that his available options was not made known to him by his previous solicitors upon the dismissal of SUM 21. However, I was not minded to accept the husband’s reasons.

38     In light of the previous directions given for the close of pleadings, I directed that parties file and serve their AEICs by 27 January 2025, with the hearing of the divorce to take place on 3 February 2025.

The husband’s 2nd stay proceedings (SUM 220/2025)

39     Leading up to the hearing on 3 February 2025, the husband filed several notices of his intention to refer to the affidavits filed in OSG 96, OSG 6, as well as affidavits which appear to have been filed in the State Courts pursuant to an application made under the Protection from Harassment Act 2014.

40     That said, the husband had yet to file his AEICs.

41     Instead, the husband only filed, on the day of the hearing, the following AEICs:

(a)     His AEIC;

(b)     The AEIC of ‘SB’;

(c)     The AEIC of ‘BC’; and

(d)     The AEIC of ‘FAR’.

42     Additionally, on 31 January 2025 (the Friday before the hearing on Monday), the husband filed another application for a stay of proceedings in favour of the divorce proceedings in India. This application was made under Summons No. 220/2025 (“SUM 220”). Given the time in which the husband filed SUM 220, that matter was fixed for a case conference together with the hearing of D 4670 on 3 February 2025.

The Hearing on 3 February 2025

43     As noted earlier, before the start of the hearing for D 4670 on 3 February 2025, Mr Segeram and the husband attended before the Court in chambers for a pre-hearing conference for final housekeeping matters (particularly in light of the late filing of the husband’s AEICs), as well as to address the Court on SUM 220.

44     With regard to SUM 220, the husband sought to highlight to this Court that there have been some developments with the various proceedings that are going on in India.[note: 10] For instance, his own divorce proceeding in OP 1318 was to be transferred from his home state in Palakkad to the wife’s home state of Kozhikode. While that in and of itself is not controversial, the point which the husband wished to make was there these proceedings happened to be going on concurrently with D 4670. In this connection and additionally, the husband highlighted that he had filed an anti-suit injunction (vide Originating Petition 660, or “OP 660”) to restrain parties from continuing with D 4670. For completeness, the husband had also filed an interlocutory application within OP 660 seeking for the matter to be expedited.

45     In short, the husband contended that proceedings in India seem to be going along its own way in spite of this Court’s decision in SUM 21. The upshot of this is that it indicates an indecisiveness on the wife’s part, and effectively amounts to her having her cake and eating it. In those circumstances, the present proceedings in D 4670 should be stayed in favour of the proceedings in India.

46     Not surprisingly, the wife disagreed with the husband’s contentions. As regards the transfer of OP 1318, Mr Segeram acknowledged the transfer order of the proceedings to Kozhikode. However, Mr Segeram mentioned that because this order was merely in furtherance of TRP 418, and nothing substantive has been done, it is speculative as to what might happen in those proceedings, if at all. Separately, in terms of the stage of those proceedings, the proceedings in D 4670 were well ahead of any of the other proceedings in India.

47     Separately, as regards OP 660, Mr Segeram brought to my attention that the Indian courts have actually conclusively dealt with the matter, and dismissed the husband’s application. In a copy of the Indian court’s decision dated 24 December 2024[note: 11], the Indian court made the following points:

On going through the entire records, I am of the considered view that the [husband] has approached this court without clean hands. So, considering the entire facts and circumstances of the case, I am not inclined to grant any kind of injunction order against the [wife].

In the result, the petition [(ie., OP 660)] is dismissed without costs.

48     The husband contends that this is not a conclusive order, because in his affidavit in support of SUM 220, there appears to be a further court date fixed for OP 660 on 1 April 2025.

49     After hearing parties, whilst I was not inclined to make a specific ruling on SUM 220 on the same day (in part because the wife has had no opportunity to properly respond to the application given the late filing by the husband), I was also not inclined to delay the hearing of D 4670 further. In this regard:

(a)     D 4670 was commenced by the October 2022. A significant amount of time had passed, with parties not finding any meaningful resolution to the matter.

(b)     At each turn, the husband had sought to prevent and/or delay the proper progress of D 4670. This includes the filing of OP 1318, the filing of SUM 21, OSN 6, and more recently the belated filing of SUM 220.

(c)     When SUM 21 was fully disposed of following the dismissal of OSN 6, the husband sought to buy himself more time by making a final attempt at seeing if the matter can be resolved. However, it would seem that the only resolution which the husband was seeking was for the wife to stop D 4670, and to have the matter litigated in India on his grievance of adultery. Put another way, the husband’s intention to resolve the matter was on the basis that it be resolved on his terms only.

(d)     When it was clear that D 4670 was going to proceed, the husband chose to only file his AEICs on the day of the trial. In addition, and perhaps trying to get another bite of the cherry, the husband filed SUM 220.

(e)     In filing SUM 220, the husband sought to make tangential and piecemeal points on the progress of the Indian proceedings. However, despite the effluxion of time, the husband readily acknowledges that further to the dismissal of SUM 21, there was no existing court order preventing this Court from proceeding with D 4670. On the contrary, as noted above, there is, at present, an express order made by the Indian court denying the husband any injunction against the wife. While the husband highlighted that he was intending to appeal against that decision, it does not change the fact there is no order preventing this Court from proceeding with D 4670.

(f)     Insofar as the husband wishes to assert that he would be prejudiced with D 4670 proceeding (at least in light of him commencing SUM 220), I was not inclined to agree. As noted above, OP 1318 was commenced after D4670. In terms of relief (ie adultery), such recourse was available to him D 4670 (had he filed his pleadings). There is nothing which he wishes to do in India which he cannot substantively achieve in Singapore. Separate from all this, the husband has fully participated in OSG 96 in Singapore. There is nothing to be gained in India other than pecuniary relief in connection with this contention of adultery. Even then, I had provisionally indicated (in the absence of anything to the contrary) in my decision in SUM 21 that such relief appears to be a separate and distinct relief which would not be extinguished even if there was a divorce order in Singapore dissolving the marriage on the grounds of adultery.

(g)     The real prejudice, if anything, to my mind, is the husband’s predilection to have the divorce concluded on his terms only.

50     It is at this point, when faced the reality that his attempts to hold off D 4670 have come to an end, the husband did what he had done previously – simply refused to participate. Whilst he had every opportunity to participate in the hearing, just before it was about to start, the husband stated the following:

[Husband]:    I don’t want to be in the trial. Your Honour.[note: 12]

51     For completeness, whilst indicating an intention not to participate in the trial, the husband attempted to raise an issue regarding the scheduling of when his witnesses were to file their AEICs. In this regard, the husband had written to Court by way of an email dated 27 January 2025 seeking, inter alia, the schedule on when his witnesses can testify, and whether they are able to give evidence remotely. For completeness, stated below is an extract of the husband’s correspondence:

4.    I would like to seek the Court’s directions and confirmation on the below –

a)    The schedule of when they can testify and whether some of them can do so by video conference via zoom or whether they must be physically present at the Court.

Analysis and Findings

73     Against the backdrop of the foregoing, I now provide my analysis and findings.

Applicable legal principles in establishing the fact of ‘unreasonable behaviour’

74     I start with applicable legal principles. For the purposes of the present proceedings, the legislative architecture governing the Court’s power to order a dissolution of a marriage on the fact of ‘unreasonable behaviour’ may be found in the then sections 95(1), (2), and (3)(b) WC, which provides as follows:

Irretrievable breakdown of marriage to be sole ground for divorce

95.—(1)    Either party to a marriage may file a writ for divorce on the ground that the marriage has irretrievably broken down.

(2)    The court hearing such proceedings must, so far as it reasonably can, inquire into the facts alleged as causing or leading to the breakdown of the marriage and, if satisfied that the circumstances make it just and reasonable to do so, grant a judgment for its dissolution.

(3)    The court hearing any proceedings for divorce is not to hold the marriage to have broken down irretrievably unless the plaintiff satisfies the court of one or more of the following facts:

…

(b)    that the defendant has behaved in such a way that the plaintiff cannot reasonably be expected to live with the defendant;

75     The oft-cited decision setting out the applicable tests to be satisfied in order to establish the fact of unreasonable behaviour is the High Court decision of Wong Siew Boey v Lee Boon Fatt [1994] 1 SLR(R) 323, where the court held (at [8]):

Whether the respondent’s behaviour has been such that the petitioner can no longer reasonably be expected to live with him is essentially a finding of fact and the courts have avoided categorising conduct as guilty or blameless in the abstract. The question whether the petitioner finds it intolerable to live with the respondent must be answered subjectively: whether his attitude is reasonable is irrelevant. In dealing with behaviour, the question is whether the petitioner can reasonably be expected to live with the respondent and it is for the court, and not the petitioner, to answer it. The test becomes objective but it is not the same as asking whether a hypothetical reasonable spouse in the petitioner’s position would continue to live with the respondent. The court must have regard to the personalities of individuals before it, however far these may be removed from some theoretical norm, and it must assess the impact of the respondent’s conduct and the particular petitioner in the light of the whole history of the marriage and their relationship.

76     As can seen from the above, in order to satisfy the legislative threshold envisaged in section 95(3)(b), it involves both a subjective and objective assessment. It is subjective insofar as to whether the applicant (in this case the wife) subjectively finds it intolerable to live with the respondent (in this case the husband). It is objective insofar as the Court is tasked to ascertain whether an applicant, with his or her personal characteristic and idiosyncrasies, and having regarding to the history of the marriage as a whole, can be reasonably expected to live with the respondent, with his or her own characteristic and idiosyncrasies.

77     I pause here and note that the foregoing deals with assessing the thresholds vis-à-vis a finding that the complained conducted took place (either by assessment of the Court or by admission or consent). It necessarily requires the Court to first undertake an examination on the existence (and so its extent) of the complained conduct or ‘unreasonable behaviour’. As to what constitutes ‘unreasonable behaviour’, I found it apposite to highlight the very recent comments made by Prof. Leong Wai Kum in Marriage, Spouses and Assets (Leong Wai Kum, 2025, Academy Publishing) (“Marriage, Spouses and Assets”) at [8.167 et seq]:

8.167 The High Court in 2009 in Teo Hoon Ping v Tan Lay Ying Angeline clarified that it has unfortunately become common to abbreviate this fact to “unreasonable behaviour”, this is a misnomer.

8.168 The provision does not require the applicant to prove that the respondent’s behaviour is objectively unreasonable. It suffices if the applicant proves some behaviour of the respondent that renders the expectation of the applicant to continue marital cohabitation with the respondent to be unreasonable. The Family Justice Courts have to assess the personalities of the parties to find that, as a result of the respondent’s behaviour, it is not unreasonable to expect the applicant to continue marital cohabitation with her.

8.169 Having said that, however, it is not a problem if the applicant manages to persuade the Family Justice Courts to find the respondent’s behaviour as objectively unreasonable. This will only aid the applicant in convincing the court that it is therefore unreasonable to expect her to continue marital cohabitation with such a spouse.

8.170  It is not necessary to find moral culpability on the part of the respondent. Even if the behaviour complained of by the applicant were something for which the respondent cannot be held morally culpable for, it should be available for use.

(emphasis added)

The state of parties’ evidence

78     It is against that backdrop where I revisit my earlier observations regarding the state of the husband’s evidence (see paragraphs 60 to 63 above). In light of the husband’s conscious decision not to participate in these proceedings, the default position is that the husband’s and his witnesses’ affidavits are not to be received as part of the evidence of these proceedings. Be that as it may, as explained earlier, I was not inclined to reject the husband’s evidence completely, but accorded it nominal weight.

79     By that same token, in light of the husband’s absence and his failure to avail himself of the right to cross examine the wife’s and YKK’s evidence, their evidence, in my view, is prima facie unchallenged. That said, and whilst not doing the husband’s job for him, I will address certain parts of the evidence adduced by the husband and the witnesses, to see whether the affidavit evidence, in itself, is able to overcome the wife’s unchallenged evidence.

Assessment of the husband’s conduct

The husband’s ‘general’ conduct of being verbally and/or physically abusive

80     In assessing the materials before me, I note that save for the specific incidents of violence in 2021 and 2022, the wife does not provide any specific particulars in her pleadings of the husband being verbally abusive. That said, I note in her AEIC that the wife makes mention of the husband belittling her in front of the domestic helper and Children,[note: 50] and that he expected her to obey all of his commands without question.[note: 51]

81     In light of the foregoing, after assessing the materials before me and notwithstanding the nominal nature of the husband’s evidence, I was unable to make a definitive finding on whether these claimed events took place. Put another way, on the wife’s own evidence, I was not inclined to find that she had discharged her burden to proving the facts which she chose to assert.

82     That said, and taking the husband’s own evidence of his discovery of the purported adultery by the wife, and the apparent oppression he was living under by the wife, it was not lost on this Court that minimally, such dissatisfaction would have influenced (or even dictated) how he conducted himself with the wife.

The incident of violence in November 2021

83     I turn next to the incident of violence on 9 November 2021 where the husband had struck the wife’s face and nose. In her evidence, she adduces the discharge summary of her visit to Parkway East Hospital on 10 November 2021, as well as the photographs she had apparently taken after the incident.

84     Unlike the earlier general averment of violence, I was satisfied that the wife had, on the materials before it, prima facie discharged her burden of establishing, on a balance of probabilities, that something happened to her. Since the husband was not present to examine the wife, these facts are not substantively challenged. That said, and for completeness, I note the husband’s evidence that it was his view that it was the wife who was violent to him that day. His assertion was that it was the wife who had kicked him, causing him to apparently suffer another heart attack.

85     After assessing parties’ evidence and materials, what is common ground is that parties were discussing the topic of divorce. The discussion got heated, and on each party’s evidence, they mentioned that it was the other person who committed violence on them first. Even if I were to accept the husband’s evidence, it still does not explain away the contemporaneous documents submitted by the wife. None of the husband’s evidence, on its face, is a complete answer towards the wife’s own documents in her AEIC.

86     For those reasons, and on a balance of probabilities on the basis of the wife’s unchallenged evidence on the matter, I was prepared to accept that parties’ undisputed argument with each other on 9 November 2021 had escalated into something more serious between the two of them. Further to my earlier observations at paragraph 82 above, what can be reasonably inferred is that by then, the husband had all but checked out from the marriage.

The husband’s late nights when he was unemployed / in between jobs

87     At the outset, in her pleadings, the wife just made the averment that the husband would generally return late at night or early in the morning. Subsequently, in her evidence, the wife did not provide any further particulars of the extent of these late nights. The wife also did not provide any particulars of her belief that the husband was “staying at some other place”. It was also only in her AEIC where she made the supposition that the late nights were connected with the husband’s improper association with SB.

88     For those reasons, and on the materials before me, I make no specific finding in respect of this issue.

Incident of family violence in 18 July 2022

89     I turn next to the alleged incident of violence of 18 July 2022, where the wife contended that the husband had, inter alia, ordered the wife to leave the matrimonial home.[note: 52] There was also an argument surrounding the issue of a divorce, which led to the husband strangling her. In her AEIC, the points raised above are substantively similar, save that the wife highlighted that the argument that day related to the husband’s purported intention to take the Children away.

90     In his AEIC[note: 53], the husband’s narrative is that it was the wife who attempted to take the Children’s passport away from him. As such, an argument ensued. In the husband’s own evidence, he acknowledged that the argument then escalated into a scuffle. While he makes mention in his police report asserting that neither party did not sustain injuries, the husband does not address the contemporaneous medical documents found in the wife’s AEIC. Such medical documents include the police medical form.[note: 54]

91     After assessing the materials before me, what is undisputed is that there was yet another disagreement between parties on marital issues (this time about the Children). What is also undisputed in both parties’ evidence is that this disagreement escalated into a scuffle. Whilst the husband may deny that he caused the wife injury (which I have my reservations about), the husband does not deny there being a physical escalation between them.

92     This is, to my mind, further evidence on the state of parties’ relationship, and how they were conducting themselves with each other.

The husband’s improper association with SB

93     I turn to the next the husband’s improper association with SB. Putting aside whether or not there was, in fact, an improper association between the husband and SB, the following facts are not disputed:

(a)     On the surveillance report, it was clear that the husband was, in my view, spending an immoderate amount of time with SB, going to her home as well as partaking in social activities with just the two of them alone.

(b)     On the husband’s own evidence, he effectively leaned on to SB as support for his “trauma” after the discovery of the wife’s alleged infidelity. By the same token, in SB’s own evidence, she acknowledges the husband’s presence in supporting her to establish a new life during the “turbulent” period of her own marriage when she was living separately from her partner.

94     At its very core, as a result of their own respective difficulties and challenges, they found support (and perhaps comfort and solace) from and with each other. The husband found joy in the company of another woman who was not the wife. It may not give rise to legal (or perhaps even moral) culpability, but it does gives an insight on the closeness between them, as evidenced in the surveillance report. Such closeness includes, from the documentary evidence, in the form of holding each other’s waist whilst walking[note: 55] and their closeness whilst having meals[note: 56]. The husband may assert that there is nothing sinister or morally culpable with his behaviour with SB, but as I had observed earlier, his behaviour with SB is a further manifestation of the underlying reality of his perspective of the marriage and how he viewed the wife. To that end, I was satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that the husband’s interactions with a woman who was not the wife was, at best, peculiar, and at worst, improper and unacceptable.

Should the marriage be dissolved?

95     When taken in its totality, and following the comments made in Marriage, Spouses and Assets I highlighted above (see paragraph 77 above), I was of the view that the conduct highlighted by the wife would make it unreasonable to expect her to continue marital cohabitation with the husband. In my judgment, for all intents and purposes, and to varying degrees and different points in time, the husband’s behaviour is indicative of someone who has all but given up on the marriage, and wishes to move on with his life. As noted earlier, his resistance is his subjective belief that he wishes to end the marriage only on his terms.

The wife’s alleged infidelity

96     For completeness, and whilst I note that this was not the husband’s pleaded case (because the husband did not file his pleadings), I found it apposite to make some provisional observations regarding the husband’s allegations of the wife’s infidelity.

97     I had earlier highlighted (see paragraph 39 above) that the husband had filed a notice of intention to refer to, inter alia, the papers filed by the wife in OSG 96. In those papers, the wife does refer to a relationship in 2016 which apparently ended in 2019. At the trial, I asked the wife about this, and she acknowledges that she was “close”[note: 57] with the husband’s brother-in-law.

98     To that end, even if a finding of adultery were to be made (which, for clarity, I do not make), I have my reservations whether the husband would be able to address the limitations set in section 95(5) WC given when the affair took place and subsequently ended. Even if I were to find that the wife had committed adultery, it does not change the fact the husband’s own behaviour rendered it unreasonable for the wife to be expected to continue marital cohabitation with the husband. Put another way, the wife’s alleged adultery, assuming if proved, does not wipe away the husband’s own conduct towards the wife.

Conclusion

99     For the above reasons, I granted the wife’s application for the marriage to be dissolved. On the issue of costs, after hearing Mr Segeram, I ordered that the husband pay the wife costs of an incidental to the hearing of D 4670, with such costs fixed at $12,500 (inclusive of disbursements). For completeness, I had also given the usual consequential directions for parties to file the necessary documents in respect of the ancillary matters.
