XFJ v XFK

XFJ v XFK
[2025] SGFC 62

Case Number:MSS 369 of 2025
Decision Date:23 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): Wife and Husband appeared in person.
Parties: XFJ — XFK

Family Law – Maintenance – Child – Whether a husband is obliged to maintain a child whom he suspects is fathered by a different man – Section 114(1) Evidence Act 1893 – Section 68 of the Women’s Charter 1961

Family Law – Maintenance – Child – Approach in factoring funds available in a Child Development Account under the Baby Bonus Scheme into the computation of child maintenance

Family Law – Interim maintenance – Wife – Whether it is reasonable for a husband to cover the costs of both hiring a domestic helper and enrolling his children in childcare centres where the wife is a working mother

23 May 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       In November 2024, the Wife applied for spousal and child maintenance against the Husband: MSS 1306 (“MSS 1306”). At the material time, she was pregnant with a second child.

2       After a trial, I made the following orders vide MO 528 (“MO 528”). See XFJ v XFK [2024] SGFC 102 (“2024 Decision”) at [6].

 

Expense item

Amount to pay

Time for payment

(a)

Interim child maintenance for the daughter

$200/month

(1) By the 15th day of each month.

(2) To begin from December 2024.

(b)

Costs of getting a person to assist the Wife to care for the daughter and the newborn baby.

$400/month

(1) By the 15th day of each month.

(2) To begin from January 2025.

 

Total

$600/month

 



The present application

3       In January 2025, the Wife gave birth to a son. In February 2025, she applied for additional child maintenance of $840 against the Husband: MSS 369/2025 (“MSS 369”).[note: 1]

4       The Husband objected to the Wife’s application on two grounds. First, he “suspected” that the son was not his. Second, he was already paying maintenance pursuant to MO 528 and there was thus no need to pay further maintenance.

5       After hearing the evidence, I decided to order the Husband to pay $650/month for the son’s maintenance. In this judgement, I will provide my reasons for this decision.

No variation to the daughter’s maintenance

6       Before explaining my reasons, I wish to touch very briefly on the daughter’s maintenance for completeness.

7       In MSS 369, the Wife did not adduce any evidence to show that there had been a material change in the daughter’s circumstances or that the child’s maintenance in MO 528 is inadequate. This is not surprising, given that (a) the daughter is still very young (only about two years old, born in August 2022) and (b) her maintenance was ordered just about six months ago.

8       Accordingly, in addressing MSS 369, I saw no need to vary my order in MO 528 that the Husband is to pay the Wife $200 for the daughter’s food and groceries: see 2024 Decision at [10] to [17]. This order was made on the basis that the Husband is to himself cover two of the daughter’s expenses (instead of making payment for them to the Wife). These are, first, the costs of the daughter’s diapers (2024 Decision at [18] and [19]), and second, her childcare fees after the funds in her Child Development Account (“CDA”) has been depleted (2024 Decision at [21]). Presently, these fees stand at about $339/month.[note: 2]

Whether the Husband is liable to maintain the son

9       Thus, for the purpose of MSS 369, I focussed on whether it is appropriate to order the Husband to pay maintenance for the son. I begin with the Husband’s submission that he is not liable to maintain the son because he “suspects” that the child’s father is someone else.

Observations in the 2024 Decision

10     It is useful to note that the Husband had made a similar submission in MSS 1306. My response to this submission is contained in the following observations in the 2024 Decision:

32    With regards to the Husband’s [submission that he could not be sure that the unborn child is his], the following bears highlighting.

(a)     First, the Husband does not deny that he had sexual relations with the Wife during the period when the unborn child was conceived, i.e., April 2024. There is no evidence that the Wife had sexual relations with any other man during this time. In these circumstances, it is reasonable to infer that the Husband is the unborn child’s father.

(b)     Second, s 114(1) of the Evidence Act 1893 is relevant. It provides that –

Where any person was born —

(a)    during the continuance of a valid marriage between his or her mother and any man; or

(b)    within 280 days after the dissolution of the marriage, the mother remaining unmarried,

it is presumed that the person is the legitimate child of that man, unless the contrary is proved.

[emphasis added]

(c)    Section 114(1) presumes that a man is the father of a child if it is born within a prescribed period. Strictly speaking, s 114(1) does not apply in the present case because the child which the Wife is carrying has not been born yet. That said, it must logically follow from s 114(1) that a man can be inferred to be the father of an unborn child if the child will be born within the period prescribed in s 114(1).

33    To sum-up, it is reasonable to infer that the Husband is the father of the unborn child. There is no need for the Wife to adduce further proof of the child’s paternity – such as by tendering a DNA report. If the Husband wishes to disprove the reasonable inference, then he is free to take the relevant actions at his own costs.

[text in square brackets added, italics in original text]

Husband is presumed to be the father

11     Returning to MSS 369, I find that it is reasonable to presume that the Husband is the son’s father – both as a matter of fact and in law:

(a)      First, the Husband had admitted to having sexual relations with the Wife around April[note: 3] / May 2024.[note: 4] The son – a second child for the Wife – was born in January 2025. The son’s date of birth falls within the usual gestation period for a child.

(b)      Second, the son was born during the continuance of the marriage between the Husband and the Wife. By virtue of s 114(1)(a) of the Evidence Act 1893, it is presumed that the son is the Husband’s legitimate child, unless the contrary is proved.

12     Thus, if the Husband wishes to rebut the paternity presumption, then he has the burden to produce the relevant evidence.

Husband had failed to rebut the paternity presumption

13     In this regard, the Husband provided the following reasons for suspecting that the son is not his.

(a)      First, the Husband had caught the Wife in the company of different men on three to four occasions in the past few years. On one of these occasions, he saw her drinking red wine with a man on her bed in the living room.

(b)      Second, the Wife had showed the Husband her WeChat thread with a man. She told him that the man was willing to take care of the children and her.

(c)      Finally, the son’s surname is “Chen”. It is different from the Husband’s surname (“Zhan”) but is the same as the surname of the man referred to in [13(b)] above.

14     In my view, the above are insufficient to rebut the paternity presumption. Specifically, they do not prove that (a) the Wife had sexual intercourse with any of the men referred to by the Husband, or (b) one of them had fathered the son.

15     To conclusively prove that the son is not his, the Husband could have done a DNA test. Despite being informed of this in November 2024 (see the 2024 Decision at [33]), he had failed to take the necessary actions in the past six months.

16     In the circumstances, the paternity presumption has not been rebutted – and the Husband is presumed to be the son’s father. Pursuant to s 68 of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“Charter”), he has a duty to maintain the son.

Son’s expenses

17     Next, I consider the son’s monthly expenses.

18     The Wife’s computation,[note: 5] and my determination, of these expenses are as follows. (Note. The Husband did not provide his computation of the son’s expenses.)

 

Expense item

$1,005



Baby Bonus Scheme

19     In deciding how much the Husband ought to contribute to the son’s maintenance, it is reasonable to consider the fact that the parties have access to funds under the Baby Bonus Scheme. Under this scheme, the son will receive (a) a Baby Bonus Cash Gift and (b) funds under the CDA First Step Grant. These funds (which are substantial) will be deposited into the son’s CDA as follows:[note: 15]

Child’s age

20     A significant component of the son’s monthly expenses are the fees for his enrolment into childcare/kindergarten – $735. In this regard, I note that funds in the CDA can be used to pay for such expenses.

21     During the trial, it appears that the Wife manages the son’s CDA. Given the Baby Bonus Scheme, it is appropriate to adjust downwards the son’s monthly expenses which the parties must bear from their own resources.

22     In my view, it will not be appropriate to make the adjustment on the basis that the relevant child’s monthly expenses are to be fully paid from the CDA. This is especially so where the paying parent is gainfully employed and can afford to pay the child’s expenses from his/her monthly income. As a matter of financial prudence, the adjustment should be conservative. This will allow the Baby Bonus dollars to be stretched for a longer period over to cover the relevant child’s monthly expenses.

23     Accordingly, I adjust this to $800/month – on the basis that the balance $205/month will be paid via funds in the son’s CDA.

Husband’s share of the son’s expenses

24     The next issue is how much of the son’s expenses (at $800/month) should be borne by the Husband. To address this issue, it will be necessary to assess the parties’ relative income ratio.

Husband’s income

25     I start with the Husband’s income.

(a)     According to the Wife, the Husband’s average monthly income (after CPF deductions) should be $10,411. She derived this figure by (i) totalling his monthly income over six months from October 2024 to March 2025[note: 16] and (ii) thereafter dividing the total income by six months.

(b)     The Husband disagreed with the Wife’s computation. According to him, his December 2024 income included an annual wage supplement (“AWS”) component, and his January 2025 income included a bonus component. The Husband submitted that the AWS and bonus components should be divided over 12 months – and not six months as contended by the Wife. This is because these components were earned over the course of a year. According to him, his average monthly income should be $8,000+.

26     I accept the Husband’s method of computation. Based on his method, the Husband’s average monthly income (after CPF deductions) should be $8,392.[note: 17]

Wife’s income

27     The Wife’s average monthly income (after CPF deductions) is $1,921.[note: 18]

28     Given the above, the parties’ relative income ratio is thus as follows:

Husband can afford to pay the son’s maintenance

30     The next question is whether the Husband can afford to pay a maintenance of $650/month. In this regard, his monthly income and expenses are as follows:

31     At this juncture, I wish to highlight the following regarding my assessment of some of the expense items:

(a)     Item [30(e)] – Since March 2025, the Husband had been caring for the daughter from Thursdays (night) to Mondays (night). According to him, he would spend $200/month for the daughter’s food and snacks. In my view, this amount seems to be excessive – given that (i) the daughter is only about two years old, (ii) the Husband’s take care of her for only half a week, and (iii) the amount of $200/month is in addition to the milk powder that he is paying monthly: see item [30(f)]. Accordingly, I reduced the amount for item [30(e)] from $200 to $100.

(b)     Item [30(j)] – Since March 2025, the Husband had moved out of the matrimonial home and has been renting a room of his own. The figure of $450 in item [30(j)] is derived by deducting the costs of renting the room ($1,050: see Exhibit C3) from the rental income that the Husband receives from letting out a room in the home ($1,500).

(c)     Item [30(p)] – According to the Husband, he gives $1,200/month as allowance to his parents. The Wife disputes this, claiming that he has in fact been siphoning this amount from the matrimonial assets. I wish to make clear that in factoring item [30(p)] into the computation, I make no finding whether the funds were in fact given to the Husband’s parents. I have included this item purely for the purpose of assessing whether the Husband can afford to pay the son’s maintenance at $650/month – assuming that he pays $1,200/month to his parents. I will leave it to the judge hearing the ancillary matters relating to the parties’ divorce to determine the issue raised by the Wife.

(d)     Item [30(q)] – In his statement filed on 8 April 2025 (Exhibit R1), the Husband stated that he had taken loans from three banks. He however did not state how much he must repay monthly. The figure of $1,000 is based on his evidence during the trial.

32     From [30] above, it appears that after deducting his monthly expenses, the Husband has a cash balance of at least $695.52/month, if not more. I say “at least” because it is not disputed that for –

(a)     Item [30(b)] – The mortgage ($1,978/month) is paid from the Husband’s CPF accounts – and not in cash.

(b)     Item [30(g)] – The childcare fees ($339/month) can be paid from the daughter’s CDA. This account is presently managed by the Husband. The child is now over the age of two. Under the Baby Bonus Scheme, there will be a top up of $400 every six months into her CDA until she is six and a half years old: see [19] above.

33     If one were to exclude the Husband’s mortgage payment (because it is not paid from his monthly income), he will have at least $2,673.52/month balance each month. In my view, the Husband can afford to pay to the Wife a sum of $650/month for the son’s maintenance.

34     Accordingly, I ordered that the Husband is to pay $650/month to the Wife for the son’s maintenance. This sum is to be paid into the Wife’s UOB account xxx666 by the 15th day of each month, commencing from June 2025.

Conclusion

35     Before concluding, I wish to briefly address a point raised by the Husband. According to him, the Wife is making a “double claim” by asking him to cover the costs of both (1) hiring a domestic helper and (2) enrolling the children in childcare centres. The Husband submitted that –

(a)     The helper can care for the son – there is no need to send him to childcare, and

(b)     The Wife should be made to choose either (1) or (2) – she should not have both.

36     The Wife submitted that the Husband’s position is unreasonable:

(a)      First, the Wife would not be able to care for the two children – a toddler and an infant – all by herself.

(b)      Second, while the domestic helper can assist with the household chores, she is not suitable for taking care of the children’s developmental needs. It is more appropriate to send them to childcare centres where there would be professionals to take care of their needs.

37     I find the Wife’s submission to be reasonable. Additionally, I wish to reiterate the following observations that I have made in the 2024 Decision at [28].

(b)      ... in addition to alleviating the Wife’s burden, a helper can allow the Wife to rejoin the workforce as soon as possible. This will provide the Wife with financial independence and the ability to have an income to maintain herself, the children and the household.

(c)      ... the fact that the Wife has an income will also mean that there is less reliance on the Husband to finance her expenses. In other words, the Husband will also benefit from the employment of a helper.

[note: 1]According to the Complainant’s Statement filed on 13 March 2025 (A1) at page 3, the Wife is “asking for fixed monthly maintenance of S$840”. This can give the impression that she is seeking child maintenance of $840 for both children. During the hearing on 15 May 2025, the Wife clarified that the amount of $840 is in addition to the $600/month maintenance that had already been ordered.

[note: 2]See Exhibit C2 at page 1; Exhibit R1 at page 15.

[note: 3]Husband’s evidence in MSS 1306. See the 2024 Decision at [32(a)].

[note: 4]Husband’s evidence during examination-in-chief in MSS 369.

[note: 5]The computation is summarised in Exhibit C2.

[note: 6]In Exhibit C2, the Wife had indicated that the computation for this expense item at $200 is for both children.

[note: 7]The Wife had provided evidence to support her computation: Exhibit C1 at page 61. The Husband did not produce any evidence to discredit this computation.

[note: 8]To commence when the son is around six months old.

[note: 9]This figure is based on the Wife’s indication in Exhibit C1 at page 14 and her testimony on 15 May 2025.

[note: 10]In Exhibit C2, the Wife had indicated that the computation for this expense item is for both children at three sets/year.

[note: 11]The Wife had provided evidence to support her computation: Exhibit C1 at pages 57 and 58. The Husband did not produce any evidence to discredit this computation.

[note: 12]The son is an infant of about four months old. He is likely to incur any expenses for travel and outings in Singapore. If the Wife intends to bring the son out of Singapore, then it is reasonable that she pays for such expenses on her own.

[note: 13]In Exhibit C2, the Wife had indicated that the computation for this expense item is for both children.

[note: 14]The Wife’s computation of $681.66 consists of (A) utilities and (B) expenses related to the domestic helper. Regarding Item (A), the Wife computed the son’s share by dividing the household’s monthly utilities ($150) equally between four persons. This results in the son’s share being $37.50. In my view, this is excessive. Logically, the adults’ share of the utilities (i.e., the Wife and the helper) ought to be higher than the children’s share (consisting of a toddler and an infant). Item (B) should be excluded. I had already ordered the Husband to pay $400/month towards the costs of getting a person to assist the Wife to care for the daughter and the newborn baby: see [2] above.My determination of $30/month for item (l) includes the expense items in [18(a)] and [18(f)].

[note: 15]See https://www.babybonus.msf.gov.sg

[note: 16]The Husband’s monthly income can be found in Exhibit R1 pages 27 to 29.

[note: 17]Based on [(a) + (b) + (c)] divide by 6.(a)Six months of annual bonus component [i.e., $17,936.70 divide by two] (b)Six months of AWS component [i.e., $6,138 divide by two](c)Six months’ income from October 2024 to March 2025 [i.e., $38,313]

[note: 18]This is based on the average of the Wife’s “net wage” reflected in her income slips from September 2024 to February 2025. These slips can be found in Exhibit C1 at pages 64 to 69.

[note: 19]Amounts for expense items based on Exhibit R1 at pages 6 and 12 to 14.

[note: 20]In the Husband’s computation, he had included, as a separate expense item ($200) as the daughter’s “food and snacks”. This appears to be duplication of the food and groceries expenses ordered under MO 528/2024.

[note: 21]Regarding the diapers, see [8] above. As for the milk powder, the Husband had voluntarily paid for this item when he takes care of the daughter half of the week.

html:
XNC v XNB

XNC v XNB
[2025] SGFC 61

Case Number:SS 2327 of 2024
Decision Date:21 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Wife in person and unrepresented; The Husband in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XNC — XNB

Family Law – Family Violence – Personal Protection Order

21 May 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       This was a dispute between the Wife and her Husband. SS 2327/2024 was the Wife’s application for a Personal Protection Order (“PPO”) against the Husband.

2       I heard the trial of the matter on 14 March 2025. After considering the evidence and testimony before me, as well as oral submissions from parties, I dismissed the Wife’s application in SS 2327. These are my grounds of decision.

3       In order for the Wife to succeed in her application, she had to establish, on a balance of probabilities, the following two requirements:

(a)     That an act of family violence (as defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter)[note: 1] had been committed by the Husband, or that it was likely that the Husband would commit family violence.

(b)     That it is necessary for the court to grant her the PPO.

4       The Wife’s complaint was based on continual harassment. She pointed to an argument which she had with the Husband on 2 December 2024. She also gave evidence about a tracker which she says the Husband had planted on her, as well as a camera which the Husband had placed in the living room in a rattan box.

5       The Wife also highlighted what she says is a pattern of escalating verbal abuse on the Husband’s part in the weeks leading up to this trial, which includes a text message that the Husband had sent on 24 Feb 2025 where he had allegedly tried to get her to have sex with him.

6       As to what constitutes continual harassment, that is usefully summarised in XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103:

37    To prove family violence under the “continual harassment” limb, the following must be established:

(a)    The respondent has committed “harassment” – i.e., an act of annoying or worrying the applicant by putting pressure on him/her or saying or doing unpleasant things to him/her.[note: 22]

(b)    The harassment is “continual” – i.e., repeated, repetitive.

(c)    The respondent has carried out the continual harassment with the intention or the knowledge that it is likely to cause “anguish” – i.e., severe pain, mental suffering, or unhappiness – to the applicant.

Courts have recognised repetitive conduct that causes worry, emotional distress or annoyance as coming within the scope of “continual harassment” under limb (d): see e.g., Yue Tock Him v Yee Ee Lim [2011] SGDC 99 at [33].

7       Examples of continual harassment include the repeated use of vulgarities (XFL v XFM at [38]), entering the applicant’s room numerous times despite being aware that the applicant was not comfortable with this (XEN v XEO [2024] SGFC 94), and repeatedly texting an applicant and sending sexually explicit and humiliating pictures (XDV v XDW [2024] SGFC 87 at [13]).

8       While the cases provide a flavour of what might constitute continual harassment, it goes without saying that the assessment of whether there had been any continual harassment in a given case is necessarily one that must be ascertained based on the facts and taking into account the context of those acts.

9       In the present case, I found that the Husband had indeed committed family violence (specifically, continual harassment) by planting the tracker in the Wife’s handbag so as to keep tabs on her whereabouts.

10     The Husband did admit to planting the trackers – his reason is that he wanted to know where the Wife would go. In his words:[note: 2]

Husband:    Because she never tell me where she goes alright. She goes out without telling me and whenever I go home, alright, the, you know, the house is always in a mess and I was wondering, you know, as a housewife why the house is always in a mess, what have you been doing at home? Where do you go? Okay. So, I---as a husband, the husband, right, I think every husband would want to know where the ha---the wife go to and if the wife never---refuse to tell me, to tell the husband, of course the husband, you know, feels insecure and wants to find out very soon what’s going on.

11     While one may be able to understand the Husband’s anxiety at not knowing the Wife’s whereabouts – at the end of the day, a key element in the assessment of whether there had been continual harassment is whether the respondent knew that such an act would cause anguish, or was likely to cause anguish to the family member concerned.

12     In the present case, I found that the Husband knew that planting the tracker was likely to cause anguish (ie, annoy) the Wife. This is because at the time the tracker was planted, relations between the Wife and the Husband were strained. The Husband did also acknowledge that the Wife might be distressed if she discovered the tracker.[note: 3] The Husband also stated, in his own words, that the Wife would get easily distressed and “triggered” over minor incidents.[note: 4]

13     Given the Husband’s knowledge of the Wife’s disposition, and her emotional state of mind given this period of elevated tensions between the both of them, it was clear to me that he would know that planting the tracker was likely to cause her anguish.

14     Having found that there was an act of family violence committed – I turn next to consider the necessity of ordering a PPO. This is essentially a risk assessment where the court considers the likelihood of the respondent committing family violence against the applicant in the future. Some factors that the court will consider include: the reasons for the family violence, whether the family violence is a recent occurrence, and whether there are any material changes in circumstances: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [20].

15     In the present case, I did not find it necessary to order a PPO. It is clear that this dispute arose out of the deterioration of marital relations between the parties. Parties did not have healthy ways of communicating with each other, expressing their needs and desires, and this torpedoed efforts to find common ground and rekindle the love that they must have once had.

16     That being said, parties are going for counselling in an attempt to resolve their differences. To that end, the Husband did express his commitment to continuing with counselling sessions in the hopes of salvaging the marriage.[note: 5] The Husband had also stated and expressed his desire to keep the family together despite the fact that the Wife has commenced divorce proceedings in the Syariah court.[note: 6] He also stated that since the Wife discovered the tracker, he has not attempted to keep tabs on her whereabouts, nor had he attempted to plant other trackers in her handbags.[note: 7] This suggested, to me, that the Husband had reflected on the impact that his actions in planting the tracker had on the Wife, and had taken steps to change his behaviour.

17     Given the points that I have sketched out above, I arrived at the conclusion that the risk of the Husband committing family violence against the Wife, in the future, was low and the circumstances therefore did not justify the need to order a PPO. In particular, I gave weight to the fact that the Husband genuinely wanted to save the marriage and appeared to be actively taking steps to repair his relationship with the Wife.

18     I therefore dismissed the Wife’s application in SS 2327. Given that the Husband did not seek costs, I made no order as to costs.

[note: 1]References to the Women’s Charter 1961 in this judgment are references to the version in force before 2 January 2025.

[note: 2]Transcript, p 34, lns 16 – 25.

[note: 3]Transcript, p 34 at lns 29 – 31.

[note: 4]Transcript, pp 34 – 35.

[note: 5]Transcript, p 38, lns 8 – 10. See also Transcript, p 50, lns 24 – 30.

[note: 6]Transcript, p 38, lns 1 – 3.

[note: 7]Transcript, p 52, lns 23 – 32.

XMS v XMT

Women’s Charter

Maintenance

Variation

19 May 2025

District Judge Sheik Mustafa:

Introduction

1       In this case the plaintiff is the Father, and the defendant is the Mother of a child. This is an application by the Father to vary 2 existing court orders on 3 aspects; firstly regarding access to the child, secondly regarding the disposal of the matrimonial home, and thirdly regarding maintenance to be paid for the child.

2       Of the original orders, the first was issued in January 2020, and this order was about the custody care and control, as well as access of the child. The second order was issued in March 2020, and this order dealt with disposal of matrimonial assets and maintenance of the child. Under this order, the Father was to pay a monthly sum of $1,750.00 for the maintenance of the child.

3       Both orders were made by consent of parties.

4       In July 2024, the Father filed an application to vary the terms of the orders.

5       In December 2024, the matter came for hearing before me. The Father’s counsel appeared on his behalf. The Mother represented herself. I heard both sides. I interviewed the child and ascertained his wishes.

6       On 21 February 2025, I issued my decision via a registrar’s notice. I made orders on all 3 issues.

7       Regarding access to the child, I made an order mostly to reflect his preferences and to suit his living arrangements.

8       On the disposal of the matrimonial home, I dismissed the Father’s prayer for interest on his share of the matrimonial home. I ordered costs in the Father’s favour to be deducted from the Mother’s share of the sale proceeds. I made orders to facilitate the carrying out of the sale of the home as ordered in the original order.

9       On maintenance, I ordered the Father to pay to the Mother a monthly sum of $1,200.00 as the cash portion of child maintenance. I also ordered for the following expenses to be shared equally with the Mother:

1.     Tuition / enrichment classes; and

2.     Year-end school expenses, including school uniform, school bags, textbooks and school shoes.

10     The Father appeals against only the portion of my order regarding maintenance.

Background

11     In the original order of March 2020, the parties had consented that the Father to pay a monthly sum of $1,750.00 as maintenance for the child of the marriage. For the avoidance of doubt, the monthly sum of $1,750.00 payable by the Father, consists of 70% of the Child’s monthly expenses (i.e. by salary ratio) which consists of the following items:

pay a monthly sum of $450 as the cash portion of child maintenance and for the following expenses to be shared based on parties’ respective financial means:

Tuition / enrichment classes; and

Year-end school expenses, including school uniform, school bags, textbooks and school shoes.

Hearing

14     The Father’s case is that he is seeking a variation of the maintenance payable by him for the child to be reduced from $1,750.00 to $450.00 a month.

15     He argues that there has been a material change in circumstances. At the time of the original orders the child was 12 years old. since then, the child has completed secondary school. The childcare/student care expense is no longer applicable as it has ceased. This comprised $350.00. He also says that the student care surcharge of $50.00 for school holidays has also ceased. The tuition payments have also ceased.

16     The Father says that the child will need more pocket money and so he increased it to $200.00 a month, and transport expenses from $20.00 to $49.00 a month.

17     The Father argues that with an increase of access with him, the Father would be bearing a higher share of the child’s day-to-day expenses, so this component should be lower than $711.75.

24     I do not accept that the Father’s share of 70% ought to be varied. It was something agreed to by both parents at the time of the original order. I do not find evidence that the relative means of the parents have changed significantly enough to warrant a change in their respective shares. I do not find that the figure is beyond the Father’s means. On the Father’s argument that he will be having more access time with the child, I find that the relative amounts of time spent by the child with either parent cannot yet be specified. The child will be in polytechnic, and he is able to travel independently. During my interview with him, he envisages spending time with each parent depending on where he would be.

25     Regarding tuition and year-end expenses, at the time of the hearing, the child has not yet obtained a place in polytechnic, so the fixed expenses he will incur were not known. However, tuition and year-end expenses are occasional and not dependent on time spent with either parent. I agree with the Father that it is fair and just for each parent to bear the child’s tuition and year-end expenses equally. I depart from the 70% share for the Father for this item because I find that it is fair and just to do so in view of the Father bearing the child’s polytechnic and university expenses solely.

html:
XMU v XMV

XMU v XMV
[2025] SGFC 58

Case Number:Divorce No 1550 of 2022
Decision Date:19 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Patrick Tay Wei Sheng
Counsel Name(s): Yap Teong Liang (T L Yap Law Chambers LLC) for the applicant; Tan Keng Loon Clarence (UniLegal LLC) for the respondent.
Parties: XMU — XMV

Family Law – Matrimonial Proceedings – Ancillary Matters

19 May 2025

District Judge Patrick Tay Wei Sheng:

1       The husband is a citizen of Singapore. The wife is a citizen of China. They married in 2018 and have no children. They fell out in or around 2022, and the husband commenced these proceedings for divorce that same year. Interim judgment of divorce was granted in 2023, and the ancillary matters of this divorce came before me for hearing. I upheld a pre-nuptial agreement between the spouses dated February 2018 that ringfenced several assets that were owed solely by the wife from division in a divorce between the spouses. I thus found that the value of the pool of matrimonial assets in these proceedings was $936,000 and divided it 55:45 in favour of the husband. I also declined to order any spousal maintenance.

2       These decisions were rendered on 14 November 2024. On 27 November 2024, the husband wrote to the court expressing his intention to file an appeal against these decisions but stating that technical difficulties were preventing him from doing so. With the consent of the wife, the time for the filing of the appeal was extended, and the husband filed the appeal on 17 February 2025.

3       I now provide my reasons for these decisions.

2018 Agreement

4       I begin with the 2018 Agreement,[note: 1] which related to several assets that had been acquired by the wife before the marriage. These assets comprised three bank accounts in the sole name of the wife (two with DBS Bank and one with Citibank) that had a total value of $1,966,613 at the time of these proceedings as well as four apartments in Shanghai, China for which no valuation was provided. For convenience, I refer to these assets as the “disputed assets”.

5       Apart from these assets, the 2018 Agreement covered a company that the wife had incorporated in 2016, which was two years before the marriage. This company operated two businesses: the sale of medical devices and the conduct of education on medical aesthetics services. For convenience, I refer to this company as the “medical device company”.

6       The 2018 Agreement prescribed that the disputed assets and the medical device company “shall NOT form part of the Parties’ matrimonial assets liable to division whether during the course of the marriage or upon the breakdown of the marriage” (see clause 11 of the 2018 Agreement). It confirmed that the wife was the “sole owner” of the medical device company and that all proceeds therefrom including “investments made/assets acquired and/or income derived from the Company and/or investments” were likewise excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets (see clause 12 of the 2018 Agreement). It recorded that each spouse was at liberty to deal with his/her pre-marital assets “including any subsequent asset derived [there]from” and that “any subsequent increment in value” of the pre-marital assets were likewise excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets (see clause 13 of the 2018 Agreement).

7       The husband asked me to disregard the 2018 Agreement because it had been “procured under coercions and/or duress and in bad faith.” He explained that it had been sent to him for his review only two days before the wedding, and that he had been coerced into signing it because “he had no other choice as preparations for the wedding etc was already done”.[note: 2] The wife replied that the 2018 Agreement should be upheld because the process by which it had been entered into was fair. First, she had asked the husband to seek independent legal advice on its terms prior to the marriage. Second, she had proposed to postpone the marriage had the husband required more time to consider its terms. Third, she had invited the husband to propose an addendum its terms even after the marriage, and he had declined to take up this invitation.[note: 3]

8       Pursuant to s 112(2)(e) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed) (the “Charter”), the court in dividing matrimonial assets may consider any agreement between the parties on the ownership and division of the matrimonial assets. Specifically, a pre-nuptial agreement that relates to the division of matrimonial assets between a set of spouses falls within the ambit of this provision (see TQ v TR [2009] 2 SLR(R) 961 (“TQ v TR”) at [73]). Still, the task of the court in dividing a pool of matrimonial assets remains that of apportioning the fruits of the marriage in a just and equitable manner. Hence, the weight to be attached to a pre-nuptial agreement will depend on the circumstances of the case. Some factors that the court may consider in the matrimonial assets include the fairness of the process by which the pre-nuptial agreement had been reached and any pressure that one spouse had exerted on the other in the reaching of the pre-nuptial agreement (see UKA v UKB [2018] 4 SLR 779 at [21]).

9       At the outset, the 2018 Agreement provided that it would be governed according to the law of the People’s Republic of China and required the spouses to submit to the exclusive jurisdiction of the Chinese courts in resolving all disputes and claims arising thereunder (see clause 17 of the 2018 Agreement). Upon my directions, the wife obtained and the husband did not challenge a legal opinion by a Chinese solicitor on the effect of this clause. The Chinese solicitor opined that the Chinese courts “generally uphold pre-nuptial agreements when dividing assets, giving full effect to clear terms and respecting the written stipulations agreed upon by the parties.” Specifically, save that a Chinese court would not exercise jurisdiction over assets located outside of the geographical territory of China, “it is highly likely that clauses 11, 12, and 13 of the [2018 Agreement] would be deemed valid and enforceable” and that “These clauses conform the legal provisions regarding asset division and protection within marriage under Chinese legislation”.[note: 4] Based on this legal opinion and given that the husband had submitted to the matrimonial jurisdiction of the Singapore courts in commencing the divorce proceedings in Singapore, I found that the 2018 Agreement was a relevant factor in the these proceedings.

10     As for the weight to be placed on the 2018 Agreement, I agreed with the wife that the process by which it had been entered had been fair. First, the husband had two full days to consider the 2018 Agreement but simply insisted that the wife was “being unreasonable and ridiculous” in putting it before him. Second, the husband had been urged to take independent legal advice before signing the 2018 Agreement but did not make any effort to seek such advice. Third, the husband could have delayed the wedding until after he had reviewed the 2018 Agreement but went ahead to enter into it. Fourth, the husband had a further opportunity even after the wedding to propose an addendum to the 2018 Agreement but declined to avail of this opportunity. I could not therefore agree with the husband that his entry into the 2018 Agreement had been procured by coercion, duress, or bad faith.

11     The window that the husband had to review the 2018 Agreement had also to be considered in the context of the wider relationship between the then-spouses-to-be in respect of the business endeavours of the wife. The medical device company had been incorporated in 2016 with its entire shareholding issued to the husband. Four days later, the husband executed a declaration of trust that stipulated that the wife had the beneficial ownership of those shares.[note: 5] Eleven months thereafter, the husband transferred the legal title of those shares to the wife.[note: 6] Even as the husband served as a nominee director in the medical device company in the time that followed, he did so without any legal or beneficial interest therein. In this way, the then-spouses-to-be had structured the business to ringfence to the wife the title to and proceeds from the medical device company. As the husband admitted, he had despite his nominee directorship not been involved in the operations of the of the medical device company until he lost his job in “early 2018”.[note: 7] The ringfencing of the medical device company to the wife through the 2016 Trust was consistent with the roles that the then-spouses-to-be played in the medical device company.

12     The 2018 Agreement ostensibly extended this ringfencing of the assets of the wife to survive an irretrievable breakdown in the marriage of the spouses. Thereunder, the ownership of and proceeds from the medical device company were ringfenced to the wife. Thereunder, too, the disputed assets, which comprised the bank accounts into which the proceeds from the medical device company had been paid as well as other assets that had been owned solely by the wife, were likewise ringfenced to the wife. In isolation, the two days that the husband had to review the 2018 Agreement may not have been a generous window. But in the context of the longstanding ringfencing to the wife of the medical device company and its proceeds, that window and the wider process by which the 2018 Agreement had been entered were generally fair. Consequently, it was just and equitable to uphold the 2018 Agreement and thereby exclude from these ancillary matters the medical device company and the disputed assets.

Valuation of matrimonial assets

13     The matrimonial assets of significance, as set out in the Facts and Positions’ Sheets filed by each spouse, were as follow:

(a)     The matrimonial home (and the loan thereon);

(b)     The husband’s ice cream business;

(c)     The husband’s paintings;

(d)     The husband’s Mercedes Benz E200 car;

(e)     The husband’s Central Provident Fund (“CPF”) balances;

(f)     The wife’s collection of luxury goods;

(g)     The wife’s Porsche 911 car; and

(h)     The wife’s CPF balances.

Matrimonial home and loan thereon

14     The matrimonial home was an apartment in Singapore that was held in the name of the husband. The wife initially submitted that it had a market value of $950,000 but subsequently argued that it had a value of $1,080,000. The husband submitted that its market value was $858,000, and, in any event, no more than $950,000.[note: 8]

15     To support the figure of $1,080,000, the wife adduced a valuation report from a firm of property valuers that was dated 20 September 2024.[note: 9] The valuers had compared the matrimonial home with similar properties that had been transacted in comparable localities. But the valuers did not conduct any site inspection of the premises. Instead, they based their valuation on photographs and floor plans of the premises as well as the fact that the premises had been renovated in or around 2021 at a cost of $254,481.

16     In my view, the valuation of $1,080,000 by the valuers on 20 September 2024 was a reasonable estimate of the market value of the matrimonial home. This was the most up-to-date estimate of its market value and represented a fair value that could be realised from its sale. Indeed, the submission of the husband that the matrimonial home had a value of $950,000 was not far from this figure. Given that a sale of the matrimonial home would inevitably incur expenses that would reduce its eventual proceeds, I used $1,000,000 as its value in the pool of matrimonial assets.

17     It was undisputed that the outstanding loan on the matrimonial home was $369,510. The net value or equity of the spouses in the matrimonial home was thus $630,490.

Vehicles

18     The spouses owned a car each. The husband owned a Mercedes Benz E200. The wife owned a Porsche 911.

19     For the Mercedes Benz E200, the husband submitted that it had a market value of $133,800 and an outstanding loan of $77,830. The wife did not dispute these figures. The equity of this car in the pool of matrimonial assets was thus $55,970.

20     For the Porsche 911, the wife estimated, and the husband did not dispute, that it had a value of $250,000 as at September 2023. But the husband pointed out, and that wife did not dispute, that two months later, the Certificate of Entitlement of the car (the “COE”) was renewed at a cost of $140,000. The husband thus submitted that the car had a value of $400,000 at the time of these proceedings, which approximated the sum of the $250,000 value of the body of the car and the $140,000 fresh COE. The wife, however, maintained that the value of the car was $250,000.

21     As Choo Han Teck J observed in VQF v VQG [2024] SGHCF 4 at [1], the date for ascertaining the pool of matrimonial assets is the date of the interim judgment, which dissolves the marriage. On the other hand, the date for valuing the assets and liabilities in that pool of matrimonial assets is typically the date of the hearing of the ancillary matters. Nevertheless, bank account balances and CPF account balances are be valued as of the date of the interim judgment. For such money accounts, the economic fruits of the marriage are the monies in the accounts rather than the accounts themselves. The quantum of the monies that represent the fruits of the marriage crystallises when the marriage is dissolved through the passing of the interim judgment.

22     The interim judgment in these proceedings was granted in May 2023. At that time, the Porsche 911 comprised the body of the car and a soon-to-expire COE. The best estimate of the value of this car body and COE as at the hearing of the ancillary matters was $250,000. That, after the interim judgment, the wife had renewed the COE at a further expenditure of $140,000 was akin to her acquisition of a fresh asset after the marriage had been dissolved. Such an asset would not have been acquired “before the marriage” or “during the marriage” and could not therefore be a “matrimonial asset” within s 112(10) of the Charter. This was especially when the $140,000 expenditure appeared to have been paid by the wife other than from the matrimonial assets. The fresh COE, as distinct from the body of the car, could not therefore fall within the pool of matrimonial assets in these proceedings. The value of the Porsche 911 in the pool of matrimonial assets was thus $250,000.

Remaining matrimonial assets

23     The remaining matrimonial assets were the CPF balances of each spouse, a collection of luxury goods that belonged to the wife, the husband, an ice cream business that was owned and operated by the husband, and two paintings that belonged to the husband. Apart from those CPF balances, however, there was a paucity of evidence on the values of the remaining matrimonial assets. This paucity was consistent with the manner that the spouses had ordered their financial affairs: each operated their own enterprise and each acquired their own possessions, as seen in their execution of the 2018 Agreement and the proposal by the wife that the husband, like her, put forward a list of his assets that were to be insulated from division in the event of a divorce. In these circumstances, it was just and equitable to have the spouses retain each of these remaining assets that were in their respective names and exclude these remaining assets from division in these proceedings. Still, if I was mistaken in so excluding from division these remaining assets, I set out my observations on their values.

Husband’s paintings

24     For the two paintings that belonged to the husband, the wife valued them at $5,000. The husband offered no value of his own on these paintings but submitted that they should in any event be excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets because they were gifts from a friend. But no evidence was provided to support the fact of such a gift beyond the bare assertion of the husband. These paintings thus appeared to be matrimonial assets with a value of $5,000.

Each spouse’s CPF balances

25     The husband had a CPF balance of $111,824. The wife had a CPF balance of $0. These figures were not in dispute. I accepted these figures accordingly.

Wife’s luxury goods

26     The luxury goods collection of the wife comprised bags, jewellery, and a coffee table. The husband submitted that the value of these luxury goods totalled $669,500. To support this claim, the husband adduced photographs of these items as well as receipts for four of the bags: a Dior pink saddle bag, a Dior white saddle calf bag, and Chanel bag, and a Birkin 25 gold bag. The wife replied that the value of these luxury goods was far less than $669,500 estimate provided by the husband. She claimed that the only items of value were the four bags that the husband had identified as well as a Birkin 30 blue bag with a value of $10,000 and a Van Cleef Arpels rose gold ring with a value of $1,500. She added that that the remaining items that the husband had identified were replicas without value and that the coffee table had been damaged and was likewise of limited value.

27     For the four bags for which the husband had identified, the wife made the following specific submissions:

(a)     the Dior pink saddle bag had been gifted to the wife’s mother as a birthday present while the marriage subsisted and no longer existed in the pool of matrimonial assets;

(b)     the Dior white saddle calf bag was a matrimonial asset; and

(c)     the Chanel bag and the Birkin 25 gold bag had been sold for $3,600 and $27,000 respectively, and that these proceeds were matrimonial assets.

28     In my view, it was convenient for the wife to claim that her collection of luxury goods comprised replicas without value apart from the four bags that the husband had identified, the Birkin 30 blue bag, and the Van Cleef Arpels rose gold ring. The husband had itemised the luxury goods (and their values)[note: 10] and adduced photographs of most of these items. But the very nature of replicas made the authenticity of each item impossible to ascertain from photographs alone. Further, the values that the husband had ascribed to each item were based on his research on the internet, and did not appear to factor in the wear and tear on the items. Moreover, even though the wife did not expressly argue as such, it was uncertain which of these items had been purchased with proceeds from the medical device business and thus excluded from division in these proceedings pursuant to the 2018 Agreement. Still, insofar as the photographs depicted authentic luxury goods, it was incumbent on the wife to prove that they were replicas or were otherwise without value. With only bare assertions to that effect from the wife, I would observe that the value of the collection of luxury goods was likely closer to that put forward by the husband than that put forward by the wife.

Husband’s ice cream business

29     The ice cream business of the husband had been incorporated before the marriage of the spouses. Although the husband owned the entirety of the shareholding of the ice cream business, it was not in dispute that the wife had invested at least $10,000 into the business during the marriage. The husband submitted that these investments were in “donations”, but regardless of the nature of the transfers, the monies went to the improvement of the business by financing marketing and operating expenditures.[note: 11] The ice cream business was thus a matrimonial asset within s 112(10)(a)(ii) of the Charter, and the husband did not appear to contend otherwise.

30     On the affidavits in these proceedings, apart from a profit-and-loss statement of the ice cream business that had been exhibited by the husband, there was little evidence on the value of the business.[note: 12] Still, as the husband admitted in his submissions, the business was a profitable one that earned “about $4,000 to $5,000 per month”.[note: 13] Annualising these figures would give a profit of at least $48,000 and possibly up to $60,000 each year. This was a stream of earnings that was not insubstantial. In all probability, such profits would have produced a business with significant value.

Conclusion on remaining matrimonial assets

31     Ultimately, the evidence in these proceedings showed that the wife had a substantial collection of luxury goods while the husband had a substantial ice cream business that earned $48,000 to $60,000 each year. Taking account the likely values of these assets as well as those of the husband’s CPF balances and the husband’s paintings, and given that the spouses had throughout the marriage ordered and operated their financial affairs independently, I found it just and equitable to exclude from the pool of matrimonial assets and have each spouse retain in their own names respectively their CPF balances, the wife’s collection of luxury goods, the husband’s paintings, and the husband’s ice cream business.

Division of matrimonial assets

32     Based on my findings above, the pool of matrimonial assets had a value of approximately $936,460. This comprised the equity of in the matrimonial home ($630.490), the value of the Porsche 911 ($250,000), and the value of the Mercedes Benz E200 ($55,970).

33     The husband contributed $621,665 to the acquisition of these matrimonial assets. This sum comprised his contributions to the purchase of the matrimonial home ($238,093 in cash and $133,121 in CPF contributions), the renovation of the matrimonial home ($194,481), and the acquisition of the Mercedes Benz E200 ($55,970). The wife contributed $410,000 to the acquisition of these matrimonial assets: $100,000 towards the purchase of the matrimonial home, $60,000 to the renovation of the matrimonial home, and $250,000 to the acquisition of the Porsche 911. In my view, the renovation expenses were direct contributions to the acquisition of the matrimonial assets because the renovations that resulted were extensive and contributed to the eventual valuation of the property (see [15] above). The ratio of the spouses’ direct contributions to the purchase of the matrimonial assets was thus approximately 60:40 in favour of the husband.

34     For the indirect contributions of the spouses towards the acquisition of the matrimonial assets, I noted that the marriage was a short one of only five years’ duration, the spouses had no children, and the spouses worked throughout the marriage. I assessed these indirect contributions of the spouses at 50:50.

35     Taking the average of the ratios of direct contributions and indirect contributions, a fair and just apportionment of the pool of matrimonial assets was 55:45 in favour of the husband. I so ordered.

Maintenance

36     Given the assets at the disposal of the wife after the marriage, especially the assets that had been ringfenced by the 2018 Agreement, the wife was well able to support herself. No maintenance for her was therefore necessary.

37     As for the husband, there was no suggestion that he was incapacitated within s 114 of the Charter. There was thus no reason to order the wife to maintain him after the marriage.

Conclusion

38     The pool of matrimonial assets, which had a value of $936,460, were thus divided in the proportions of 55:45 in favour of the husband. To promote the amicable resolution of these matters, I encouraged the spouses to endeavour to agree on the mechanics of implementing this order of division. They were at liberty to apply for orders on such implementation were such agreement beyond them.

XLX v XLY and another

XLX v XLY and another
[2025] SGFC 51

Case Number:FC/OSP 20/2024
Decision Date:15 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Shobha Nair
Counsel Name(s): Plaintiff acting in person; Defendants acting in person.
Parties: XLX — XLY — XLZ

Probate – Duties of Executors and Trustees – Duty to Account – Testamentary Expenses

15 May 2025

District Judge Shobha Nair:

Introduction

1       The plaintiff and defendants are siblings. They appeared in person for these proceedings. The defendants are the executors and trustees of their late mother’s estate. They obtained probate in July 2015. The plaintiff sought the following:

(a)     A fair and accurate statement of accounts relating to his late mother’s estate; and

(b)     Timely execution of probate.

2       The defendants provided accounts to the plaintiff after the application was filed. I found the information provided after such filing to be a fair and accurate account of the status of the estate of their late mother.

3       Given that no order was necessary in relation to the provision of accounts, I directed only that the defendants provide to the plaintiff his share of their late mother’s estate. There was considerable delay in the distribution of assets in no small part attributable to litigation between the parties over the ownership of 2 immoveable properties, namely, a HDB shophouse and a private residential property (immoveable properties). The ownership of these properties became an issue only after the parties’ father passed away in 2019.

4       As the hearing progressed, the main issue between parties appeared to be in relation to the amount the plaintiff stands to receive from his mother’s estate after testamentary expenses are paid. I had when issuing the orders, alerted them to the order of distribution so as to facilitate understanding. The plaintiff appeals against the orders made on the prayers sought.

Facts

5       The parties’ mother passed away in July 2013. She had executed a will which named the defendants as her executors and trustees. Much of the estate of their late mother was left to the first defendant including her share in the HDB shophouse and the private residential property.[note: 1] The grant of probate was obtained only in 2015 as the second defendant had a challenging pregnancy and took steps to obtain an order only after her child was born. A schedule of assets was filed which did not reflect the mother’s share in the HDB shophouse and the private residential property. This was because the properties were held by their parents and the plaintiff as co-tenants and they believed that the right of survivorship applied.

6       The parties’ father passed away in June 2019. The first defendant was named the executor and trustee of his father’s estate. In the father’s will, he had stated that his share of the HDB shophouse and the private residential property were to be given to the first defendant. All other assets were provided to either the first or the second defendant.[note: 2] From the tenor of the father’s will, the defendants began to understand that the parents never intended the plaintiff to benefit from the properties and that the HDB shophouse was being held by the plaintiff on trust for his parents. The defendants then filed an amendment to the schedule of assets for the mother’s estate to include her share of the 2 properties. This gave rise to a separate set of proceedings in HC/S 793/xxxx (S 793) as the defendant disputed the position. The court in S 793 found that the plaintiff held the HDB shophouse on trust for his parents and he was ordered to transfer interest, title and rights in the same to the defendants as executors and trustees of their mother’s estate and to the first defendant an executor and trustee of their father’s estate. In relation to the private residential property, the plaintiff was similarly ordered to transfer his rights in the property to the estates of their parents. Upon such transfer, the estates were to pay to the plaintiff the monies that were paid by him towards the 2 properties.[note: 3] It was only in late 2023 that the transfers were effected.

7       In relation to their late mother’s estate, the second defendant and the plaintiff stood to inherit a relatively small part leaving the bulk to the first defendant. More particularly, the plaintiff stood to inherit only the monies in 2 Citibank accounts totalling $42 614.33.[note: 4]

Have the defendants provided a fair and accurate account?

8       As executors and trustees, the defendants owe fiduciary duties to the beneficiaries, an important aspect of which is the duty to keep accounts and to provide beneficiaries with the same when called on to do so.[note: 5] This duty is a continuous one.[note: 6] If an order is made for the taking of accounts either on a common or wilful default basis, the process is distinct and Rules 684-686 of the Family Justice Rules (2014) would need to be complied with and consequential orders made arising from the taking of such accounts.[note: 7]

9       The defendants had in their affidavit in reply[note: 8] provided a table accounting for the assets collected, the date and the value of such collected assets, the expenses incurred and payable from the estate including the date of payment of such expenses and the assets not called in as yet.[note: 9] I was satisfied that this was a fair and accurate statement of accounts. The plaintiff disagreed but, in his affidavit, it was unclear as to why he took issue with the information produced. During the hearing however, he provided positions as follows:[note: 10]

(a)     That there are several assets which were not put into the schedule of assets. He did not however identify those omitted assets.

(b)     That he paid towards the price of the immoveable properties and that should not be written as a debt. The order by the court in S 793 however speaks of the need for the defendants to reimburse from the estates, the amounts paid by the plaintiff towards the properties in question.

(c)     That the legal costs arising from the lawsuit in S 793 should not be included as it related to the estates of both parents. I did not agree with this as both estates formed the subject matter of the lawsuit and the issue of the rights of both estates was inextricably linked.

(d)     That item 3.2 in the table provided by the defendants should reflect a figure of about $6 000. The defendants explained that this was a sum in a joint account held by their father and the first defendant and that the law of survivorship enabled the surviving account holder to keep this money, thus explaining the nil value.[note: 11]

(e)     That item 8 should indicate a surrender value when the defendants had indicated that no value was in fact obtained.

(f)     That item 9 should state a value. It was explained that this item referred to a MSIG insurance policy and they had not heard from the insurance company at the time of this hearing.

(g)     That item 11 should have a value ascribed. This too related to a policy with AVIVA Ltd. and for which no information had yet been received.

(h)     That the values of the 2 immoveable properties should be reflected. The 1st defendant is entitled to his mother’s share in these properties and the values are reflected in the table.

(i)     That no documentation of testamentary expenses have been exhibited. There is reflection of the total amount incurred supported by invoice numbers and correspondence, although it is accepted that the full set of invoices have not been produced.[note: 12]

Are the defendants in breach of timely execution of probate?

10     In relation to the second prayer for the timely execution of the probate, I agree that the defendants in their fiduciary capacities need to act in a timely manner to ensure that all beneficiaries receive their shares of the estate. Having said that, it was noted that Clause 3 of the will of their late mother allowed for the defendants to postpone the sale, calling in and conversion of assets without being responsible for any loss occasioned by that.

11     I do not believe there was an intention to avoid providing the plaintiff with his entitlement. At Clause 3 (I) of the will, all the money in their late mother’s Citibank accounts were to be provided to the plaintiff. The amounts that are contained in the Citibank bank accounts are known. The defendants have set up an estate account but no beneficiary has received his/her share yet. As the plaintiff did not seek the removal of the defendants as executors and trustees or any alternative means of obtaining his rightful share, seeking only for timely distribution of the assets, the defendants were directed to act on distribution immediately.

12     I accepted that the lack of timely distribution was largely on account of the fact that the passing of their father in 2019 opened up concerns about the plaintiff’s rights to the immoveable properties. The parties were locked in litigation over the ownership of the immoveable properties which was concluded only about 6 months prior to the instant application.

The actual dispute - unaddressed

13     Even as the plaintiff sought to identify by means of oral submissions, his areas of contention with the accounts provided and for an order that the defendants act on probate obtained, what he appeared to in fact be asking for is his entitlement to the entire sum of $43 614.33 found in his mother’s 2 Citibank accounts. In fact, the distributable amount in these accounts have increased to $43 819 as evidenced in the table produced by the defendants.[note: 13]The defendants however were of the view that it ought to be reduced on account of the net value of the assets of the estate excluding the 2 immoveable properties from the asset pool. Given the testamentary expenses indicated to be $138 112.50 which sum included legal costs arising from previous litigation, they argued that it had to be shaved off the gross value held in their late mother’s account which they say total $316 665.42, leaving a net balance of the estate to be distributed at only $178 552.92. They stated that they were advised by their lawyers that the gross value of the estate should not include the immoveable properties as the properties were not immediately available for distribution.[note: 14] It was their position that the plaintiff’s entitlement to $42 614.33 which represents 13.46% of the gross value of the estate (excluding the immoveable properties) would therefore result in only an amount of $24 028.24 of the net value of their mother’s accounts.[note: 15]

14     I had when issuing my decision alerted the parties to what appears to be at the heart of their dispute. While it appears from the plaintiff’s application and supporting affidavit[note: 16] that he wanted a fair and accurate statement of accounts and timely distribution of the assets, he appears to in fact be taking issue with the defendants’ position that the immoveable properties should not be brought into the equation when determining the net value of their late mother’s estate.[note: 17] If it were included, the net value of the assets would be significantly increased. I repeat the observations I made when issuing my decision:

Although the plaintiff had sought a fair and accurate account of the estate, the underlying dispute appears to be with regards the exact entitlement of the plaintiff. This is outside the ambit of the prayers. Parties are to refer to s 57 of the Probate and Administration Act, 1934 (PAA) which provides for the manner of administration of assets and in particular s 57(4) of the Act which provides:

“Where the estate of a deceased person is solvent his estate shall, subject to the Rules of Court and section 58 as to charges on property of the deceased, and to the provisions, if any, contained in his will, be applicable to the discharge of the funeral, testamentary and administration expenses, debts and liabilities payable thereout in the order mentioned in the Second Schedule”.

Where there then is deficiency to meet the interests of all beneficiaries, it would be up to the party who says he has clear priority over other beneficiaries to show why this is so from the wording of the testator’s will or other evidence. As the plaintiff has not sought nor made any submissions with regards priority or in its absence, how the distribution is to be borne, the Court can make no further orders.

15     The order of application of assets where an estate is solvent is provided in the Second Schedule of the PAA as follows:

(a)     Property of the deceased undisposed of by will, subject to the retention thereout of a fund sufficient to meet any pecuniary legacies.

(b)     Property of the deceased not specifically devised or bequeathed but included (either by a specific or general description) in a residuary gift, subject to the retention out of such property of a fund sufficient to meet any pecuniary legacies, so far as not provided for as aforesaid.

(c)     Property of the deceased specifically appropriated or devised or bequeathed (either by a specific or general description) for the payment of debts.

(d)     Property of the deceased charged with, or devised or bequeathed (either by a specific or general description) subject to a charge for the payment of debts.

(e)     The fund, if any, retained to meet pecuniary legacies.

(f)     Property specifically devised or bequeathed, rateably according to value.

(g)     Property appointed by will under a general power, rateably according to value.

(h)     The provisions shall also apply:

(i)       The order of application may be varied by the will of the deceased; and

(ii)       The Schedule does not affect the liability of land to answer the death duty imposed thereon in exoneration of other assets.

16     If the defendants take the position that the value of the immoveable properties called in should not be added to the pool from which the testamentary expenses are to be deducted, leaving therefore an insufficient amount in the account for all specific legatees to receive their entitlement, they would need to make an application for such determination. Indeed, the classification of the gift to the plaintiff as a specific legacy may in itself be subject to challenge. Conversely, if the immoveable properties are agreed to be brought into the pool for distribution but there is still an insufficiency to meet all the claims of the beneficiaries, there needs also to be a determination of the correct reduction for each beneficiary proportionate to the net value of the estate. The parties were somewhat limited by a lack of legal representation to advance their cases. In any event, the prayers sought were not in line with what was at the heart of the dispute. The parties are open to file an application for consideration of the issue under appropriate legislative provisions if they are not in agreement on the order of distribution. At this time, the defendants cannot decide unilaterally to hold on to the plaintiff’s share unless and until the plaintiff agrees to accept a smaller sum. There is significant guidance on how assets are to be marshalled to meet the entitlement of legatees, the issue of priority of claims and circumstances which may lead to reduction or even abatement of claims.[note: 18] Appropriate prayers would need to be drafted, and submissions made if this remains unresolved.

Conclusion

17     The statement of account provided by the defendants is a fair and accurate one. The legal costs incurred by the defendants for the lawsuit to determine the entitlement of their late mother to the immoveable properties forms part of the expenses to be discharged before distribution.

18     The transfer of the plaintiff’s interest in the immoveable properties had taken significant time to be effected, largely on account of the litigation surrounding the status of the immoveable assets. Additionally, information relating to 2 insurance policies remain outstanding at the time of the hearing. None of the beneficiaries have received their share of the estate. The defendants have been directed to act on the probate and provide the plaintiff his entitlement.

19     Even as the plaintiff sought for an account and the timely execution of probate, the real dispute for which an order was not prayed for nor adequately argued centred on whether the plaintiff was entitled to the full sum in the Citibank accounts. Any dispute with respect to this issue would necessitate further steps.

20     Each party was ordered to bear his/her own costs for these proceedings. Parties acted in person, had filed one affidavit each and did not address the core concern. Even if a court is minded to provide direction to parties in person to facilitate presentation of their cases adequately and in so doing, achieve closure, it needs to be mindful of its primary role, which is to adjudicate disputes. The plaintiff appeared to be asking the court to inform him of what the law is with respect to the order of distribution of estate assets. There are various arguments that can be mounted insofar as the position parties took on this issue. It would be wrong for a court to make a decision without understanding the reasons for the position each took and the law they base those positions on.

21     Given that the amount in question is relatively modest, I would encourage parties, and particularly the plaintiff, to agree to mediation, a step he declined when offered at an earlier case conference.
