html:
XLS v XLT and another

XLS v XLT and another
[2025] SGFC 49

Case Number:Divorce No 2676 of 2022 (Ancillary Matters)
Decision Date:06 May 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): Tan Wei En & Margaret Lee (instructed counsel), Alfred Dodwell (M/s Dodwell & Co LLC) for the Wife; Ms Carrie Gill, Cyril Ting (M/s Harry Elias Partnership LLP) for the Husband.
Parties: XLS — XLT — XLU

Family Law – Care and control – Husband seeking shared care and control of the children – Applicable considerations – Whether an order of shared care and control for the son and an order that the Wife is to have sole care and control of the daughter will result in the splitting of the siblings and is thus not in their best interests

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Dual income marriage lasting about 17 years – Appropriate approach to division of matrimonial assets – Circumstances when courts may exceptionally apply the precedent-based approach in TNL v TNK 2017 1 SLR 609 and WSY v WSX 2024 SGHCF 21 at 53 to a dual income marriage

Family Law – Maintenance – Children – Wife applying for maintenance order to be backdated – Application rejected

6 May 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       The Plaintiff (“Wife”) and Defendant (“Husband”) are Indian nationals in their mid-40s. They were married in January 2005. In 2011, they came to Singapore, have two children, and became permanent residents. On 21 December 2022, their 17-year marriage ended with the grant of an interim judgement.

2       Regarding the ancillary matters, the parties agree to the following:

(a)     That they shall have joint custody of the children, and

(b)     That there shall be no order as to spousal maintenance.

3       The parties cannot agree on the rest of the ancillary matters. These matters came before me for a determination.

Children – Care and control

4       I begin with the issue of the care and control of the children. The parties have –

(a)     A daughter of about 11.5 years old (D.O.B. XX December 2013).

(b)     A son of about 6 years old (D.O.B. XX April 2019).

5       By way of background, the situation regarding the children’s care and control at the time of the hearing is as follows.

(a)     In June 2022, the Wife left the matrimonial home (in the Bayshore area) with the children for India. They returned to Singapore in July 2022. Since then, they have been staying in the Pasir Ris area.[note: 1]

(b)     In October 2022, the Wife applied for – and obtained – interim care and control of the children. The Husband was allowed to have weekly supervised access to the children.

(c)     In February 2023, pursuant to his appeal and by consent, the Husband was given unsupervised access to the children (i) every Sunday and (ii) on weekday(s) to be agreed between the parties.

(d)     In May 2023, the parties were informed that a custody evaluation report (“CER”) had recommended that they be granted joint custody as well as “joint care and control” of the children.

(e)     In June 2023, the Wife sought a personal protection order (“PPO”) to protect the Daughter from the Husband: SS 1003/xxxx (“SS 1003”).

(f)     In December 2023, pursuant to his application, the Husband was granted interim care and control of the children every Sunday (from 9.00 am to 5.00 pm), while the Wife was granted interim care and control of them for the rest of the week: FC/ORC 5379/xxxx (“ORC 5379”).

(g)     In June 2024, the Wife withdrew SS 1003. According to her, she had done so because positive steps had been taken to mend the relationship between the Daughter and the Husband.[note: 2]

(h)     By the time of the hearing before me, the parties had already agreed to the Husband having access to the children as follows:

(i)       Meet the Daughter once every 1½ weeks in a public place for up to 6 hours.[note: 3]

(ii)       Fetch the Son from school every Friday (from 12.30 pm) and spend time with him until 8.30 pm.

(iii)       Spend time with the Son every Sunday from around 7.40 am to 8.00 pm.[note: 4]

Parties’ position

6       The parties submitted for the following orders to be made regarding the children:

 

Wife’s position

Husband’s position

Care & Control

To be granted to the Wife

To be shared between the parties on a weekly basis[note: 5]

Access

Reasonable access[note: 6]

(If shared care and control is not granted)

Access to be stepped up over time with the aim of eventually transitioning to shared care and control



Applicable considerations

7       Before addressing the parties’ submission, it is useful to first set out the applicable principles.

Shared care and control

8       In WXA v WXB [2024] SGHCF 22 (“WXA”) at [9], the High Court explained that –

An order for shared care and control means that the children spend about equal time living with both parents. Each parent will be responsible for the day-to-day decision-making for the children when the children are living with him or her. The children will effectively have two homes and two primary caregivers under such an arrangement.

9       In assessing whether a shared care and control arrangement is appropriate, the paramount consideration is the child’s interests. The factors relevant to this consideration include the following:

Whether there is allegation of family violence against the child by the parent(s)

(a)     For obvious reasons, where a parent has committed, or is alleged to have committed, family violence against his/her child, it is generally not appropriate for that parent to have shared care and control of the child. For clarity, the mere fact that one parent has a PPO against the other parent does not preclude a shared care and control order from being made: WEM v WEN [2024] SLR(FC) 247 (“WEM”) at [45].

Whether both parents are equally committed to care for the child

(b)     Another relevant factor is whether both parents are equally committed to care for the child. In assessing this factor, courts typically consider, for instance, whether they –

(i)       are responsible parents,

(ii)       have been/are involved in the child’s care and development, and

(iii)       have taken an active interest in the child’s life and place the child’s needs before their own.

See e.g., UGQ v UGR [2017] SGFC 125 (“UGQ”) at [39] and [41]; WXA at [10]; AUA v ATZ [2016] 4 SLR 674 at [62]; TAA v TAB [2015] 2 SLR 879 at [18]; VJJ v VJK [2020] SGFC 57 (“VJJ”) at [37]; WEM at [39].

Whether the parents are able to care for the child

(c)     The extent to which the parents can care for the child is also a factor in assessing whether a shared care and control arrangement is suitable. Considerations that are relevant to this factor include the following:

(i)       Where a parent is a foreigner, can that parent remain in Singapore? If the answer is no, then courts have ordered sole care and control to the parent who can remain in Singapore: see e.g., XII v XIJ [2025] SGFC 40 at [32] and [88].

(ii)       How will the parents juggle their work and other commitments with that of caring for the child?

(1)       To be clear, the mere fact that one parent is employed full-time (Parent A) while the other parent is employed as a freelancer is not a basis for denying Parent A the benefits of shared care and control of the child. This is because “[f]ull-time employment is an ordinary part of daily life”. The more critical inquiry is whether Parent A makes time for the child: XFF v XFG [2024] SGHCF 45 (“XFF”) at [5].

(2)       In UPK v UPL [2018] SGFC 92 (“UPK”), the court ordered shared care and control of a two-year-old child because, among others, the father had a helper and his parents to help care for the child.

(3)       In XIC v XID [2025] SGFC 14 (“XIC”) at [9], the court denied the father’s request for shared care and control of his two primary school going children because he could not show how he would be able to care for them when (1) he had two toddlers with his new partner and (2) both his partner and him were working full-time.

Whether the parents can cooperate within an arrangement of shared care and control

(d)     Another factor is the degree to which the parents can cooperate with each other within an arrangement of shared care and control: TAU v TAT [2018] 5 SLR 1089 (“TAU”) at [12]; WXA at [9]; VSF v VSG [2022] SGFC (“VSF”) at [19] and [20]. This factor is relevant because for such an arrangement to work properly, the parents must be able to (i) discuss and agree on the child’s daily activities and (ii) ensure that the child’s daily life is seamless even when he/she switches homes: XHY v XHZ [2025] SGFC 13 at [10].

(e)     At this juncture, a few points bear highlighting.

(i)        First, the mere fact that the parents reside together – even after interim judgment is ordered – is not conclusive evidence that they can cooperate with each other within an arrangement of shared care and control: see XCQ at [13].

(ii)        Second, as rightly noted in XFF at [6] –

Although acrimony between parents is one factor that should be accounted for when considering a shared care and control arrangement, it does not automatically nullify such an option. The court has to take a close look at the facts of each case to see if a shared care and control arrangement would be unworkable because of the acrimony, and if it would be in the best interests of the children. Otherwise, parties may have a perverse incentive to increase the acrimony to gain a tactical advantage in the care arrangements of the children (BNS v BNT [2017] 4 SLR 213 at [73], [76]-[77] citing AZZ v BZZ [2016] SGHC 44 at [40]).

(iii)       Thus, a shared care and control arrangement has been ordered in cases even where –

(1)       The parties’ relationship with each other is acrimonious: see e.g., CXR v CXQ [2023] SGHCF 10 at [18] and [19]; VJJ at [27], [35] and [46].

(2)       The parties disagree on the appropriate orders to be made for the child: see e.g., VJJ at [46]; WEM at [39].

(3)       The parties have different parenting styles – as such differences, which arise due to differences in each parent’s personality, can often be addressed with appropriate counselling orders: see e.g., WEM at [40] and [42]; VSF at [22], [23] and [29]; VJJ at [25] and [52].

(iv)        Third, the law expects parents to cooperate to promote the child’s best interests: CX v CY [2005] SLR (R) 690 at [28]. This includes an expectation that a parent will support the child’s relationship with the other parent: WAH v WAG [2024] SGFC 6 (“WAH”) at [50].

(v)        Finally, a shared care and control arrangement will not be appropriate if the parents are clearly unable to even communicate with each other and compromise in making day-to-day decisions for the child: XJI v XJJ [2025] SGHCF 17 at [5]; XCQ v XCP [2025] SGHCF 26 (“XCQ”) at [7].

Whether there has been attempts to alienate the child

(f)     Another relevant factor is whether one parent has attempted to alienate the child against the other parent. If a parent has, for instance, –

(i)       sought to remove the other parent from the child’s life: see e.g., UGQ at [43] to [46],

(ii)       “methodically involved [the child] in the dispute between the [parents]”: see e.g., VJJ at [27], [28] and [48], or

(iii)       restricted the other parent’s access to the child: WAH at [46],

then an order of shared care and control may be appropriate to prevent further alienation.

Whether a shared care and control arrangement is likely to harm the child

(g)     A shared care and control arrangement will often introduce uncertainties and disruptions into the child’s routines: XFF at [9]. It is important to assess the impact of such uncertainties and disruptions, and whether it will be easy for the child to live in two homes. (For instance, what is the distance that the child will need to travel between the two homes and his/her school?) This, in turn, requires a consideration of (i) the child’s age, (ii) the child’s level of maturity and independence, and (iii) the child’s needs at that stage of life. See e.g., TAU at [12]; WXA at [9]; XHS v XHT [2025] SGFC 20; XCP v XCQ [2024] SGFC 107 at [38]; XFF at [5].

(h)     Accordingly, a shared care and control arrangement may be appropriate if, for instance, the child (i) is adaptable to changes and (ii) will not experience significant psychological resistance if he/she is required to live with both parents on an alternating basis: WEM at [41]. It has been observed that a young child who has yet to commence formal education may be more suited to a shared care and control arrangement: ATZ v AUA [2015] SGHC 161 at [109]; UPK at [26]. On this note, such an arrangement has been ordered for children as young as two years old: see e.g., WEM; UPK.

(i)     On the other hand, a shared care and control arrangement may not be appropriate if the uncertainties and disruptions to the child’s routines are likely to be significant. See for instance the following cases.

(i)       In XGE v XGF [2024] SGFC 109 (“XGE”), the court dismissed the father’s request for an order of shared care and control for his four-year-old daughter. In coming to this decision, the court noted the following:

(1)       The mother had been the child’s primary caregiver since birth. The father had lived with the daughter only until she was about 10 months old. Thereafter, he visited the mother and daughter often until the latter was about two years’ old. From then on, the visits became rare because the father’s and mother’s relationship had broken down: XGE at [8], [10] to [18].

(2)       The father’s proposal was for the daughter to live in two different households every three to four days. This would be too disruptive for her: XGE at [58].

(3)       The father had come from a traditional Chinese patriarchal family. The differences in the father’s and mother’s values and approaches to parenting were very severe and was a reason for the breakdown in their marriage. These differences would cause the daughter to suffer “a sense of dislocation” if a shared care and control order was made: XGE at [8] and [58].

(ii)       In XIC at [9], the court declined to grant a shared care and control order because the two children (nine years old and seven years old) –

(1)       had been living with their mother for the past 5 years, and

(2)       did not have any overnight access with their father since he left the home when they were only three years old and one year old.

(j)     For completeness, the mere fact that a child shares a closer bond with one parent is not a bar to a shared care and control arrangement. This is especially so when the reason for such a bond is because that parent had unilaterally removed the child from the matrimonial home: WEM at [48].

Sole care and control

10     If a shared care and control arrangement is assessed to be inappropriate, then a court will have to determine which parent should be granted sole care and control of the child. On this issue, the relevant considerations have been discussed in detail in XDZ v XEA [2024] SGFC 90 (“XDZ”) at [14] to [16]. To summarise, they include the following.

(a)      The parents’ past and present interactions with the child. For instance, which parent (i) has been showing greater concern, interest and responsibility for the child, (ii) has been his/her primary caregiver, (iii) has a stronger bond with the child?

(b)      The parents’ future caregiving arrangements. For instance, which parent (i) can provide better care for the child, (ii) can provide him/her a more secure and stable home environment, and (iii) is more willing to promote a healthy relationship between the child and the other parent? It is also important to consider the child’s wishes.

(c)      Adverse considerations. For instance, does any of the parent have an unhealthy lifestyle or outlook which may affect his/her ability to make rational decisions for the child? Has any of the parent acted in a way to intentionally or knowingly harm the child’s interest?

(d)      Other considerations. Finally, continuity of living arrangements is an important factor for a child’s emotional well-being. Siblings should generally not be separated.

CER’s recommendation

11     In assessing which option – a shared care and control order or a sole care and control order – better serves the child’s interests, a judicial interview with the child and/or a CER can be useful: WKM v WKN [2024] 1 SLR 158 (“WKM”) at [34], [60], [62] to [64], [67], [68], [72] and [74].

12     This brings me to the CER’s recommendation in the present case – i.e., that the parties be granted “joint care and control” of the children.

13     What weight should be given to this recommendation? The parties took polar positions on this issue.

(a)     According to the Husband, the recommendation should be accepted because there was no material change in circumstances to suggest that it was unworkable.[note: 7]

(b)     The Wife disagreed. After the CER’s recommendation was disclosed to the parties (in May 2023), a PPO application was filed (in June 2023). The application alleged that the Husband had committed family violence on the Daughter from September 2022 to 28 May 2023. The maker of the CER would not have known of such violence, especially those committed around May 2023.[note: 8]

14     After considering the matter, I declined to rely on the CER’s recommendation as a basis for deciding on the issue of care and control of the children. These are my reasons.

15      First, I accept the Wife’s submission that the maker of the CER would not have known of the family violence allegedly committed by the Husband – especially those committed around May 2023. It is unclear whether the maker will still recommend “joint care and control” for the children if such information had been made to him/her.

16      Second, and in any event, the CER’s recommendation is somewhat dated. It was made about two years before the hearing. In view of this, I called on the Divorce Support Specialist Agency (“DSSA”) which was working with the parties and the children to provide an update on the family situation. The update did not touch on the PPO application. It did however state the following:

(a)     The Daughter continued to have struggles with how to perceive the Husband’s communications,

(b)     She was not yet comfortable to meet him more regularly at his home, and

(c)     (On a more positive note) the father-daughter relationship was improving.

My decision

Whether shared care and control is appropriate

17     I will now apply the considerations in [8] and [9] above to the present case. My analysis is as follows.

Factors

Considerations

(1)

Whether there is allegation of family violence against the children by the parent(s)?

Finding – Yes, there was a PPO application against the Husband for having committed family violence against the Daughter. This application had been withdrawn.

(a) As stated earlier, the Wife had filed a PPO application (SS 1003) against the Husband in June 2023. The Husband denied having committed family violence against the Daughter. He submitted that the Wife had filed the application to undermine the CER’s recommendation for joint care and control of the children: see discussion at [17(5)] below.[note: 9]

(b) I decline to determine whether the Husband had committed family violence against the Daughter. My reasons are as follows.

(i) First, the specific allegations and relevant evidence regarding the violence are not before me.

(ii) Second, the Wife had eventually withdrawn the PPO application.

(iii) Third, at the time of the hearing before me, the father-daughter relationship had already improved, and the parties were eager to move forward with their lives. In the circumstances, it would be counter-productive to such positive efforts by raking up past allegations of family violence.

(c) To be clear, the above view does not mean that the Daughter’s reservations towards the Husband – which may have been shaped by past incidents – are wholly irrelevant in deciding whether to order joint care and control for her. This issue is addressed more fully in [17(6)] below.

(2)

Whether the parents are equally committed to care for the children?

Finding – Yes.

The issue

(a) It is not disputed that the Wife is committed to care for the children.

(b) The issue is whether the Husband is similarly committed. On this issue, the parties have divergent views.

Husband’s case

(c) According to the Husband, he has been “an active caregiver and a hands-on father ever since the children were born”. For instance,[note: 10] –

(i) He was present during their birth and cared for them when they were infants.

(ii) He had been involved in various aspects of the children’s educational, enrichment, sporting and outdoor activities. He had also looked after their religious, health, and physical wellbeing.

(iii) He had made various sacrifices in his career – including declining a lucrative overseas job offer – so that the children could have a stable life in Singapore.

(d) The Husband added that despite the breakdown in the marriage, he[note: 11] –

(i) continues to play and do homework with the Son,

(ii) takes the Son for skating classes every Friday,

(iii) practices cricket with the Son for hours every Sunday, and

(iv) has interactions with the Daughter through counselling sessions and other physical/remote contacts – and is eager to have more interactions with her, subject to her comfort level.

Wife’s case

(e) On the other hand, the Wife alleged that the Husband[note: 12] –

(i) had been an “absent father”,

(ii) has never looked after the children’s daily care from their birth and does not know how to,

(iii) has decided to be present in the children’s lives only after the divorce proceedings commenced.

(f) According to the Wife, the Husband had acted against the children’s interests. For instance –

(i) He had refused to allow the Son to change his school.[note: 13]

(ii) The Husband had wanted to change the Daughter’s school (in October 2023) despite the latter’s wish to remain there, and had stopped paying her school and bus fees (since November 2023).[note: 14]

My analysis – Wife’s claims in [17(2)(e)] above

(g) Regarding the Wife’s claims in [17(2)(e)] above, I am of the view that while a parent’s past conduct towards his/her child is a relevant consideration, it is equally (if not more) important to consider his/her current attitude towards the child. A contrary view would improperly disregard a parent’s genuine efforts to make amends. This may also result in court orders that prevent the parent-child relationship from improving.

(h) In the present case, even if the Wife’s claims about the Husband in [17(2)(e)] above are true (to be clear, I make no judgement on these claims), this does not prove that he is unable to become a committed caregiver moving forward.

(i) In my view, the Husband is committed to care for the children. These are my reasons.

(j) First, the Wife does not dispute the Husband’s evidence in [17(2)(d)] above. Such evidence shows that he has invested a lot of time and effort – and is very keen – to play a larger role in his children’s lives.

(k) Second, the Husband’s eagerness to connect with the Daughter is supported by the DSSA working with them. The DSSA has updated that –

(i) Independent access between the father and child had improved and increased,

(ii) They had shared meals independently,

(iii) The Husband continued to pace with the Daughter’s level of comfort while also offering encouragement where appropriate, and

(iv) The Husband had been responsive and adapted well to the Daughter.

(l) Finally, the Wife acknowledged that the Husband’s efforts at connecting with the children had borne fruit – there is now a stronger bond between the children and him.[note: 15]

My analysis – Wife’s claims in [17(2)(f)] above

(m) As for the Wife’s claims in [17(2)(f)] above, I find that the Husband did not deliberately act against his children’s interests. His actions arose from a genuine disagreement with her over how the children should be educated: see [61] and [63] below.

(3)

Whether the parents are equally able to care for the children?

Finding – Yes.

My analysis

(a) Again, it is not disputed that the Wife is able to care for the children. The issue is whether the Husband is similarly able to do so.

(b) According to the Husband, he is able to care for the children given that[note: 16] –

(i) he enjoys flexible work from home arrangements, and

(ii) he can tap on his parents who have helped to take care of the children when the parties were living together.

(c) I accept the Husband’s evidence – which I find to be reasonable and have not been discredited.

(4)

Whether the parents can cooperate within an arrangement of shared care and control?

Finding – Yes.

My analysis

(a) According to the DSSA update, the Husband’s and Wife’s relationship continues to be strained and challenging.

(b) Despite this, I find that they can still cooperate with each other within an arrangement of shared care and control. These are my reasons.

(c) First, it is common ground that the interactions between the Husband with the Wife have improved.[note: 17] For instance, they have been attending DSSA counselling sessions as a family, and they agree that positive steps have been taken at such sessions.[note: 18]

(d) Second, in its update, DSSA has reported that –

(i) The parties are managing to exhibit functional co-parenting, as evidenced by their ability to coordinate family sessions, such as the Daughter's graduation and birthday celebrations,

(ii) Communication between the Husband and Wife has increased, and

(iii) There have been instances where the parties successfully collaborated before addressing the Daughter together.

(e) Third, the Wife is “very keen” for the children to have a close relationship with the Husband.[note: 19] She accepts that[note: 20] –

… the parties’ co-parenting relationship has seen improvement since the present divorce proceedings were commenced. This is attributable to the efforts of both parties to do what is best for their children’s welfare despite their acrimonious relationship with each other.

(f) Finally, the Husband has acknowledged the Wife’s efforts at improving his relationship with his children and has given her credit for the positive outcomes reached thus far.[note: 21] This shows that the Husband is able to isolate (i) his difficulties with the Wife from (ii) the need for him to act in the children’s best interests.

(5)

Has there has been attempts to alienate the children?

Finding – There are allegations of such attempts by both parties.

The Wife’s case

(a) According to the Wife, the Husband and/or his mother had sought to alienate the children from her.

(i) Sometime in or around May 2023, the Son began to behave aggressively towards her and to repeat “awful insults” about her. She believed that the Husband had told the Son that she was “bad” and that the Husband and his mother had taught the child such behaviour.[note: 22]

(ii) There was an incident (on an unspecified date) where the Son had cried to go to the Husband’s home. The Wife learnt from the child that the Husband’s mother had told him to cry if he wanted to see the Husband again.[note: 23]

(iii) During his access times with the children, the Husband had verbally abused the Wife to the children. This triggered the filing of the PPO application in June 2023.[note: 24]

The Husband’s case

(b) According to the Husband, the Wife[note: 25] –

(i) had blocked his access to the children from May 2023 and alienated them from him,

(ii) had encouraged the Daughter to file PPO application, which was baseless, to undermine the CER’s recommendation for the parents have joint share and control of the children.

Analysis

(c) Both parties have denied alienating the children from the other party.

(d) In my view, it would not be productive to determine whether the parties’ claims of alienation is true or not.

(i) First, the alleged incidents are somewhat dated.

(ii) Second, and importantly, the parties have since then been actively working together to ensure effective co-parenting for the children.

(6)

Is a shared care and control arrangement likely to harm the children?

Finding –

- The Son: No.

- The Daughter: May be.

The Wife’s case

(a) According to the Wife:

(i) A shared care and control arrangement is not feasible as she has been the primary caregiver from the time of the children’s birth. Further, there is a strong maternal bond between them and her.[note: 26]

(ii) The children have been staying with her at the in Pasir Ris since 2022. They are familiar with their present living environment. The children need stability in their lives. It does not make sense for them to move between two different households every week.[note: 27]

(b) In the case of the Son, the Wife further submits that (i) he is still very young and sleeps with her, and (ii) he will cry for her when he wakes up in the middle of the night.[note: 28]

(c) As for the Daughter, the Wife submits that –

(i) The Daughter had “traumatizing experiences” during access with the Husband in the past (this led to the filing of the PPO application in June 2023) and the child does not wish to be separated from her.[note: 29]

(ii) A shared care and control arrangement would be a “monumental change” for the Daughter and this is contrary to her best interests. The child had to go through counselling before she could agree to spend time with the Husband. An order for shared care and control would essentially coerce the daughter into spending significantly more time with the Husband in a private setting. This is more than what the Daughter is comfortable with.[note: 30]

My analysis – General

(d) As a matter of principle, the mere fact that the Wife has been the children’s primary caregiver from the time of their birth does not preclude a shared care and control arrangement. This is because the children will grow up and their needs will change.

My analysis – The Son

(e) Using the Son’s case as an example, he is already 6 years old. He will overcome his fear of the dark when he wakes up in the night.

(f) The Son has a strong bond with the Husband. It is the Husband’s case that the child wants to spend overnights with him. This has not been disputed by the Wife.

(g) There is no evidence to show that the Son will be psychologically affected if he spends a longer time with the Husband or were to reside in the matrimonial home on a weekly basis. In this regard, I note that prior to 2022, the Son had been staying with the Husband in the matrimonial home. The child is familiar with its surroundings.

My analysis – The Daughter

(h) The situation with the Daughter is different. It is not disputed that her relationship with the Husband is fragile.

(i) I accept the Wife’s submission at [17(6)(c)] above. In my view, a shared care and control arrangement at this point may adversely affect the Daughter.

(j) That said, I am heartened to note that the father-daughter relationship is improving. The issue of shared care and control of the Daughter can be revisited at a later stage, if needed.



18     Having considered the factors wholistically –

Daughter

(a)     I find that a shared care and control arrangement is not suitable for the Daughter at the present stage. In my view, the Wife should be given sole care and control of the child.

(b)     That said, I agree with the Husband that mechanisms should be put in place for him to have greater access to the Daughter. Hopefully, this can facilitate eventually making of an order of shared care and control for the child in the future.

Son

(c)     I find that a shared care and control arrangement is suitable for the Son. Such an arrangement can be on a “week-in week-out basis”.[note: 31]

Whether the siblings will be split

19     In coming to the above view, I have considered the Wife’s submission that the different care and control arrangements for the Daughter and Son can end up splitting the siblings and that this will not be in their best interests.[note: 32]

20     I am not persuaded by the Wife’s submission. Let me explain.

(a)     I am mindful that when making care and control orders, courts generally try to avoid separating siblings: Wong Phila Mae at [22(e)]; ABW at [23(e)]; TAA v TAB [2015] 2 SLR 879 at [24]. This consideration arises where each parent has the sole care and control of one of the children – with the result that the children end up residing in different households and leading separate lives.

(b)     This will not be the situation in the present case. This is because the Daughter and Son will be residing in the same household during those periods when the Wife has care of the Son.

(c)     In my view, the adverse impact of separating the children (if any) during those periods when the Wife does not have care of the Son will be minimal. This is because (i) such separations will only be for one week every fortnightly, and (ii) the Wife can still arrange for the children to meet during her access periods with the Son.

(d)     On the other hand, the adverse impact of the Son being prevented from deepening his relationship with the Husband is likely to be greater. It is the Husband’s evidence that the Son is very close to him and wants to spend more time with him. The Wife did not dispute this evidence.

(e)     Finally, I accept the Husband’s submission that a shared care and control arrangement for the Son – where the child is seen spending quality time with him – may help the Daughter overcome her own psychological resistance towards the Husband.[note: 33]

Dividing the matrimonial assets – Applicable approach

“Structured approach”

26     Having determined the total value of the matrimonial assets, the next step is to divide them in a “just and equitable” way. In this regard, I note that (a) the parties had a marriage lasting about 17 years and (b) both had been working at all material times.[note: 40]

27     In the circumstances, the matrimonial assets ought to be divided in accordance with the “structured approach”: ANJ v ANK [2015] 4 SLR 1043 at [22] and [26] (“ANJ”). Under the “structured approach”, a court considers two factors when making a division. First, the parties’ direct/financial contributions towards “the acquisition or improvement of matrimonial assets”. Second, the parties’ “indirect contributions to the well-being of the family”.

Wife’s submission for an alternative approach

28     The Wife submitted that apart from the “structured approach”, the court could “alternatively” apply the precedent-based approach in TNL v TNK [2017] 1 SLR 609 (“TNL”). Relying on WSY v WSX [2024] SGHCF 21 (“WSY”) at [53], the Wife submitted that the starting point should be an equal division of the matrimonial assets as the marriage was a moderate to long one and the Husband was the primary breadwinner. [note: 41]

Alternative approach rejected

29     I am unable to accept the Wife’s submissions.

30      First, the precedent-based approach is suitable only in two scenarios:

(a)      Scenario 1 – Single income marriages. This is well established. See TNL.

(b)      Scenario 2 – Dual income marriages where the monthly income of one of the parties is “so low” that it will not contribute significantly towards either (i) the acquisition/improvement of matrimonial assets or (ii) the well-being of the family. Scenario 2 is in line with the de minimis principle. An example where the precedent-based approach was applied in Scenario 2 is WSY at [46] and [47] In that case, the disparity between the parties’ income is as follows:

Indirect contributions

35     At this juncture, I wish to elaborate on the parties’ submissions on their respective indirect contributions.

36     Indirect contributions relate to the parties’ contributions to “the well-being of the family”. The usual components of such contributions have been discussed in XDZ at [29(b)]. They include the following:

(a)     Paying household expenses.

(b)     Performing household chores.

(c)     Caring for the child(ren) and other family members.

(d)     Expending money and effort to maintain/enhance the condition of the matrimonial home. (Note. This is to be distinguished from the expenditure of funds, when a matrimonial home is first acquired, to renovate it and make it habitable. The expenditure of such funds should be considered in assessing the parties’ direct contributions: WTL v WTM [2024] SGHCF 40 at [33] and [34].)

(e)     Expending money and effort to enhance the quality of life of family members.

(f)     Making personal sacrifices for the family, e.g., stop work to look after the child or so that a spouse may advance in his/her career and endeavours.

(g)     Supporting a spouse. This can carry a lot of weight especially when the support is given during the spouse’s personal crisis.

My decision

39     Having set out the parties’ position, I will now state my findings.

Direct contributions

40     Regarding the parties’ direct contributions, I note that the difference between the Husband’s computation ([34(a)(i)]) and the Wife’s computation ([34(b)(ii)]) is negligible – a mere difference of 2.41%.[note: 70] Adopting a broadbrush approach, I apportion the parties’ direct contributions at 25% (Wife) and 75% (Husband).

Indirect contributions – Husband’s submissions

41     Next, I turn to the indirect contributions. The Husband had submitted that “more emphasis should be placed on indirect financial contributions, rather than indirect non-financial contributions”.

42     I am unable to accept this submission.

(a)      First, the Husband’s approach gives undue emphasis to indirect financial contributions over indirect non-financial contributions. Not all indirect contributions can be measured in dollars and cents. This does not however mean that such contributions are any less significant. Take, for instance, the fact that the Wife had gone through IVF procedures. I find the Husband’s submissions – (i) that “undue focus” should not be given to this “minutiae of family life” and (ii) that he had supported the Wife in the IVF procedures by paying for them – to be insensitive and unfairly diminish the side-effects and sacrifices that she had to go through to produce two children for the family.

(b)      Second, while it is undeniable that the Husband’s financial contributions had allowed the Wife and children to enjoy a high quality of life, I have serious doubts regarding his claim that he had paid “over 90%” of the family expenses. The Husband had failed to provide any proof for such an arbitrary claim.

(c)      Third, the mere fact that the Husband earns a higher income than the Wife does not mean that her financial contributions towards the family are insignificant. In this regard, the following bears highlighting.

(i)       The Husband did not disprove the Wife’s evidence that she had paid for some of the household expenses.

(ii)       Given that her income is significant ($9,782/month), it is plausible that the Wife could have made substantial financial contributions towards the household and other expenses.

(iii)       This is especially so when the Husband has significantly (about five times) more matrimonial assets in his sole name than the Wife: see [23(b)] and [23(c)]. This suggests that the Husband would have channeled a significant portion of his income into savings and investments – and not just for paying all the household expenses.

43     There is another aspect of the Husband’s case that I have difficulty accepting. This relates to his submission that the parties would have discharged roughly equal indirect non-financial contributions during the marriage: see [38(a)] above. I am unable to see how this could have been the case given that between the two of them –

(a)     The Wife is the primary caregiver for the children.

(b)     The Wife probably played a larger role in managing the household. The Husband is the Executive Director of a large local bank[note: 71] whereas the Wife works as a senior software developer.[note: 72] Comparing the nature of their respective job, the Husband would likely be spending more time on his work than the Wife.

(c)     The Wife was “more relaxed” about her career prospects. According to the Husband, this was because he had a stable career. This is consistent with the Wife’s evidence that she had sacrificed her career development to focus on the children.

Indirect contributions – Assessment

44     Based on the evidence, it appears that the parties had made contributions in their own way to ensure the well-being of the family – the Husband by providing financial stability, and the Wife by focusing on managing the children and the household.

45     Taking a holistic view of the factors in [37], [42], and [43] above, I find that the Wife and Husband had made equal indirect contributions to the family. Accordingly, I apportion their respective share of indirect contributions as 50% (Wife) and 50% (Husband).

Ratio for division of matrimonial assets

46     Considering both their direct and indirect contributions, I find that the matrimonial assets should be divided in the ratio of 37.5 (Wife) and 62.5 (Husband).

Whether to backdate maintenance order

Parties’ position

60     The Wife had applied to backdate the children’s maintenance order to cover the Daughter’s school fees and associated school expenses for the academic year 2024 (i.e., $25,452.11).[note: 87]

61     The Husband urged me to reject the Wife’s application.[note: 88] He gave the following reasons.

(a)     There was no agreement for the Daughter to be enrolled in an international school for the academic year 2024.

(b)     In April 2022 (i.e., about two months before the Wife left the matrimonial home with the children), the Husband have given her $50,000. The Wife could have used these funds.[note: 89]

(c)     The Wife did not apply for interim maintenance.

(d)     The Wife was not in need of financial contribution from the Husband – given that she was able to afford to initiate PPO proceedings against him.

Applicable principles

62     In Lee Siew Choo v Ling Chin Thor [2014] SGHC 185, the High Court helpfully observed that –

16    In deciding whether to grant an order for backdated maintenance, the court should have regard to the overall circumstances of the case, and in this regard, the following are some of the considerations that it ought to bear in mind:

(a)    First, maintenance is based on need. As such, the applicant has to show that he/she needs maintenance from the date prior to the application for maintenance or ancillary hearing;

(b)    Second, the applicant should give reason(s) for the delay in seeking maintenance for the child/children. Not making interim maintenance to save costs is a good reason in explaining the delay (TG v TH (see above: [14]) at [43]);

(c)    Third, income and expenses of the parties in the past (AMW v AMZ (see above: [16]) at [12(b)]) and whether circumstances have changed since;

[…]

(e)    Fifth, potential savings in costs, time and resources in having maintenance for children dealt with in the ancillary hearing, instead of having a separate hearing for interim maintenance.

[…]

(f)    Sixth, the detriment caused to the parent in default if backdated maintenance is ordered (AMW v AMZ (see above: [16]) at [12(c)]-[12(d)]). It is not difficult to appreciate why this might be the case. On the backdating of an order, the payer is instantly in arrears in respect of the payments due prior to the claim for maintenance. The payer might not have the means to pay, or if he does, at the cost of hardship to himself;

(g)    Seventh, an order for maintenance is an order of court. If the parent in default does not pay, he/she potentially faces committal proceedings;

(h)    Eighth, difficulties or hardship that the applicant faced in trying to meet expenses prior to the claim for maintenance. These were alluded to by Kan Ting Chiu J in the High Court case of AJE v AJF (see above: [16]), who there described an extreme situation of hardship (see above: [16]) (at [27]):

If the [applicant] had to incur debts or sell possessions to make up for the shortfall in maintenance, that would be a strong ground for backdating the maintenance.

But in some situations, the applicant faces no hardship. The applicant might have in fact been maintained the child with income from other sources beside his/her own. This was the concern Kan J expressed in AJE v AJF (at [27]):

[I]f the [payee] had been able to had been able to manage…, back-payment would be a windfall, and the case for backdating would be weaker.

(i)    Ninth, the length of the period for which maintenance for the child is claimed, and whether the applicant sought maintenance from the parent in default to begin with.

My decision

63     Applying the above principles, I declined to backdate the maintenance order.

(a)      First, there is a genuine dispute as to whether the Daughter’s enrolment into an international school for academic year 2024 was in accordance with what the parties had planned for her. It would not be fair to expect the Husband to pay for the fees in such a school – especially when they involve a significant amount.

(b)      Second, and in any event, enrolment in an international school is a good-to-have and not a must-have. There is no evidence that the Daughter would have been deprived of a proper education in Singapore by virtue of being enrolled in a local school.

Conclusion

64     Before concluding, I note that the Husband has an outstanding costs order for $5,000 arising from HCF/DCA 125/2023 (heard on 22 April 2024). One year after it was made, this order remains unsatisfied. There is no confirmation as to when the Wife would satisfy the outstanding costs order. In the circumstances, pursuant to the Husband’s application, I order that the sum of $5,000 be deducted from the Wife’s share of the matrimonial assets.

65     Finally, I make no order as to costs as this stage of the proceedings. If the parties wish to make costs submissions, they are to inform the court within two weeks of the date of this judgement.

4       The Wife shall have care and control of the Son until 5 August 2025. From 6 August 2025, the parties shall have shared care and control of the Son. The Husband’s access to the Son shall be as follows.

From 6 May to 5 June 2025

(a)     The Husband shall have reasonable access to the Son.

From 6 June to 5 July 2025

(b)     In addition to [4(a)] above, the Husband may bring the Son to his place of residence to stay overnight on every Friday night – or on any other night mutually agreed by the Parties.

From 6 July to 5 August 2025

(c)     In addition to [4(a)] to [4(b)] above, the Husband may bring the Son to his place of residence to stay overnight on every Saturday night – or on any other night mutually agreed by the Parties.

From 6 August 2025

(d)     The Son shall reside with the Parties on a week-in week-out basis, with the handover of the Son from one party to the other to take place on every Saturday at 11.00 am. The Party taking over the care of the Son shall do so at the residence of the Party handing over the Son.

(e)     Special occasions as stated below shall take precedence over [4(d)]:

(i)       Son’s birthdays – When the birthday does not fall within a Party’s parenting time, that parent shall be granted 4.5 hours with the Son from 4.00 pm to 8.30 pm.

(ii)       Parties’ birthday – When a Party’s birthday does not fall within his/her parenting time with the Son, that parent shall be granted 4.5 hours with the Son from 4.00 pm to 8.30 pm.

(iii)       Hindu festivals (specifically Holi, Lohri and Janamastmi) – When such a festival does not fall within his/her parenting time with the Son, that parent shall be granted 4.5 hours with the Son from 4.00 pm to 8.30 pm.

(f)     The arrangement in [4(d)] shall take precedence over public holidays and school holidays at the end of Term I and Term III.

(g)     Parties shall have equal time with the Son during his school holidays at the end of Term II and Term IV, starting with the Term II holidays in December 2025.

(i)       The Husband shall have time with the Son for the first half of the school holidays and the Wife shall have the second half, on an alternating basis.

(ii)       During their respective periods with the Son during the school holidays, Parties may bring the Son out of jurisdiction for up to 2 weeks during the school holidays, subject to the provision of full written details of destination(s) during the trip, transport, accommodation, itinerary and contact details, to the other Party at least 2 weeks in advance.

(h)     During the Parties’ respective shared care and control periods, the Party having care and control shall be responsible for bringing the Son to and fetching the Son from his schools and any other ECAs.

(i)     The Husband shall be the custodian of the Son’s passport.

(j)     When the Wife intends to bring the Son out of jurisdiction, the Husband shall release the Son’s passport at least 48 hours before the intended travel date. Upon return to jurisdiction, the Wife shall return the Son’s passport to the Husband within 3 days of the return to jurisdiction (unless otherwise agreed).

5       Parties may depart from the access arrangements in [4] above by mutual agreement.

XLN v XLM

XLN v XLM
[2025] SGFC 47

Case Number:Maintenance Summons No 1289 of 2024, (Registrar's Appeal No 12 of 2025)
Decision Date:29 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Sheela Kumari Devi
Counsel Name(s): Complainant- in- person; Respondent- in- person.
Parties: XLN — XLM

Family Law – Maintenance – Stay of proceedings – Forum non conveniens

29 April 2025

District Judge Sheela Kumari Devi:

Introduction

1       The parties (whom I will refer to as the “Wife” and the “Husband”) are Indian nationals. They had their traditional marriage on 16 November 2016 in India and registered their marriage in India on 16 September 2019. Parties moved to Singapore in mid-2019. Their child was born in India on 21 June 2022 (the “Child”).

2       The parties’ marriage was fraught with difficulties leading to the Wife moving out of the parties’ rental flat together with the Child and commencing divorce proceedings in Singapore via Divorce Suit No. 5293 of 2023 (“D 5293”) on 2 November 2023. The Wife also filed the present maintenance proceedings for wife and child maintenance (“MSS 1289”) and an application for a personal protection order for herself via SS 1057 of 2024 (“SS 1057”) against the Husband on 4 June 2024.

3       For context, the Husband applied to stay D 5293 on the ground of forum non conveniens citing that India was the better forum. The Husband also commenced divorce proceedings in India. The Husband’s stay application was allowed by the learned Deputy Presiding Judge Chia Wee Kiat on 30 December 2024 and no appeal was filed by the Wife against the same. The parties’ divorce proceedings are on-going in India.

4       Both parties acted in person. At the hearing of MSS 1289 and SS 1057 on 17 December 2024, the Husband orally applied to stay both proceedings on the basis of forum non conveniens. I heard the applications on 24 February 2025 and dismissed both applications. The Husband has filed a Notice of Appeal against my decision in respect of MSS 1289. I shall now set out my brief reasons for dismissing the Husband’s application to stay MSS 1289.

Affidavits filed by the parties

5       Parties filed the following affidavits in respect of the stay application for MSS 1289:

(a)     the Husband’s affidavit filed on 20 December 2024 (“R1”);

(b)     the Wife’s affidavit filed on 30 December 2024 (“C1”);

(c)     the Wife’s affidavit filed on 12 February 2025 (“C2”); and

(d)     the Husband’s affidavit filed on 16 February 2025 (“R2”).

The parties’ cases

6       The Husband’s case was set out in R1 and R2.

7       In summary, the Husband’s case was as follows:

(a)     India is the more appropriate forum for hearing the maintenance proceedings and ancillary matters.

(b)     The Singapore court has found that India is the better forum to decide on the issues related to the divorce including the ancillary matters such as maintenance. The outcome of the stay application in D 5293 is binding on the MSS court.

(c)     The Wife can apply for interim maintenance in India immediately.

(d)     Allowing MSS 1289 to proceed would be inconsistent with the outcome of the stay application in D 5293 that Singapore is not the appropriate forum to deal with the ancillary matters. Further, if the Singapore Court grants interim maintenance, it will interfere with the Indian divorce proceedings and complicate the overall financial adjudication.

(e)     There are ongoing divorce proceedings in India and an application for interim maintenance can be made immediately.

(f)     The parties have never intended to permanently settle in Singapore. As such, given their temporary status, it would be inappropriate for the Singapore Court to assume jurisdiction over long-term matters such as spousal maintenance, which should be decided in India, which is their home country.

(g)     There is no urgency for interim maintenance as the Wife has financial resources.

8       The Wife’s case was set out in C1 and C2.

9       In summary, the Wife’s case was as follows:

(a)     R1 only addresses why the divorce proceedings should not continue in Singapore and does not address why MSS 1289 should not proceed in Singapore.

(b)     The parties and the Child have no plans to relocate to India. The Wife has been staying in Singapore since November 2019 and now holds an employment pass on the basis of her employment. The Child is also studying in Singapore. The Husband has been working in the same office in Singapore for the past 4.5 years and has not indicated anywhere in his affidavit of his immediate intention to resign his job and go to India to work.

(c)     The Wife and the Child’s monthly expenses are being incurred and will continue to be incurred in Singapore. It is therefore better that the Singapore Courts assess how much they should both be entitled to for maintenance from the Husband. Further, if the Husband fails to pay maintenance, the Wife can go to the Singapore courts for aid and assistance in enforcement.

(d)     The Wife will suffer severe prejudice if a stay is granted as the Indian Courts do require quite a number of hearings to be attended to in person. The Wife will have to travel to India with the Child and engage Indian lawyers to assist her.

Issues to be determined

10     The applicable test to determine if a proceeding commenced in Singapore ought to be stayed on the ground of forum non conveniens is set out in Spiliada Maritime Corporation v Cansulex Ltd [1987] AC 460 (the “Spiliada test”). As such, the issues that I was to decide on as per the Spiliada test were as follows:

(a)     Whether there was another available forum which was clearly or distinctly more appropriate than Singapore to determine the dispute as per stage one of the Spiliada test.

(b)     If there was another available forum which was prima facie more appropriate than Singapore, whether there were any special circumstances existing to warrant the exercise of the Court’s discretion to refuse a stay as per stage two of the Spiliada test.

11     In relation to the first issue, my finding was that Singapore is the most appropriate forum to determine the issue of interim maintenance. As such there was no need for me to go on to make to a finding on the second issue.

12     I set out my reasons for my findings on the first issue below.

Issue: Whether Singapore was the most appropriate forum?

13     The Spiliada test is essentially a factors-based test: the weight to be placed on the various factors varies with each factual matrix. What may prove to be critical in one case might not be that important in another. However, as noted by the High Court in BDA v BDB [2013] 1 SLR 607 (“BDA”) at [24], residence appears to be an important factor:

“Thus, where a defendant seeking a stay is working and residing in Singapore, there lies a greater evidential burden on him: the countervailing factors adduced in favour of the stay have to be correspondingly more convincing, in comparison to the hypothetical factual matrix, ceteris paribus, where the defendant is not resident in Singapore.”

14     In BDA, the parties were similarly Indian nationals and the wife had also made a s. 69 application for maintenance. The husband was resident in and employed in Singapore. The wife and the child were previously residing in Singapore but had left for India before the s. 69 application was filed. Parties were Singapore permanent residents. The husband commenced divorce proceedings in India shortly after the s. 69 application was filed. On appeal, the High Court dismissed the husband’s stay application. The Court noted, that the wife had instituted the maintenance application in Singapore, where the husband resided and worked. The Court also noted that the pending divorce proceedings instituted by the husband in India was not for the same relief as that claimed by the wife in her s. 69 maintenance application in Singapore. The former would result in the termination of the marriage, with the wife being entitled to apply for post-divorce maintenance while the latter was premised on the subsistence of the marriage.

15     In the instant case, the parties and the Child are presently residing in Singapore. While parties and the Child are Indian nationals, nationality per se is of limited significance as noted by the High Court in BDA at [29]. Parties are working in Singapore on their respective employment passes and are earning income from their work here. The Child is also presently enrolled in nursery in Singapore. The relevant living expenses of the Wife and the Child are incurred in Singapore. The marriage still subsists. If the matter is heard in India, both parties would have to travel from Singapore to India to attend to this.

16     While the Husband contends that parties’ stay in Singapore was temporary in nature and could be terminated at any point if their respective employment passes were not renewed, I did not think this was a strong factor to grant a stay as there was no evidence put before me that suggested that parties were at imminent risk of losing their jobs or that their employment passes would be terminated. In any event, should circumstances change, parties may make the appropriate application (if necessary) to vary and/or rescind any maintenance orders that have been made in Singapore.

17     Further, any maintenance order made in MSS 1289 would be temporary in nature for the following reasons:

(a)     Any spousal maintenance order made in MSS 1289 would cease to operate once the divorce proceedings have concluded in India and the Wife ceases to be a “wife” married to the Husband under the Women’s Charter.

(b)     The child maintenance order would also be superseded by any ancillary orders made by the Indian Court in relation to child maintenance.

18     I also did not agree with the Husband that there was an issue of lis alibi pendens arising. The pending divorce proceedings instituted by the Husband in India (which deals with reliefs arising post-termination of marriage) was not for the same relief as that claimed by the Wife in the present maintenance application in Singapore. MSS 1289 (at least in respect of the Wife’s claim for spousal maintenance) is premised on the subsistence of the marriage and any child maintenance order made in Singapore in these proceedings would similarly be overtaken by the ancillary orders made by the Indian Court. Thus, both proceedings are distinct and do not cover the same grounds.

19     I also address the Husband’s argument that the decision made by the learned Deputy Presiding Judge to stay the Singapore divorce proceedings in D 5293 was binding on this Court. Firstly, no legal basis was put forward as why the outcome of the stay application in D 5293 would be binding on this court. Secondly, the granting of the Husband’s stay application in D 5293 meant that Singapore was not the appropriate forum to deal with the divorce and ancillary issues. However, as stated above, the issues being raised in the application in MSS 1289 were not covering the same ground as the divorce proceedings in India. Finally, the Husband’s argument that any maintenance orders made in MSS 1289 would interfere with the Indian divorce proceedings and complicate the overall financial adjudication was not convincing. There were no specifics provided by the Husband beyond this bare assertion.

20     Ultimately, as stated by the Court in BDA, two questions must be addressed by the court in a s 69 application. First, the wife must show that she needs maintenance and that the husband has neglected or refused to provide reasonable maintenance for her and any child of the marriage. Second, the court will have to determine the quantum required for maintenance. On the first question, the court in Singapore is as well placed as any other to decide on the issue. As regards the second question, it would appear that the Singapore Court would be better placed to decide on this issue. First, the parties and the Child are presently residing in Singapore. Second, in determining the quantum of maintenance, the court shall have to take into account the standard of living enjoyed by the Wife and the Child before the Husband’s neglect or refusal to maintain them (see s 69(4)(f) of the Women’s Charter) and the present maintenance that they require. These determinations would be based on their expenses incurred in Singapore since they have been and are presently residing in Singapore. In this regard, the Singapore court would have an advantage over the Indian court in making these determinations.

Conclusion

21     For the reasons set out above, I find that the Husband has not discharged the burden of showing that India is clearly or distinctly a more appropriate forum. Therefore, based on stage one of the Spiliada test, MSS 1289 should not be stayed. There is then no need to go on to consider stage two of the Spiliada test.

22     The Husband’s application to stay the proceedings in MSS 1289 is dismissed.

XLO v XLP

XLO v XLP
[2025] SGFC 48

Case Number:Summons No 1206 of 2024
Decision Date:28 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Marcus Ho
Counsel Name(s): Mohamed Fazal Bin Abdul Hamid (I.R.B Law LLP) for the complainant; The respondent in person.
Parties: XLO — XLP

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection

28 April 2025

District Judge Marcus Ho:

Introduction

1       The Complainant and the Respondent are sisters. The Complainant is 44 years old this year. The Respondent is 50 years old this year. The Complainant and the Respondent live separately. The Complainant lives with her son, though her parents and her other sisters sometimes live with her.

2       On 26 June 2024, the Complainant applied for a personal protection order (“PPO”) against the Respondent. On 19 July 2024, the Respondent applied for a personal protection order against the Complainant. I heard both applications together and dismissed both. The Complainant has filed an appeal against my decision to dismiss her application. As the Respondent did not file any appeal against my decision to dismiss hers, this decision will focus on my reasons for dismissing the Complainant’s application.

The Complainant’s case

3       In the Complainant’s complaint form (the “Complaint Form”), she claimed that the Respondent caused hurt to her, placed her in fear of hurt, and continually harassed her. The Complainant primarily relied on an incident on 24 June 2024 to support her application.

4       The Complainant’s recount of the incident on 24 June 2024 is, in brief, as follows:

(a)     The Complainant had just stepped out of her room after a shower and was surprised to see the Respondent sitting in the dining area of her home. The Respondent did not inform the Complainant that she would be there.[note: 1]

(b)     The Respondent then started threatening the Complainant. The Respondent brought up the fact of the Complainant’s recent divorce from her former husband, saying “that is why your ex-spouse and you have to divorce because you are like this.”[note: 2] The Respondent started taking a video of the Complainant using her phone. This agitated the Complainant, who asked the Respondent to stop. The Respondent refused to stop, saying “I want to see how you’re so angry.”[note: 3] The Respondent called the Complainant’s son, to ask him to look at the Complainant.[note: 4]

(c)     The Complainant saw her mother packing her belongings into her luggage and noticed that she had taken a teeth retainer belonging to one of her sister’s daughters. The Complainant told her mother to remove this from her luggage. When she did not comply, the Complainant removed this from the luggage herself using her right hand.[note: 5]

(d)     The Respondent and her mother then tried to stop the Complainant. The Respondent tried to grab the teeth retainer and hurt the Complainant in the process. After the Respondent successfully took away the teeth retainer from the Complainant, the Complainant freed herself.[note: 6]

Legal requirements

5       The definition of ‘family violence’ is set out in Section 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed) (the “Charter”). This includes the commission of the following acts:

(a)    wilfully or knowingly placing, or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt;

(b)    causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt;

…

(d)    causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member

…

6       Section 64 of the Charter also defines ‘hurt’ as “bodily pain, disease and infirmity”.

7       Section 65(1) of Charter 1961 provides that the court may grant a PPO if two requirements have been met. First, the court must be satisfied that family violence has been committed or is likely to be committed. Second, the court must be satisfied that a protection order is necessary for the protection of that family member. The burden of proof is on the Complainant to prove that these two requirements have been met on a balance of probabilities.

My decision

8       On the balance of the evidence before me, I was not satisfied that the Respondent had committed family violence on the Complainant, or that the Respondent was likely to commit family violence on the Complainant.

Did the Respondent cause the Complainant hurt?

9       The Complainant claimed that the physical altercation caused her soreness on her right arm, scratches on her palm and wrist, and a bruise near her thumb. These injuries could constitute “hurt”, as defined in Section 64 of the Charter. The Complainant adduced five pictures showing a wound on her right palm and marks around her right hand.[note: 7] She also adduced a memo with a referral letter, certifying that the Complainant had visited a clinic on 26 June 2024 for “right shoulder strain and superficial abrasion over right wrist and palm”.[note: 8]

10     The evidence provided by the Complainant may have shown that the Complainant did suffer some injuries, but it did not necessarily establish that it was the Respondent who caused her these injuries. It remained unclear from the evidence who caused the injuries and how they were caused:

(a)     There was no evidence advanced by the Complainant to show that the Respondent was responsible for the injuries, bearing in mind that the tussle over the teeth retainer (that the Complainant says led to the hurt) was a tussle that involved three persons. There was also a lack of detail and description, whether in her Complaint Form, her affidavit, or from her oral evidence, to explain just how the Respondent had caused her the injuries she claimed. Even the referral form issued by the clinic she visited on 26 June 2024 stated that the Complainant was “uncomfortable to elaborate more other than she was pushed”.[note: 9]

(b)     During cross-examination, when asked about the cause of the blister on her palm, the Complainant was initially reserved in levelling any accusation that it was the Respondent who directly caused her injuries. Instead, her response was more oblique and general, saying that it was caused by the “commotion … by the physical interaction that was---came towards [her] while the Respondent is trying to take the teeth retainer from [her] palm.”[note: 10] The Respondent in fact did not seem certain as to the cause of the blister, saying that she “suspect[ed]” that it was from a sharp nail.[note: 11]

(c)     While the Complainant complained of a pain on her upper arm and suggested that this was caused during her physical altercation with the Respondent[note: 12], she had, in her Complaint Form, also conceded that this was because she “just had [her] covid booster on 7th June.”[note: 13] This cast doubt over whether the Respondent was responsible for the pain that the Complainant felt in her upper arm.

11     Further, I note that there were some inconsistencies in the Complainant’s evidence, which in my view diminished the credibility and likelihood of the Complainant’s claims relating to her injuries:

(a)     In her Complaint Form, the Complainant accused the Respondent of “hurting [the Complainant’s] palm with scratches and bruise on [her] right hand”.[note: 14] However, in C1, which contained the Complainant’s fleshed-out evidence, the Complainant did not mention being scratched by the Respondent at all.

(b)     In C1, the only acts of physical contact alleged were that the Respondent pushed the Complainant when trying to snatch the teeth retainer from her, and that the Respondent had restrained her (implied in the Complainant’s claim that she had to “free [herself]” from the Respondent). However, there was no suggestion on the Complaint Form that the Respondent pushed the Complainant or tried to restrain her. It is also noted that the nature of family violence complained of by the Complainant was not that of physical restraint.

12     On the evidence before me, I therefore found that the Complainant was unable to prove that the Respondent had caused her the hurt she claimed to have suffered.

Did the Respondent place the Complainant in fear of hurt?

13     The Complainant did not articulate in what way she had been placed in fear of hurt. While she suggests in C1 that she had to “break free”[note: 15] from the Respondent, there was no indication that the Respondent had intended to hurt her, such that she should have been afraid of being hurt if she had not freed herself. This is especially so where on the face of the Complainant’s evidence, the Respondent appeared focused on taking the teeth retainer away from the Complainant, rather than on specifically inflicting or threatening to inflict any sort of hurt on the Complainant.[note: 16]

14     The Complainant also mentioned being ‘threatened’ by the Respondent[note: 17]. However, there were no details as to what was said, or what were the threads made by the Respondent. There also did not appear to be any history of the Respondent threatening to hurt the Complainant, nor was there any suggestion that the Respondent was predisposed to inflict violence, such as to give the Complainant cause for such concern.

15     I therefore did not find sufficient evidence to establish that the Respondent had placed the Complainant in fear of hurt.

Did the Respondent continually harass the Complainant?

16     The Complainant claims to have been traumatised by the Respondent’s unannounced entry into her home. The Respondent had not given the Complainant any prior notice that she would be there, and the Complainant was surprised to see the Respondent in her home.

17     I did not find the Respondent’s entry into the Complainant’s home in itself to have placed the Complainant in fear of hurt (given the absence of any threat of hurt), or to amount to continual harassment for the purposes of establishing family violence. Both the Respondent and her mother each had a key to the Complainant’s home, and there was also no evidence that the Complainant had asked the Respondent to return her house keys prior to the incident. This suggests that the Complainant did not consider them to be persons whom she was afraid of and whom she could not trust with access to her home.

18     Furthermore, the Respondent did not enter the Complainant’s home by force, nor did she do so without reason. It was evident that she was there to accompany her mother, who was there to pack her belongings which were left in the Complainant’s home. In this context, it did not seem to me that the Respondent had appeared in the Complainant’s home with the intent of causing her anguish. In fact, it is unclear to me whether the Respondent would even have known that her presence in the house would have caused the Complainant anguish. I therefore did not find the Respondent’s entry into the Complainant’s home, as unwelcome as it may have been, to amount to continual harassment.

19     The Respondent had also allegedly made hurtful remarks to the Complainant about her relationship with her ex-husband, started taking a video of the Complainant, and asked the Complainant’s son to look at her while she was angry. Taken at face value, I accept that such acts could be provocative and aggravating. However, I did not find these claims to have been established on the evidence presented. In any case, the law requires that any harassment must be continual (see Yue Tock Him @ Yee Chok Him v Yee Ee Lim [2011] SGDC 99 at [43]); that is, the act must be repeated or repetitive (see XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [6(d)(ii)]). I did not consider any harassment that may have been caused to the Complainant to be continual, bearing in mind that there was no suggestion or proof of that the Respondent had previously provoked the Complaint in similar fashion.

20     I therefore did not find the Respondent to have committed family violence against the Complainant by way of continual harassment.

Conclusion

21     Having found no family violence committed by the Respondent, I consequently declined to grant the PPO sought by the Complainant.

22     For completeness, even if I were to find that the Respondent had inflicted family violence on the Complainant (which I did not in this case), I would not have found a protection order to be necessary for the protection of the Complainant. In my view, the tussle on 24 June 2024 was a one-off incident between the parties that started when the Complainant removed a teeth retainer from her mother’s luggage. It was her mother who first intervened to stop the Complainant, before the Respondent intervened. There does not appear to have been any other incident between them, whether before or after this incident, whether within the Complainant’s home, or anywhere else. It was also the Complainant’s position that the Respondent never entered her home before this incident, even though the Respondent held a key to her home, which suggests a low probability of the circumstances on 24 June 2024 repeating itself. I also noted that between the hearing on 27 November 2024 and 13 January 2025, the Respondent returned her copy of the Complainant’s home key to the Complainant.

23     In any event, I also noted that it was the Complainant’s own evidence that her interaction with the Respondent was limited at best. The Complainant’s evidence was that the parties were not close to each other, and that if at all, they only communicate to arrange for the Respondent’s daughter to give tuition to the Complainant’s son, which the Respondent’s daughter had been doing since March 2024.[note: 18] The Complainant said that the parties would cross paths with each other during family gatherings such as Chinese New Year, however I find the incidence of any family violence during such group settings to be unlikely. I therefore found the risk of the Respondent committing family violence against the Complainant in future to be low or non-existent, and that a PPO would therefore have been unnecessary.

24     As neither party made any request for costs, I made no order as to costs.
