html:
TPL v TPM

TPL v TPM
[2025] SGFC 46

Case Number:Divorce No 2524 of 2014 (Summons No 2478 and 2743 of 2024)
Decision Date:08 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Husband, in person and unrepresented; Kalvinder Kaur D/O Ranjit Singh and Kulvinder Kaur (I.R.B Law LLP) for the Wife.
Parties: TPL — TPM

Family Law – Costs

Family Law – Costs – Assessing the quantum of costs payable to a successful self-represented person

8 April 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       This is my judgment on costs in respect of SUM 2478 and 2743 of 2024.

2       The divorce between parties had concluded in 2016. Parties returned to court when, on the 26th of June 2024, the Wife took out an application vide SUM 1993/2024 (“SUM 1993”) to vary the orders made in respect of the ancillary matters.

3       As SUM 1993 wound its way through to a hearing, the Husband took out two applications for discovery and interrogatories in SUMs 2478 and 2743. I heard both applications and granted orders in respect of the Husband’s application. The only outstanding matter left for me to decide was that of costs.

4       The Husband submits that he should be entitled to costs. In formulating his position on costs, he argues that the court should take into account the fact that he is a practising lawyer. The Husband says that it is only fair to do so to ensure that he is compensated for reasonable costs incurred in the litigation.[note: 1]

5       In that vein, the Husband provides two bases upon which he has calculated the costs he says he should be entitled to:

(a)      Basis “A”: a discounted rate of $725 per hour. The discount applied reflects the discount that the Husband normally applies to his fees, and a further 30% discount to reflect the fact that he is not a Singapore qualified lawyer.[note: 2] The Husband says he has spent a total of 114.9 hours on both summonses. On this basis, the quantum of costs the Husband says he is entitled to comes up to $83,302.50.

(b)      Basis “B”: a discounted rate of S$330 per hour. According to the Husband, this rate takes into account the “actual cost” of participating in this litigation.[note: 3] The Husband has, in deriving this figure, computed the impact these proceedings has had on his billings. He says that he has spent a total of 114.9 hours on both summonses. The quantum of costs which the Husband says he is entitled to thus comes up to $37,917.00.

6       Counsel for the Wife, on the other hand, took the position that there should be no order as to costs. The following reasons were given. First, that it would be prudent to avoid aggravating acrimony between the parties. In support of this argument, counsel not only cited the decision in JBB v JBA [2015] 5 SLR 153 (“JBB”), but also pointed to the Husband’s conduct of the litigation where he had also taken out numerous other proceedings against the Wife.[note: 4] Second, that although the Husband is a lawyer, he is still effectively a litigant in person (or self-represented person). According to counsel, this justifies making no order as to costs because, as the court in WSH v WSI [2023] SGFC 40 had noted, costs are usually only provided when parties had legal representation.[note: 5]

7       Finally, counsel for the Wife also argued, in the alternative, that if I was minded to order costs in the Husband’s favour, the quantum of such costs should be fixed at $800. This reflects the fact that the Husband had not incurred filing fees in respect of the documents he had submitted. Counsel also cited the decision of the General Division of the High Court in Arokiasamy Steven Joseph (administrator of the estate of Salvin Foster Steven, deceased) and another v Lee Boon Chuan Nelson and others and other matters [2023] SGHC 291 (“Arokiasamy”) for the proposition that where litigants-in-person are awarded costs, the costs awarded are “much lower than what would have been awarded as party-and-party costs where the litigant is represented by solicitors”.[note: 6]

8       The starting point when it comes to costs in family proceedings is that costs shall follow the event. Given that the Husband had succeeded in both SUMs 2478 and 2743, in that he had obtained orders in respect of the majority of the items pursued in discovery and interrogatories, he is entitled to costs.

9       Although counsel for the Wife has argued that I should depart from this starting point to minimise acrimony between the parties, I find no basis to do so in the present case.

10     For one, although counsel for the Wife had stated that the acrimony between parties had “caused problems relating to their co-parenting of the children”, this was a bare assertion in their submissions made without references to any evidence contained in the affidavits that had been filed (see WYA v WYB [2024] SGFC 43 at [8]).

11     Counsel for the Wife did draw my attention to the various summonses filed by the Husband as evidence of the acrimony between the parties. That said, the mere fact of multiple applications being taken out by one party is not necessarily an indication of deep-seated acrimony between the parties.

12     This brings me to the next point – that is the quantum of costs which the Husband is entitled to. The starting point, when it comes to awarding costs to a self-represented person, is Rule 870 of the Family Justice Rules 2014 (“FJR 2014”) – that provision states:

Compensatory costs for litigants in person

870.  On a taxation of the costs of a litigant in person, such costs as would reasonably compensate the litigant for the time expended by him, together with all expenses reasonably incurred may be allowed.

13     Rule 870 has been interpreted as affording the court the discretion to “allow costs for a litigant in person that would reasonably compensate the litigant for the time expended by him, together with all expenses reasonably incurred” (VTQ v VTR [2021] SGFC 85 at [81]; see also WXI v WXJ [2024] SGFC 31 at [66]).

14     In this connection, the decision of the General Division of the High Court in Mah Kiat Seng v Attorney General and others [2023] SGHC 52 (“Mah Kiat Seng”) provides an example of how the court might assess costs that a self-represented person is entitled. In awarding the self-represented person (“Mah”) costs, the court applied O 59 r 18A of the Rules of Court (Cap 332, R 5, 2014 Rev Ed) (“ROC 2014”),[note: 7] which is essentially in pari materia with Rule 870 of the FJR 2014.

15     In its assessment of the quantum of costs that would reasonably compensate Mah for the time he had spent, the court considered two points. First, how much time did Mah spend on the litigation? Second, to fix an hourly rate that would compensate him for that time spent: Mah Kiat Seng at [10].

16     As to the amount of time Mah had spent, the court was of the view that there was no need to produce time sheets – the court was able to use its “own experience of litigation” to estimate the reasonable time spent. In that connection, the court noted that there must be an “objective yardstick of reasonableness” in assessing the amount of time spent: Mah Kiat Seng at [13].

17     As to the applicable hourly rate, the court arrived at a figure of $66.66 which was rounded down to $60.

18     In arriving at this hourly rate, the court took, as its starting point, the scale of costs applicable in the Magistrate’s Court – a typical case involving 2 to 3 days of trial and 3 to 4 days of pre and post-trial work would encompass some 50 hours of work on the part of the lawyer. Costs for such a case would come in at $5,000, and this would result in an hourly rate of $100. To eliminate the profit margin that a lawyer would be entitled to, but not a self-represented person, the court discounted the $100 hourly rate by a third: Mah Kiat Seng at [16].

19      Mah Kiat Seng, however, did not involve a situation where the self-represented person was a practising lawyer who had full conduct of their own case. In this connection, the Husband relies on the case of London Scottish Benefit Society v Chorley [1884] 13 QBD 872 (“Chorley”) for the proposition that he should be entitled to recover “his professional costs” for the legal work he had done on his own case. The Husband also cites the Singapore Court of Appeal decision in Lam Hwa Engineering & Trading Pte Ltd v Yang Qiang [2014] SGCA 3 (“Lam Hwa Engineering”) which he says implicitly recognises the principle in Chorley.

20      Chorley was a case where the defendants were lawyers who had acted in person. They won, and so, were entitled to costs. The question was whether they were entitled to costs that any other defendant in person was entitled to, or whether they were entitled to costs that a successful defendant who had employed a lawyer could claim (excluding costs for matters such as taking instructions). The plaintiffs objected when the defendants presented their bill of taxation to the master – they argued that that the defendants only ought to be entitled to costs that any other defendant in person was entitled to.

21     The master overruled the objection. A summons to review the master’s taxation was taken out and subsequently dismissed (see London Scottish Benefit Society v Chorley [1884] 12 QBD 452). The case went on to the Court of Appeal where Brett MR, Bowen LJ and Fry LJ dismissed the appeal.

22     This was the proposition laid down in Chorley: that a lawyer who acted in person was entitled to the same costs as a litigant who had engaged counsel to act for them, save for those items of costs that are rendered unnecessary (ie, the “costs of instructions and attendances”).

23     The rationale underlying this proposition was to avoid a situation where a lawyer, who was involved in their own personal litigation before the courts, could recover full costs by simply engaging another lawyer to act for them in their own case. As Brett MR noted:

It was contended for the plaintiffs that there is no difference as regards the right to costs between a solicitor and an ordinary person; and for the defendants it was contended that the costs of a solicitor, who is party to a suit, ought substantially to be taxed as if he had been acting for a different person. I think neither contention correct. I cannot think that any privilege of a solicitor exists. I am wholly unable to agree to any argument standing upon that footing. I should have thought that a person wrongfully brought into litigation ought to be indemnified against the expenses to which he is unjustly put; but there cannot be a perfect indemnity, because it is impossible to determine how much of the costs is incurred through his own over-anxiety. When an ordinary party to a suit appears for himself, he is not indemnified for loss of time; but when he appears by solicitor, he is entitled to recover for the time expended by the solicitor in the conduct of the suit. When an ordinary litigant appears in person, he is paid only for costs out of pocket. He cannot himself take every step, and very often employs a solicitor to assist him: the remuneration to the solicitor is money paid out of pocket. He has to pay the fees of the court, that is money paid out of pocket; but for loss of time the law will not indemnify him. When, however, we come to the case of a solicitor, the question must be viewed from a different aspect. There are things which a solicitor can do for himself, but also he can employ another solicitor to do them for him; and it would be unadvisable to lay down that he shall not be entitled to ordinary costs if he appears in person, because in that case he would always employ another solicitor. If a solicitor does by his clerk that which might be done by another solicitor, it is a loss of money, and not simply a loss of time, because it is work done by a person who is paid for doing it. It is true, however, to say that the costs of a solicitor appearing in person must be taxed differently from those of an ordinary litigant appearing by a solicitor. The unsuccessful adversary of a solicitor appearing in person cannot be charged for what does not exist, he cannot be charged for the solicitor consulting himself, or instructing himself, or attending upon himself. The true rule seems to be that when a solicitor brings or defends an action in person, he is entitled to the same costs as an ordinary litigant appearing by a solicitor, subject to this restriction, that no costs which are really unnecessary can be recovered. Of this kind are the costs of instructions and attendances. None of the text-books have laid down a different rule from that which I have enunciated, and a uniform practice has not prevailed amongst the masters.

[emphasis added]

24     Fry LJ made a similar observation:

I think that the conclusion at which we have arrived will be beneficial to the public, because if the rule were otherwise a solicitor who is party to an action would always employ another solicitor, and whenever he is successful he would recover full costs; whereas under the rule of practice laid down by us, a solicitor who sues or defends in person will be entitled, if he is successful, to full costs, subject to certain deductions, of which his unsuccessful opponent will get the benefit.

[emphasis added]

25     The Husband’s reliance on Chorley does not support his claim for costs on either basis that he has computed (above at [5]). It is clear from the speeches of Brett MR and Fry LJ that one concern was to avoid a situation where a lawyer, who had their own personal litigation before the courts, could claim full costs by simply engaging another counsel to act for them. The practical way of dealing with this was to allow such litigants to claim full costs, but to discount items that had been rendered unnecessary – such as the time expended in taking instructions from a client.

26     Even if one applies the rule in Chorley, the Husband would only be entitled to the same costs that he would have recovered, had he engaged a family lawyer to act for him, less any costs rendered unnecessary by the fact that he had acted in person. What this means, in practical terms, is that if the court would have awarded costs of $1,000 to a litigant who was represented in respect of an application for discovery and interrogatories, a quantum lower than $1000 should be awarded if the litigant were a lawyer who had chosen to represent themselves.

27     As to the Husband’s point, that the Singapore Court of Appeal had, in Lam Hwa Engineering, implicitly approved “the notion of a self-represented lawyer recovering his costs”, I do not share the same reading of that judgment.

28     In Lam Hwa Engineering, the respondent had sought to claim, as disbursements, travel expenses which came up to $1,208. The appellant objected to this claim. Their objections, however, found little weight with the taxing registrar, and the District Judge, and the High Court. The case eventually wound its way to the Court of Appeal.

29     Before the Court of Appeal, the appellant cited the decision in Chorley, claiming that it laid down a “general principle of law precluding the recovery of a successful litigant’s travel expenses”: Lam Hwa Engineering at [23].

30     The Court of Appeal rejected this argument, noting that the costs regime was governed by a legislative provision which reflected the prevailing policy considerations and societal conditions, and so the decision in Chorley, which was of some vintage, had little bearing on the issue of whether travel expenses could be reasonably claimed as disbursements: Lam Hwa Engineering at [24]. In any event, a close reading of Chorley revealed that there was a transcribing error – the word “travel” which appears in that judgment was “probably in fact meant to mean trouble” – and so Chorley could not support the proposition that the appellant had contended for: Lam Hwa Engineering at [25] – [28].

31     There is nothing in the passages of Lam Hwa Engineering which suggest that the Court of Appeal had implicitly endorsed the proposition in Chorley. On the contrary, the Court of Appeal had noted (at [29]) that little weight could be given to precedent from other jurisdictions unless it had been established that the costs framework applicable were in pari materia with our own framework. On that note, I also observe that the principle in Chorley is not a universally accepted one: see the decision of the High Court of Australia in Bell Lawyers Pty Ltd v Pentelow and Another [2019] HCA 29.

32     In the present case, as I have noted above, Rule 870 of the FJR governs the determination of costs, and the General Division of the High Court in Mah Kiat Seng had, in interpreting O 59 r 18A of the ROC 2014 (which is in pari materia with Rule 870 of the FJR 2014), laid down a framework to assess what constitutes reasonable costs. The question was whether this framework in Mah Kiat Seng should be applied (with or without any modifications) to the present case.

33     Both the Husband, as well as counsel for the Wife were invited to address me, in further written submissions, on this specific point.

34     Counsel for the Wife reiterated their position, that no order as to costs should be made. They also distinguish Mah Kiat Seng on the basis that the case was a relatively “complex tort matter concerning wrongful apprehension, false imprisonment and assault and battery, heard in the High Court” whereas both SUMs 2478 and 2743 were merely interlocutory applications heard in the Family Courts.[note: 8] This is, in my view, a distinction without merit – the real issue, which was not addressed, was whether the methodology for assessing costs payable to a self-represented person that had been used in Mah Kiat Seng was applicable, or could be adapted to the present case.

35     In addition, counsel for the Wife also pointed me to a set of proceedings in the High Court involving the same parties (ie, the Husband and the Wife). The Husband had taken out a discovery application, and prevailed. The Assistant Registrar had fixed costs at $500, despite having claimed $100,000 based on his hourly rate as a solicitor.[note: 9]

36     The Husband had filed an appeal which was dismissed by the High Court. Counsel for the Wife pointed out that the Husband had relied on Mah Kiat Seng in support of his arguments that he should be entitled to compensate him for the time expended by him on the matter, and that the court should fix an amount to compensate him for that time. The Husband’s appeal was wholly dismissed.

37     Insofar as counsel for the Wife had referred to this set of proceedings in the High Court involving both the Husband and the Wife, they had not placed before me, or cited, the reasons as to why the High Court had declined to apply Mah Kiat Seng in its assessment of costs.

38     The Husband, on the other hand, takes the position that if one applies the various propositions drawn from Mah Kiat Seng to the present case, I should take into account “non-monetary relief and considerations”. As to the considerations that should be accounted for, the Husband urges me to consider factors such as the Wife’s conduct, namely her alleged attempts to exclude him from the sale of their four jointly-owned properties, and the monthly sums that she is claiming in respect of maintenance for the children.[note: 10]

39     The Husband, however, argued that the “putative restriction” on costs in Mah Kiat Seng (referring to the 1/3 discount applied to reflect the profit margin that a lawyer is entitled to, but not a self-represented person (see above at [18]) should not apply. He cited the decision of the General Division of the High Court in Arokiasamy at [10] for the proposition that because he had “outperformed [counsel for the Wife] by a significant margin”, it would be “manifestly unjust” to limit his costs to “two thirds of what [a] fumbling counsel” would get.[note: 11]

40     In Arokiasamy, the court had to deal with the assessment of costs payable to a successful self-represented person. The court observed (at [8] – [11]) that:

8    The claim for costs by the plaintiffs is less straightforward. Traditionally costs were not given to litigants-in-person because such costs are party-and-party costs and awarded to help a litigant defray his solicitor-and-client costs. In modern times, the Rules of Court allow costs to be awarded even to litigants-in-person. In the rare cases where such costs had been awarded, they are much lower than what would have been awarded as party-and-party costs where the litigant is represented by solicitors or counsel.

9    The Civil Procedure Rules in the UK capped costs to litigants-in-person to two thirds of what would have been ordered had the litigant been represented by a lawyer. This appears to have been the formula adopted by the High Court in Mah Kiat Seng v Attorney-General and others [2023] SGHC 52 at [7]-[9]. I have no disagreement with the decision of Jeyaretnam J in that case, save to say that it is not appropriate to lay down strict formulae for costs for litigants-in-person for reasons that I shall now elaborate.

10    Unlike the Civil Procedure Rules in the UK which provide for capped costs to litigants-in-person, our Rules of Court 2014 (O 59 r 18A) and Rules of Court 2021 (O 21 r 7) do not provide for any cap on quantum. As such, I am of the view that the two thirds cap found in the UK Civil Procedure Rules is, at best, a useful guide. The quantum of costs is always discretionary (as opposed to the principles regarding when costs may be awarded). That is because costs are fact sensitive, and every case is different. When litigants appear in person, matters can get even more complicated because an anxious litigant may labour excessively, often misguiding himself for lack of knowledge of the law. In other cases, the litigant may indeed have knowledge of the law and labour as hard with better results. Conversely, a litigant-in-person may outperform counsel in the case, making it appear manifestly unjust that he should be limited to two thirds of what the fumbling counsel gets.

11    The point therefore, is that costs of a litigant-in-person should not be taxed separately, but fixed by the trial judge because he is the person who knows the facts and merits required to adjust the discretionary quantification of costs to a litigant-in-person. That court will be guided by the fact that money is rarely adequate compensation even in successful litigation. Neither are costs meant as a punishment to the party who has failed.

[emphasis added]

41     It is worth noting that the court in Arokiasamy did not follow the approach in Mah Kiat Seng. In fixing costs at $500, the court took into account the fact that both plaintiffs had to attend court on two or three occasions and that they had produced evidence on affidavit that had assisted the court. Given that neither plaintiff was employed, there was no loss of income to claim as disbursements.

42     In the present case, I would decline to follow the approach in Mah Kiat Seng for two reasons. First, in Mah Kiat Seng, the court’s starting point, when it came to assessing the hourly rate that a self-represented person was entitled to, was the scale of costs included in Part IV of Appendix 2 to ROC 2014 which provided that in cases before the Magistrate’s Court, where a plaintiff was awarded $20,000, the range of costs to be awarded was $3,000 – $6,000 (excluding disbursements).

43     If one looks at the FJR 2014, a set of fixed costs is also provided for certain cases (ie, where summary judgment is obtained) under Part 2 to the Third Schedule of the FJR 2014. These figures are identical to those found in Part 2 of Appendix 2 of the ROC 2014, except that the scale is for the District Court, whereas the figures provided for the same proceedings in the Magistrate’s Court are approximately 1.5 times lower.

44     While it may be tempting to apply a multiplier of 1.5 to the hourly rate of $60 in Mah Kiat Seng in order to fix an hourly rate, I would decline to do so. That is because the figures given in Part 2 to the Third Schedule of the FJR 2014 do not appear to cover applications for discovery and interrogatories.

45     This leads me to my second reason for declining to apply the approach in Mah Kiat Seng. I consider that adopting such an approach would be counterproductive, especially when one considers the principles of therapeutic justice. Adopting an hourly rate to the computation of costs may well serve to promote acrimonious litigation as parties are incentivised to keep track of the score in terms of the time they had spent on proceedings so that they are in a position to make submissions on costs should they prevail. This would only serve to distract parties from focussing on how they can amicably resolve the dispute, heal, and move on and rebuild their lives in a positive way.

46     Ultimately, costs are in the discretion of the court, and a glance at the costs jurisprudence in the Family Courts demonstrates that weight is typically given to factors such as the conduct of parties (XER v XES [2025] SGFC 4; WQF v WQG [2024] SGFC 113 at [23]; XBG v XBH [2024] SGFC 81; see also Tan Hui Qing, “The Role of Conduct in the Award of Maintenance and Costs Orders: WUP v WUQ [2024] SGHCF 15” [2024] SAL Prac 15 at [21] – [22]), and whether the award of costs would risk worsening the acrimony between the parties (JBB; XHS v XHT [2025] SGFC 20 at [91] citing BNH v BNI [2013] 283 at [50] and USC v USD [2021] SGHCF 4 at [9]; WZH v WZI [2025] SGFC 15 at [141]).

47     Apart from these considerations, I also agree with the proposition in Arokiasamy (at [8]) that costs awarded to a successful self-represented person are typically lower than in cases where the litigant is represented by counsel.

48     There is, of course, that scenario as described in Chorley: that lawyers who had their own personal litigation in the courts could simply claim the full quantum of costs by hiring another lawyer to represent them. There are, however, good reasons, at least in the context of family disputes, as to why one might wish to engage the counsel of a member of the Family Bar. For one, it is clear that the practice of family law has developed into a specialised field and the role of the modern family lawyer is not limited to merely resolving disputes, but also “rehabilitating relationships, championing resilience and restoring hope”: Justice Teh Hwee Hwee, “Building Hope, Embracing Change” (Speech delivered at the 10th Anniversary Celebration of the Family Justice Courts, 21 October 2024) at paragraph 8.

49     In my assessment of costs, I considered the numerous items which the Husband had pursued in respect of his applications for discovery and interrogatories. Given the number of items pursued, it was unsurprising that voluminous sets of documents had been filed, and that two tranches of hearing were needed to dispose of both summonses. This spoke to the time and energy that had been expended on both summonses that would justify a higher quantum of costs.

50     There was also one other consideration I gave weight to which merited awarding a lower quantum of costs – and that was the conduct of parties. It was clear to me, from the various documents that had been filed (ie, the correspondence between parties that had been exhibited)[note: 12] that the Husband had, in his pursuit of both summonses, taken a rather adversarial stance which is not acceptable in our family justice system: see XER v XES [2025] SGFC 4 at [4(c)] citing VVB v VVA [2022] 4 SLR 1181 at [26] and [28].

51     As a final point, I would add that the essence of the Husband’s claim for the sum of roughly $40,000 – $80,000 in costs was to compensate him for his lost income in light of the time and effort he had spent on the litigation.

52     I do not take the Husband’s lost income into account. The Husband had attached correspondence showing that he had obtained a fee quote from at least one member of the Family Bar. Although that fee quote did not factor in applications for discovery and interrogatories, the point remains that the Husband thus had, available to him, what appeared to be a cost-effective option of handling the dispute that would leave him free to focus on his work. Given that he had chosen not to avail himself of this option, I do not think it now open to him to urge this court to consider his lost income in the assessment of costs.

53     In light of what I have set out above, costs for both SUMs 2478 and 2743 are fixed at $2,500 (all-in). This sum shall be paid by the Wife to the Husband by 6 May 2025.
