html:
XLD v XLE

XLD v XLE
[2025] SGFC 45

Case Number:SS No. 201 of 2024
Decision Date:21 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Khoo May Ann
Counsel Name(s): Ms Hoon Shu Mei and Ms Shannen Leong (Drew & Napier LLC) for the Complainant; Ms Kulvinder Kaur and Ms Kalvinder Kaur (I.R.B. Law LLP) for the Respondent.
Parties: XLD — XLE

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection

21 April 2025

District Judge Khoo May Ann:

Introduction

1       SS 201 of 2024 (“SS 201”) relates to a father’s (“Complainant”) application for a personal protection order (“PPO”) on behalf of his son (“Child”), against the Child’s step-father (“Respondent”).

Witnesses

2       The relevant hearings for the matter were held on 24 May 2024 (“1st Hearing”) and 18 July 2024 (“2nd Hearing”). During the course of the relevant hearings, the following witnesses had been called by the Complainant:

a.     The Complainant’s mother (“Complainant’s Mother”);

b.     The Complainant’s younger sister (“Complainant’s Sister”);

c.     The Complainant’s sister’s boyfriend (“Complainant’s Sister’s Boyfriend”);

d.     A teacher from the Child’s school (“Teacher”);

e.     The first doctor that had examined the Child, Dr S (“Dr S”); and

f.     The second doctor that had examined the Child, Dr P (“Dr P”),

(collectively, the “Witnesses”).

Documents

3       The following documents had been submitted by the Complainant for the purposes of the application:

a.     The Complainant’s bundle of affidavits marked as “C1”, which included the following documents:

i.       Complainant’s Affidavit dated 20 March 2024 (affirmed on 19 March 2024) (“Complainant’s first affidavit”);

ii.       Complainant’s Sister’s Affidavit dated 20 March 2024 (“Complainant’s Sister’s Affidavit”);

iii.       Teacher’s Affidavit dated 20 March 2024 (“Teacher’s Affidavit”),

b.     Complainant’s supplementary affidavit dated 21 May 2024 marked as “C2”;

c.     Complainant’s Sister’s affidavit dated 21 May 2024 marked as “C3”;

d.     Complainant’s four thumb-drives marked as “C4”;

e.     Complainant’s additional thumb-drive marked as “C5”;

f.     Affidavit of Ms L marked as “C6”;

g.     Complainant’s Opening Statement (“COS”); and

h.     Complainant’s Written Submissions (“CS”).

4       The following documents had been submitted by the Respondent for the purposes of the application:

a.     Respondent’s affidavit marked as “R1”; and

b.     Respondent’s supplemental affidavit marked as “R2”;

c.     Respondent’s Opening Statement (“ROS”);

d.     Respondent’s Written Submissions (“RS”); and

e.     Respondent’s Bundle of Authorities (“RBA”).

5       For completeness, the relevant Notes of Evidence relating to the trial will be collectively referred to as the “NE”. For avoidance of doubt, the references to the relevant NEs are as follows:

a.     The NE for the 1st Hearing will be referred to as “NE1”;

b.     The NE for the 2nd Hearing will be referred to as “NE2”; and

c.     The NE for the hearing on 23 January 2025 where submissions had been made on the issue of costs will be referred to as “NE3”.

6       In the present case, I found that the requirements for a PPO had not been satisfied on a balance of probabilities. As the Complainant has appealed against my decision, the grounds of my decision are set out below.

Background

7       First, it would be important to set out the background to the present matter due to high-conflict nature of the dispute. From the outset, one of the arguments that had been raised by the Respondent was that the Complainant had an “ulterior motive” in filing SS 201 as he was attempting to “fight” for the Child from the Child’s mother (“Mother”), who is the former wife of the Complainant and the current wife of the Respondent[note: 1].

8       In brief, the Complainant and the Child’s mother (“Mother”) were married around November 2015[note: 2]. The Child was born on 17 January 2019[note: 3].

9       An Interim Judgement (“IJ”) was made in respect of the Complainant and the Mother on 9 March 2022. Under the further orders to the IJ, the Complainant and the Mother had consented to an arrangement where both parties’ were to be granted joint custody of the Child, with care and control to the Mother. Access was granted to the Complainant under the IJ. The Final Judgment is dated 13 June 2022[note: 4].

10     The Respondent’s case was that he and the Mother were married around December 2023. From the time of the marriage, the Respondent claims that he had helped the Mother in taking care of the Child[note: 5]. For avoidance of doubt, the Child has been living with the Mother and the Respondent, with the Complainant having access to the Child in accordance with the terms set out under the IJ.

11     The Complainant filed SS 201 on 2 February 2024. At the material time, the Child was around 5 years of age.

12     It is not disputed that after SS 201 was filed in February 2024, the Complainant had filed an application on 20 May 2024 to vary the IJ, particularly on the issue of access to the Child.

Parties’ Positions

Complainant’s Position

13     The Complainant relied on an isolated incident in his Complaint Form that allegedly occurred around Friday, 26 January 2024, whereby he said, in his words, that a “cane alike wound” was spotted on the Child’s right upper arm and that this was caused by the Respondent (“Isolated Incident”). The Complainant claimed that the Child had allegedly stated that “he [was] naughty and Uncle [D] beat him. [D] is his step-father”. He claimed that when the Child’s “school” asked the Child about the alleged wound on Monday, 29 January 2024, the Child had allegedly stated that “Uncle [D]” (the term that the Child used to refer to the Respondent) had beat him[note: 6].

14     The Complainant then filed his first affidavit, where he elaborated on the alleged Isolated Incident. The salient points have been set out below:

a.     The Complainant claimed he had picked the Child up from school on 26 January 2024.

b.     He claimed that on 27 January 2024, the Complainant’s Mother discovered bruises on the Child’s right upper arm while she was changing him. The Complainant then stated that he understood from his mother that the Child had said that the Respondent had beaten him[note: 7].

c.     The Complainant texted the Mother on 28 January 2024. The Mother denied that the Respondent had caused the Child’s bruises. The Complainant also texted the Child’s paternal grandmother, who denied that anyone had hit the Child in the Mother’s residence[note: 8].

d.     The Complainant’s Sister and the Complainant’s Sister’s Boyfriend also had an exchange with the Child on what happened to his arm. The Complainant claimed that the Complainant’s Sister informed him that the Child had told her that the Respondent “beat [him]”[note: 9].

e.     The Complainant and the Complainant’s Sister then brought the Child to visit a doctor where the Child was attended to by Dr S. Dr S expressed that the Child had a “[contusion] of shoulder and upper arm”. Dr S subsequently provided a medical report dated 21 February 2024 (“Medical Report”) stating that the bruises over the Child’s right shoulder could “possibly” represent cane marks[note: 10].

f.     Apart from this, the Complainant sent a message to the Child’s school to enquire how the Child got bruises on his arm. The Teacher, namely, one Mdm G, subsequently informed the Complainant that the Child informed her that it was the Respondent who hit him[note: 11].

15     After the Complaint Form and Complainant’s first affidavit were filed, it is observed that the Complainant’s counsel made submissions after the event that the Respondent had hit the Child with a cane-like object because the Child had allegedly opened a family member’s room door at night[note: 12].

Respondent’s Position

16     The Respondent strongly denied the Complainant’s allegations. He claimed that the Complainant had made a false allegation that he had caned the Child. The Respondent’s claims are summarised below[note: 13]:

a.     The Respondent’s case was that the Isolated Incident never happened, and he had never hit the Child, be it with his hand or any item.

b.     The Respondent stated that, on 26 January 2024, the Child had gone to school as per normal and the Mother and the Child’s maternal grandfather had sent him to school. The school had not reported any bruises on the Child. The Child then went to the Complainant’s place for his access session in the evening.

Applicable Law

17     In SS 201, it is observed that the degree of parental conflict between the parties was relatively high, given that it was undisputed that the Complainant had also filed an application relating to the Child’s access after filing SS 201. In addition, the Isolated Incident allegedly occurred when the Child was in the care and control of the Mother. It would thus be apposite to highlight the Court’s observations in the case of WDC v WDD and others [2024] SLR(FC) 58; [2022] SGFC 41 at [8]:

“In cases where there is high parental conflict with underlying substantive disputes over access (like in the present case), there is a tendency for the parents to point fingers at each other upon discovery of minor injuries on their child. This may often lead to the child being subject to physical examination with every handover for access and the taking of photographic evidence. If there is no family violence or likelihood of family violence, such behaviour is particularly harmful to the child as it brings the child into the direct path of conflict between the parents. As such, it is all the more important to scrutinize the evidence carefully in these cases to determine whether family violence has indeed been committed or is likely to be committed. Section 65(1) of the Women’s Charter 1961 states that: -

65.-(1) The Court may, upon satisfaction on a balance of probabilities that family violence has been committed or is likely to be committed against a family member and that it is necessary for the protection of the family member, make a protection order restraining the person against whom the order is made from using family violence against the family member.”

18     The law is clear that before a PPO may be granted, two conditions must be satisfied (see section 65 of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“WC”); and UNQ v UNR [2020] SGHCF 21 (“UNQ”)).

a.     First, that family violence has been committed or is likely to be committed against the family member; and

b.     Second, that a PPO is necessary for the protection of that family member.

19     The burden is on the Complainant to prove, on a balance of probabilities, that family violence has been committed and is likely to be committed.

20     What constitutes family violence? Under the WC, “family violence” is defined to include the commission of any of the the following acts:

a.     wilfully or knowingly placing, or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt (“Limb A”);

b.     causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt (“Limb B”);

c.     wrongfully confining or restraining a family member against his or her will;

d.     causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member,

e.     but does not include any force lawfully used in self-defence, or by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age.

21     The protection of a PPO carries with it criminal sanctions. In light of the criminal consequences that follow a breach of a PPO, ordering one is not a decision that the Court would make lightly (UNQ at [28])[note: 14]. In XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103, it was highlighted that at [22]:

“It bears emphasis that PPOs will not be issued where they are sought to serve a collateral purpose. Courts have dismissed such applications where they are sought –

(a)    To bolster an applicant’s request for the care and control of her children: CSW at [13]-[17];

(b)    To indirectly challenge a child handover order: CSW at [18] and [19];

(c)    To resolve a dispute regarding (i) child access (UNQ at [39]) or (ii) trivial matters (VKW at [15]).”

Issues To Be Determined

22     The issues are as follows:

a.     Whether family violence was committed or is likely to be committed against the Child by the Respondent. In particular, the key issue relates to whether it can be shown, on a balance of probabilities, that the bruises observed on the Child were caused by the Respondent during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident; and

b.     Whether a PPO is necessary to protect the Child.

Issue 1: Whether Family Violence Has Been Committed Or Is Likely To Be Committed

23     The key issue is whether the bruise observed on the Child’s arm had been caused by the Respondent during the material time of the Isolated Incident such that this fell within the scope of the definition of “family violence” under the WC, particularly Limb A and/or Limb B (which the Complainant referred to at page 5 of the Complaint Form).

24     Having considered the evidence and the submissions, I was unable to find that the Complainant had proved, on a balance of probabilities, that family violence had been committed against the Child by the Respondent during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident. My reasons are set out below.

Child

25     As a starting point, the Complainant relied on what he claimed he had heard from the Child and what the Witnesses claimed they had heard from the Child to support his argument that the Respondent had allegedly committed family violence against the Child during the material time of the Isolated Incident.

26     The Complainant submitted that the statements made by the Witnesses on what the Child had allegedly said were admissible under Section 32(1)(j)(i) of the Evidence Act 1893 (“EA”) read with Section 120 of the EA. The Complainant’s arguments on this point are summarised below:

a.     The Complainant highlighted that the Child, who was at the young age of around 5 years old at the material time, had delayed speech development and difficulties in expressing himself. As such, the Complainant argued that the Child was not competent to testify as a witness.

b.     Thus, the Complainant’s submission was that the Child’s statements that had been relayed to the Witnesses were admissible under the EA.

c.     The Complainant also submitted that the Child’s statements were cogent and buttressed by the fact that the Child repeated this statement multiple times[note: 15].

27     My observations on the Complainant’s arguments are set out below.

28     First, in respect of the Complainant’s argument that the Child was not competent to testify as a witness, it was difficult to reconcile this argument with the Complainant’s other argument that the Child’s alleged statements were “cogent”. It did not logically flow that the Child’s statements could be relied on as “cogent” statements, when the Complainant was also attempting to argue that the Child was not competent to testify due to the Child’s delayed speech development and difficulties in expressing himself.

29     Second, the burden is on the Complainant, who is seeking to rely on section 32(1)(j)(i) of the EA, to prove that the Child was unfit to attend as a witness. While the Complainant cited the case of UUX v UUW [2019] SGFC 137 as an example where an application to call a young child as a witness was rejected, I observed from the said case that the District Judge had the benefit of assessing the child’s evidence and demeanour via video-link before making the determination to reject the relevant application at [12][note: 16]. In the present case, apart from the lack of opportunity to observe the Child’s demeanour, there was also a lack of evidence provided by the Complainant, such as any medical report, that expressly indicated that the Child was too young or that his mental condition rendered him unable to testify for the Court to make any determinative findings on the same.

30     Third, even if I had found that the alleged statements that the Child made were admissible under the EA, due consideration must be given to the weight to be accorded to these alleged statements. On this point, I observed that the Complainant, himself, had expressed concerns that the Child could be coached and/or indirectly pressured. As such, I found it difficult to place much weight, if at all, on the Child’s statements. I elaborate on this below:

a.     In the present case, it is observed that the Complainant and the Respondent’s counsel had both tried to cast doubt on the veracity of the statements that the Child had made.

b.     As stated above, the Complainant had expressed concerns that the Child could be coached and/or indirectly pressured. In particular, the Complainant had highlighted that when he returned the Child to the Mother on 28 January 2024 (after the Isolated Incident), the Child had initially told the Mother that the Respondent hit him. However, the Complainant said that when the Mother repeated her question to the Child, the Child then claimed that his injuries were caused by a fall. The Complainant then said he was “worried” and “concerned” about the Mother indirectly pressuring the Child to say the “correct” answer[note: 17].

c.     Furthermore, when the Complainant was asked during cross-examination whether the Child tells “fibs”, he claimed that the Child is “very cheeky” and “does tell white lies at times”.

d.     The Complainant also did not dispute that he had sent the WhatsApp message exhibited at page 71 of R1 where he affirmed that he had made the following statement in relation to the Child: “I know he lies, and we always tell him not to. If no tell lies, we will give him present.”

e.     In view of the Complainant’s own position that the Child has told lies and the Complainant’s own concerns of the Child’s propensity to be indirectly pressured by his parents, this created doubt as to the veracity of the Child’s statements that were allegedly made.

31     Fourth, apart from the Complainant, it must be reiterated that the Respondent’s counsel had also attempted to cast doubt on the statements the Child had made. This is elaborated upon below:

a.     The Respondent’s counsel referred to a transcript submitted by the Complainant in C2 where the Child is recorded to have said to the Mother during a call that, “Uncle [D] beat me”, on 3 February 2024 (“Relevant Transcript”). In response, the Respondent’s counsel argued that the Complainant was coaching the Child before the call with the Mother, whereby the Complainant is recorded to have said “Remember ah, mama ask you, want to go mama house, if you say yes papa will send you back. Then Uncle [D], you will see him already ok? If you don’t want to go, you must tell mama don’t want to go mama house.”

b.     In this regard, the Respondent’s counsel raised the point that it was odd that, at the outset, the Child had first said that the Respondent had beat him.

c.     After reviewing the contents of the Relevant Transcript, I observed as a preliminary point that it was unclear who prepared the transcript as there was no certification to be found on the said transcript.

d.     Nevertheless, even if the Relevant Transcript could be relied upon, it is noted that the transcript related to an event on 4 February 2024 which was around more than a week after the material time that the alleged Isolated Incident was expected to have occurred (i.e. in or around 24 to 26 January 2024, as submitted by the Complainant). Based on the Relevant Transcript, the Complainant’s words to the Child could be construed as a form of coaching on his part where he instructed the Child that he “must tell” the Mother that he did not want to go to the Mother’s house. The prompts provided by the Complainant to the Child cast doubt on the reliability of the Child’s statements, particular the Child’s alleged claim that the Respondent had allegedly beaten him.

e.     Given that the Complainant had his own concerns on the Child’s propensity to be indirectly pressured and given that he appeared to have been coaching the Child himself, I could not rely or place much weight on what the Child allegedly stated from the Relevant Transcript to find that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child, on a balance of probabilities.

32     For completeness, the Complainant’s own concerns on the veracity of the Child’s statements cast doubt on all of the claims that the Child had allegedly made to the Complainant and the Witnesses. It was thus difficult to rely on the assertions the Child had made as evidence as to the truth of the contents therein and I could not place much weight, if at all, on such statements.

Complainant

33     This leads me to the observation that the Complainant’s allegations were largely based were based on hearsay evidence.

34     The thrust of the Complainant’s claims were premised on what he claimed the Child had allegedly said to him or what the Witnesses told him about what the Child had conveyed to them. As the Complainant himself had doubts as to the veracity of certain statements that the Child had made, it was difficult for me to rely on the Complainant’s statements (which were largely based on what he claimed that he had heard from the Child), to find that he had satisfied the burden of proof that lay on him to demonstrate that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child, on a balance on probabilities. I elaborate on this below:

a.     First, the Complainant’s various statements on the Isolated Incident and what occurred thereafter appeared to be inconsistent, as highlighted during the cross-examination. For example, in the Complaint Form, the Complainant stated that he discovered the bruise on the Child on 26 January 2024. However, on the stand during the 2nd Hearing, he claimed that he had only discovered the bruise on the Child on the morning of 27 January 2024. When the Respondent’s counsel asked the Complainant whether he agreed that his version in the Complaint Form differed from the version in his first affidavit, the Complainant confirmed that this was correct[note: 18]. The Complainant had also agreed when the Respondent’s counsel had put it to him that he had mentioned “inconsistent days in the days in the documents” before the Court. In particular, it is also noted that the Complainant did not disagree when the Respondent’s counsel put it to him that he had inconsistent timings in the documents before the Court[note: 19].

b.     Second, the Complainant did not witness the Respondent hit the Child. On the stand, when the Complainant was questioned during cross-examination on whether he had seen the Respondent hit the Child, the Complainant’s response was “no”. When the Complainant was questioned during cross-examination on whether he had ever seen the Respondent hit the Child, the Complainant’s response was “no”[note: 20]. As such, it was difficult for me to rely on the Complainant’s account to find that the Respondent had caused the bruises observed on the Child’s arm, when the Complainant had not witnessed what had occurred during the material time of the Isolated Incident and when he had admitted that he had never seen the Respondent hit the Child.

c.     As the Complainant did not witness what had occurred during the material time of the Isolated Incident, I could not rely on what he claimed the Child told him or what the other Witnesses claimed the Child had told them to make affirmative findings that the Respondent had beaten and/or caned the Child.

35     To summarise, in the absence of clear particulars relating to what had transpired during the material time of the Isolated Incident, the inconsistencies in the Complainant’s documents, as well as the lack of clear evidence that the Respondent had beaten and/or hit the Child (given that the Complainant admitted he had never witnessed this before), I could not rely on the Complainant’s statements to find that the Complainant had sufficiently shown, on a balance of probabilities, that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child.

Respondent

36     I now turn to the Respondent’s case.

37     The Respondent repeatedly denied the Complainant’s allegations. In particular, during cross-examination, the Complainant’s counsel put the following statements to the Respondent, which he disagreed with[note: 21]:

Q    Okay. I put it to you that you had sufficient opportunity that night---on---on---on the days prior to the 27th when [the Child] said that he woke up in the middle of the night and you lost your temper, and you struck him. Agree or disagree?

A     Disagree.

Q    At 2:00, 3:00, 4:00am, everyone else would have been sleeping, I put it to you that when you hit the child, no one else would have known or no one would have seen because everyone else would have been in bed. Correct or incorrect?

A     Incorrect.

[Emphasis added.]

38     From the above extract, it would be pertinent to highlight the following:

a.     First, the Respondent repeatedly denied that he had struck or hit the Child. This was consistent with the position he maintained during the relevant hearings over the course of the trial and in his documents.

b.     Second, certain statements that were put to the Respondent by the Complainant’s counsel during cross-examination had not been mentioned in the Complaint Form. For example, under the Complaint Form, the Complainant had not suggested that it was his case that the Respondent had hit the Child during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident in the middle of the night or between “2:00, 3:00, 4:00am”, when everyone else was sleeping (as put by the Complainant’s counsel to the Respondent during cross-examination). Furthermore, it is also noted that it was only in the Complainant’s submissions that it had been suggested that the Respondent hit the Child with a cane-like object for opening his family member’s room door at night. These explanations appear to only have been provided by the Complainant as an afterthought.

c.     Third, even if it were the Complainant’s case that the Respondent had allegedly hit the Child in the middle of the night during the material time of the Isolated Incident, I found it unusual that the Complainant’s counsel had suggested that “no one else would have known or no one would have seen”, as there was a high likelihood that the Child would have cried or expressed discomfort if the Respondent had indeed struck or hit the Child, causing the “cane alike” wound that the Complainant had described. Furthermore, the Complainant’s counsel submitted that the Respondent had hit the Child “because he was naughty for opening a door”[note: 22]. From the said argument, it could only be inferred that the Complainant had been implicitly suggesting that the reason why the Child was naughty for opening the door was that he would be disturbing his family members (resulting in the alleged punishment of the Child). Even if this were the case, this argument did not square with the Complainant’s argument that the rest of the Child’s family members at the Mother’s residence would not have woken up or have been alerted to the Child’s cries if the Respondent had hit the Child in the manner the Complainant suggested in the middle of the night (at a timing that remained unspecified and unclear based on the Complainant’s own case).

d.     Fourth, as stated above, there was a lack of clarity as to what time or on which exact day the Respondent had allegedly hit the Child during the material time of the Isolated Incident, much less other supporting documents or further evidence to corroborate the Complainant’s counsel’s submissions that the Child had been hit between “2:00, 3:00, 4:00am” with a “cane-like” object by the Respondent for opening a door. For example, there was no video or photographic evidence produced to demonstrate that the Respondent had allegedly struck the Child. The Complainant also did not produce any evidence that the Respondent had a cane, which the Respondent denied possessing. The Complainant had also not made any application to summon the Mother, or the Child’s maternal grandparents, who were allegedly around at the Mother’s residence during the material time of the Isolated Incident, as witnesses.

39     For completeness, I also considered that the Complainant’s counsel had tried to rely on the following portions of the NE2 [note: 23], during the 2nd Hearing to claim that the Respondent had allegedly admitted to hitting the Child:

Q     [The Mother] does not know you hit [the Child], correct?

A     Yes. Um---

Q    That’s why she agreed for [the Child] to be handed over to you pending investigations on 29th Jan, correct?

A    Sorry, can you repeat that again?

Q    That’s why she even agreed for [the Child] to be handed over to [the Complainant] pending investigations on 29th Jan, correct?

A    He hand---she handed over to [the Complainant] because [Complainant] was worried.

[Emphasis added.]

40     Having considered the relevant NEs in totality, I could not rely on the exchange above to find that this amounted to a unequivocal admission by the Respondent that he had hit the Child during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident to arrive at the finding that the Complainant had sufficiently proved that family violence had been committed against the Child, on a balance of probabilities. I elaborate on this below:

a.     Having examined the Respondent’s answer (i.e. “yes”) in response to the question, “[the Mother] does not know you hit [the Child], correct?”, it was unclear whether the Respondent had understood or heard the Complainant counsel’s question correctly in the context of the trial.

b.     In particular, the Respondent had been interrupted while attempting to answer the above question, as evinced by the transcript where he stated (i.e. “Yes. Um—"). On this point, the immediate statement that the Respondent had made after saying “Yes. Um---” was to ask the Complainant’s counsel to repeat her question which related to the alleged hitting of the Child (i.e. “Sorry, can you repeat that again?”). However, in between the two statements, the Complainant’s counsel had asked the Complainant a separate and distinct question (i.e. “That’s why she agreed for [the Child] to be handed over to you pending investigations on 29th Jan, correct?”). In response to the Respondent’s request for the Complainant’s counsel to repeat the question again, the Complainant’s counsel did not repeat the material question (i.e. whether the Mother knew the Respondent had hit the Child) and had only repeated the following “That’s why she even agreed for [the Child] to be handed over to [the Complainant] pending investigations on 29th Jan, correct?”, to which the Respondent then claimed that the Mother had handed the Child to the Complainant because the Complainant was worried.

c.     The above exchange created doubt as to whether the Respondent had understood the import of the Complainant’s counsel’s question clearly, especially when he had requested for the question to be repeated to him and the material question had not been repeated. As such, I could not place much weight on the same to find that this had amounted to an unequivocal admission that the Respondent had hit the Child during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident, particularly when there was no other incident being relied on by the Complainant to suggest that the Respondent had hit the Child and there was a lack of corroborative evidence to support this finding.

d.     For completeness, I also considered that the Respondent had consistently maintained the position in denying that he had ever hit the Child. In particular, the Respondent had maintained from the outset in the ROS that his position was clear in that he had never hit the Child and that the burden was on the Complainant to prove that the Respondent had allegedly “caned” the Child (which the Respondent denied)[note: 24]. Furthermore, I note that when the Complainant’s counsel had put it to the Respondent that the Mother had suspicions that he caused the Child’s injuries and bruises, the Respondent’s response was that this was “incorrect”[note: 25].

e.     Given that the above excerpt of the NE2 (particularly, page 106 of NE2) was the only portion of the relevant NEs relied on by the Complainant’s counsel at paragraph 18 of CS to assert that the Respondent had admitted to hitting the Child, it was difficult to rely on the singular exchange (set out above) to find that the Respondent had clearly admitted to hitting the Child during the Isolated Incident.

41     As such, I could not rely on the above to find that the Complainant had sufficiently proved that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child. The Complainant had also failed to clearly rebut the Respondent’s claims during the trial, given that there was a lack of objective evidence to support the allegation that it was the Respondent who hit the Child, such as when the Respondent had allegedly hit the Child or what the Respondent had allegedly hit the Child with.

Letter of Warning

42     I turn to address the Complainant’s argument that the Respondent had admitted in cross-examination that a letter of warning had been issued to him by the Singapore Police Force (“SPF”) on 8 March 2024.

43     The essence of the Complainant’s argument was that Respondent’s admission that he had been administered a warning by the SPF lends weight to the Complainant’s claim that the Respondent caused the Child’s injuries[note: 26].

44     Having considered the above, while the Respondent had been issued with a letter of warning from the SPF, the Complainant did not show how the letter of warning could be relied upon for the Court to find, on a balance of probabilities, that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child. This is especially since the Court of Appeal had affirmed in the case of Teo Seng Tiong v Public Prosecutor [2021] SGCA 65 at [82] to [88] that stern warnings, whether conditional or not, have no legal effect.

Complainant’s Sister, Complainant’s Mother and Complainant’s Sister’s Boyfriend

45     I then turned to consider the statements made by the Complainant’s family members, as well as the Complainant’s Sister’s Boyfriend.

46     On balance, the statements made by the Complainant’s family members created even more uncertainty as whether the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident.

47     I elaborate on this below.

48     First, the Complainant’s Sister’s statements were not consistent as to how the Respondent had allegedly caused the bruise on the Child. In particular:

a.     The Complainant’s Sister was not present during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident to demonstrate that the Respondent had allegedly hit the Child.

b.     The Complainant’s Sister claimed that the Child had informed her that the Respondent had beat him. The Complainant’s Sister claimed that the Child first told her that the Respondent used a “toy”. However, it seemed that the Child later suggested that the Respondent had used a “line”. These alleged statements made by the Child created confusion as to how the bruise had been allegedly caused by the Respondent (e.g. had the Respondent hit the Child with an alleged “line” or a “toy”?). As such, I could not rely on these purported statements to find that the Complainant had proven, on a balance of probabilities that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child, as there was a lack of certainty on how the bruises developed on the Child.

c.     Critically, there was a lack of objective corroborative evidence provided by the Complainant or the Complainant’s Sister to demonstrate the type of object that was allegedly used by the Respondent to cause the bruise observed on the Child. This is bearing in mind that it is unclear what a “line” or a “toy” referred to. If the Complainant or his sister were claiming that the Respondent had used a cane to hit him, it was unusual as to why a Child would refer to a cane as a “toy”. This has not been clearly explained.

d.     For completeness, I had also considered that the Complainant’s Sister had filed a Police Report No.: L/20240127/7046 (“Police Report”)[note: 27]. However, I could not place much weight on the said Police Report. Of note, the Complainant’s Sister claimed that she had prepared the draft Police Report to be filed but she had held back on making the relevant report while the Complainant was talking to the Mother. In particular, she mentioned that she had submitted the police report upon the Complainant’s instructions. She also stated that the Complainant had “made [her]…submit the draft”[note: 28]. As the Complainant’s Sister’s account in the said report was based on what the Child had allegedly informed her and she was not present during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident, I was unable to attribute much weight to the statements that had been made in the said Police Report.

49     Second, the Complainant’s Mother’s statements were also not consistent. In particular:

a.     I would first set out that the Complainant’s Mother was also not present during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident to demonstrate that the Respondent had allegedly hit the Child. She expressly confirmed on the stand that her evidence was based purely on what the Child had told her whereby she claimed that the Child had said that the Respondent beat him.

b.     In addition, her testimony on the stand as to when she had noticed the bruise on the Child was inconsistent whereby she initially claimed that this was on 26 January 2024, but subsequently claimed that this was on 27January 2024, during cross-examination.

c.     As such, it was also difficult to rely on the Complainant’s Mother’s testimony to find that the Complainant had satisfied the burden of proving, on a balance of probabilities, that it was the Respondent who had committed family violence against the Child.

50     Third, in respect of the Complainant’s Sister’s Boyfriend, I could not place any weight on his testimony as he confirmed on the stand that he was not present when the Complainant’s Mother discovered the bruise on the Child. He also confirmed that he had never seen the Respondent hitting the Child[note: 29].

51     In view of the above, I could place much weight, if at all, on the statements made by the Complainant’s Witnesses, particularly, his relevant family members, bearing in mind that none of them had been present during the alleged material time of the Isolated Incident. Their statements were also largely premised on what they claimed the Child conveyed to them. As demonstrated above, given the Complainant’s concerns on the veracity of the Child’s statements, I could not place much weight, if at all, on the claims the Child had allegedly made to the said Witnesses. For completeness, I also had doubts as to the objectivity of observations or statements made by the Complainant’s family members and the Complainant’s Sister’s Boyfriend against the Respondent due to the high-conflict nature of the present dispute and the acrimony between the parties.

Relevant Doctors

52     The Complainant also called two doctors as witnesses to testify in this matter. The first doctor being Dr S and the second doctor being Dr P.

53     Dr S’s claims are summarised below.

a.     The Complainant highlighted that Dr S testified that bruises on the Child could possibly represent cane marks. Dr S also claimed that based on photos that were taken of the Child’s bruises, the bruises were between 0 to 3 days old[note: 30]. The Complainant used this opinion to highlight that, on 24 to 26 January 2024, the Child was in the Mother’s care, before the Complainant had access to the Child after school on 26 January 2024, and that this pointed to the fact that the injuries could have been inflicted during this period. Specifically, the Complainant relied on Dr S’s testimony to claim that the relevant injuries were inflicted on the Child “on or around 24 January 2024”[note: 31].

b.     When cross-examined on the Child’s bruise, it is noted that Dr S had stated the following[note: 32]:

“[It] is plausible that the bruise could have been caused by hitting something. However, let me state that that in the absence of any tenderness around the wound, it is much more likely that a light object struck him rather than he hit an object with a force of his body. This is because when you hit---well, when a person hits and object with a force of the body, then there is the weight, the mass and therefore, the energy behind that body that tends to cause more swelling and tenderness.”

[Emphasis added.]

54     While Dr S raised the probability that it was likely that the Child’s bruise was caused by a light object that struck him, I could not rely on this claim to find that the Complainant had proved, on a balance of probabilities, that the bruise had been caused by the Respondent. I had to consider Dr S’s statements in the context of the totality of the evidence in the case. I elaborate on my reasons below:

a.     First, Dr S, like the rest of the Witnesses, had not been present during the material time of the Isolated Incident.

b.     Second, there was a lack of contemporaneous evidence to demonstrate what or who had caused the Child’s bruise. Dr S himself had claimed that it was plausible that the Child’s bruise could have been caused by the Child “hitting something”[note: 33]. However, he also further confirmed on the stand that he could not definitively say that the bruise was caused by a cane. As such, where Dr S could not confirm that the bruise observed on the Child was caused by a cane, it was difficult to see how the Complainant could show, on a balance of probabilities, that the Respondent had caned the Child.

c.     Third, as for Dr S’s claim that the bruises were about 0 to 3 days old around 27 January 2024, I was hard pressed to see how the Complainant could argue that this meant that the Respondent had definitively caused the bruises on the Child. It was difficult to see how the Complainant arrived at the assumption that the Respondent had hit the Child on this basis alone, when Dr S could not comment with any certainty on the exact date where the bruises had begun to develop, much less show that the alleged bruise had been caused during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident.

d.     Fourth, Dr S had raised the possibility that the bruises could have been caused by the Child hitting something, and it is noted that the Complainant expressly confirmed that the Child was also at school on 26 January 2024 during the window of the period where Dr S opined the bruise could have been caused (i.e. that the “bruises were between 0 to 3 days old” based on the photos on 27 January 2024[note: 34]). As such, I could not rely on Dr S’s claims to find that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child due to the lack of certainty as to when the bruise was caused and where the bruise had been caused.

e.     Fifth, as the Respondent’s counsel had highlighted, Dr S had also confirmed on the stand during cross-examination that he had relied solely on the information from the Complainant and the Complainant’s Sister in his affidavit and that he had not conducted an independent assessment to verify the claims provided by them[note: 35]. As such, given that Dr S was not present during the material time of the Isolated Incident, coupled with the fact that he had relied on the self-reports made by the Complainant and Complainant’s Sister as part of the basis in which he formed his opinion, I could not rely on these statements to arrive at a finding that it was the Respondent who had allegedly hit the Child during the Isolated Incident.

55     Next, I considered Dr P’s testimony.

56     In particular, Dr P claimed that there was “suspected abuse” in relation to the Child. In this regard, it was difficult for me to place much reliance on Dr P’s testimony to find that the Complainant had sufficiently shown, on a balance of probabilities, that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child, for the following reasons:

a.     First, Dr P was not present during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident.

b.     Second, Dr P had confirmed that she was not the one who had the “suspected” that the Child had been abused[note: 36]. When she was questioned as to why she used the term “suspected abuse” in relation to the Child on 2 March 2024, she claimed that this was based on a referring memo where the reasons and circumstances were described to her by Dr S, as well as what the Complainant and the Complainant’s Sister had described.

c.     Third, insofar as Dr P had relied on Dr S’s description of the circumstances, Dr S had based this on what the Complainant and the Complainant’s Sister had informed him. As mentioned above, the Complainant and the Complainant’s Sister had not been present at the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident. As such, I could not place much weight on Dr P’s testimony to find that the Child had been the subject of “suspected abuse” or that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child.

d.     In sum, it was difficult to rely on Dr P’s statements to find that the Complainant had satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that family violence had been committed by the Respondent against the Child.

57     In view of the above, I could not find that the Complainant had proved, on a balance of probabilities, that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child. As it stands, most of the views and opinions that were expressed by Dr S and Dr P were predominantly based on “self-reports” made by the Complainant and his family members. As such, their views could not be relied upon to prove that family violence had been committed by the Respondent against the Child. As set out above, Dr P admitted that her report was based on Dr S’s description, which was based on self-reporting. Insofar as the doctors relied on the claims of the Complainant and his family members when preparing the reports, it was difficult to rely on the said reports as independent and objective means to verify the Complainant’s claims that the Respondent had allegedly committed family violence against the Child. This is especially since there was a lack of certainty as to the date on which the Child had allegedly been hit. There was also a lack of documentary evidence to show that the Respondent had hit the Child, much less what type of object had been used by the Respondent. For completeness, based on the pictures provided by the Complainant relating to the bruise that had been observed on the Child[note: 37], it was also difficult to rely on such pictures alone to find that it was the Respondent who had hit or caned the Child.

58     Furthermore, even though Dr S had highlighted that the bruises of the Child could represent cane marks, this could not be relied upon alone to find that the Respondent had caused the bruises on the Child, as Dr S had also raised the plausibility that the bruises could have been caused by the Child hitting something.

Teacher

59     This leads me to the Teacher’s account, whereby the Teacher conveyed that the Child said to her that the Respondent had beat him. I could not accord much weight to the Teacher’s statements as the Teacher did not witness the alleged Isolated Incident. Moreover, the Teacher raised further possibilities on how the Child could have developed the bruise:

a.     First, the Teacher highlighted the possibility that the Child could have sustained the relevant bruise in school. In particular, when the Teacher was asked during cross-examination whether it was common for young boys of the Child’s age to hit things and injure themselves, she claimed that “it also happens” and that she “couldn’t say that it’s not a possibility that [it happened] in school”[note: 38]. The Teacher’s statement during cross-examination was also consistent with her statement in her affidavit that she “could not rule out the possibility that the [Child’s] injury was sustained in school”.

b.     Second, while the Teacher stated in her affidavit that she was “more inclined towards believing the [Child’s] version of events”, I could not place much weight on her opinion as the Teacher was not present during the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident and she did not show why the Child’s version of the events should be relied on to arrive at a finding that the Respondent had hit the Child during the alleged Isolated Incident. This is also bearing in mind that the Complainant had raised doubts as to the veracity of the statements that the Child had made.

c.     In view of the above, I could not rely on the Teacher’s Statement to find that the Complainant had satisfied the legal burden of proving, on a balance of probabilities that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child. This is also in consideration that the Teacher had raised the alternative possibility that the Child’s injury could have occurred at school, coupled with the fact that Dr S had also raised the plausibility that the bruises could have been caused by the Child hitting something.

60     Having considered the testimonies and evidence of the Complainant and the Witnesses, I could not find that the Complainant had proved that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child, on a balance of probabilities.

Likelihood

61     It remains for me to consider whether there is any likelihood of family violence being committed against the Child by the Respondent. After considering the allegations raised by the Complainant in the Complaint Form and in C1, I was unable to find that the Complainant had proven, on a balance of probabilities, that family violence had been committed against the Child or that family violence was likely to be committed against the Child.

62     Prior to the Isolated Incident, it is noted that when the Complainant was questioned on whether the Child had ever said that the Respondent had hit him between December 2022 to January 2024, the Complainant said that there was no incident he could remember[note: 39]. For completeness, I also considered his claim that, prior to the material time of the alleged Isolated Incident, the Complainant and the Mother had a largely harmonious co-parenting relationship[note: 40].

63     As there was a lack of evidence that the Respondent had hit the Child or that he had a propensity to commit family violence, I could not find that the Complainant had proven, on a balance of probabilities, that family violence would likely be committed by the Respondent against the Child, particularly under Limb A and/or Limb B.

Issue 2: Necessity

64     As the Complainant had not satisfied the legal burden of proving that family violence had been committed or was likely to be committed against the Child, it would follow that a PPO would not be necessary in this case. In any event, it would have been difficult to arrive at a finding that a PPO was necessary in this case for the following reasons:

a.     First, during the 1st and 2nd Hearings, it was not disputed that the Child continued to stay with the Mother and Respondent at the Mother’s residence. It is also observed that there were also other family members present at the residence, particularly, the Child’s maternal grandparents who also lived with him. The Complainant had not clearly established that the Mother or the Child’s maternal grandparents could not be relied upon to ensure that the Child was safe. For completeness, I note that the Complainant also continued to have access to the Child.

b.     Second, apart from the lack of evidence adduced by the Complainant to prove that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child, it must be stressed that the Complainant’s allegations related to a single instance where the bruises had been spotted on the Child to form the basis of his complaint in the Complaint Form. As stated above, when the Complainant was questioned during cross-examination on whether he had seen the Respondent hit the Child, the Complainant’s response was “no”. When the Complainant was questioned during cross-examination on whether he had ever seen the Respondent hit the Child, the Complainant’s response was “no”[note: 41]. As such, there was a lack of evidence to suggest that a PPO was necessary to restrain the Respondent from committing family violence in the future against the Child, when the Complainant had not witnessed the Respondent hit the Child and in view of the lack of evidence to corroborate the finding that the Respondent had committed family violence against the Child.

Conclusion

65     In the circumstances, I was unable to grant the Complainant’s application in SS 201.

66     On the issue of costs, the Respondent’s counsel submitted that the sum of $25,000 should be ordered in favour of the Respondent. Broadly speaking, she submitted that there were several witnesses on the Complainant’s end who had mostly filed substantive affidavits with transcripts and recordings. In addition, she highlighted that there were supplementary affidavits filed on the first day of the trial, whereby the trial had to be heard in two tranches, with opening statements and written closing submissions that had been submitted.

67     In brief, the Complainant’s counsel submitted that costs of $7,000 would be more appropriate in the present case where the trial was over two days and there were co-parenting issues between the parties. The Complainant’s counsel also asked that the Complainant be allowed to pay any such costs over the course of six months due to his cash flow issues.

68     Given that the Complainant had not succeeded in his application, the Respondent would ordinarily be entitled to costs.

69     Having considered the submissions of both parties, the number of affidavits filed, the fact that further affidavits were produced by the Complainant during the 1st Hearing, the fact that a reply affidavit had to further be directed on the Respondent’s part, the written submissions, the relevant opening statements, the number of authorities filed by both parties, as well as the number of witnesses and court attendances for SS 201, the Complainant was ordered to pay costs of $12,000 (all-in), in monthly instalments of $2,000 over the course of six months commencing from 23 January 2025.

70     Going forward, the reality is that the parties would need to continue to journey together in co-parenting the Child. I observe that the Child is deeply loved by his family and has a strong eco-system, with a caring immediate and extended family (e.g. his grandparents, aunts, etc.). I strongly encourage parties to draw on their love for the Child to work on showing kindness and grace to each other for the sake of the Child’s well-being.

71     It is my sincere hope that the harmonious co-parenting relationship that the Complainant had claimed he shared with the Mother will be restored. It is difficult for children to be caught in the middle of parental conflicts, and I would encourage all parties to explore counselling on how to communicate and co-parent in the best interests of the Child.
