XLH v XLI

XLH v XLI
[2025] SGFC 43

Case Number:Divorce Suit No. 5772 of 2023, (Summons No. 587 of 2024)
Decision Date:16 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kevin Ho
Counsel Name(s): Ms Teh Guek Ngor Engelin, SC and Ms Tan Xin Er, Sylvie (Chen Xin'er) (Engelin Teh Practice LLC) for the Plaintiff; Mr See Chern Yan (instructed) (Drew & Napier LLC), Ms Shiao Hong Ho and Mr Choo Yik-Hean Bryan (Quahe Woo & Palmer LLC) for the Defendant.
Parties: XLH — XLI

Family law – Custody – Access to Children

16 April 2025

District Judge Kevin Ho:

Background and Procedural Posture

1       In the present application, ie. FC/SUM 587/2024 (“SUM 587”), the defendant-father (“Father”), seeks inter alia the following orders:

(a)     that he be granted regular weekly access to the parties’ 2 children, [M] and [E] (collectively, the “Children”) from Thursdays 5.00pm to Sundays, 9.00am;

(b)     that he be granted access to the Children for half of their mid-year and end-year holidays; and

(c)     various other orders relating to public holiday access and overseas travel arrangements for the Children.

2       In essence, the Father’s case is that he should be entitled to 50% (or an equal “split”) of the Children’s time. That broadly reflects what he is seeking through SUM 587. His counsel submits that even as early as October 2023 (before divorce proceedings were actually commenced), both parents had an understanding that they should have equal time with the Children, and that there were no safety and/or other concerns which justifies any deviation from this understanding.[note: 1]

3       The Plaintiff-mother (“Mother”) challenges the Father’s application. The Mother’s position is that she is already providing access to the Father and that these arrangements should continue.[note: 2] The Mother – through her counsel – argues that the current arrangement already reflects, broadly, a 50/50 split of the Children’s available time.

4       To complete the picture of the applicable procedural posture, SUM 587 is an interlocutory application filed in FC/D 5772/2023, which are the ongoing divorce proceedings between the same parties. These divorce proceedings remain pending as both parties having filed a claim and a counterclaim praying for a divorce to be granted.

5       Given the various allegations raised by the parties, including the Mother’s concerns with possible use of illicit drugs and the Father’s ability to care for the Children, I found it useful for a Custody/Access Evaluation Report (“Report”) to be prepared by the appointed agency to assist the Court in making the determination on the appropriate access arrangements for the Children. I therefore gave the relevant directions at the first hearing of SUM 587 in October 2024.

6       For the interim period (pending the final disposal of SUM 587), I also made various orders on 9 October 2024 to provide for a more structured and clear access plan for the Father so that both parties and the Children are clear as to when they would see the Father.

7       The Report has since been prepared in February 2025 and I have considered its contents in deciding the appropriate access arrangements to be made in SUM 587. I delivered my brief decision, in writing, to the parties in March 2025, pursuant to r. 670 of the Family Justice Rules 2014.

8       I set out my grounds of decision below.

Preliminary Observations

9       Before I address the substantive orders which I made in the present case, I find it necessary to make several observations as to how the parties (and their counsel) have conducted this matter.

10     Arising from the differences in perspectives between the parents, both parties’ arguments and submissions descended into rather technical (and often unnecessary) disputes. These arguments tended to obfuscate more than they illuminate.

11     For example, the parties argued over whether they had in fact adhered to the alleged understanding where the Father would be given an equal split of the Children’s time. The Father says that he should be given half of all available time whereas the Mother believes that only the Children’s “free” time (which excludes the Children’s “down-time”, activity time, etc.) should be divided.[note: 3]

12     In my view, these arguments are unduly technical and borders on inane. Arguing over whether extra-curricular or activity time should be included misses the larger point which is that the purpose of access time is to enable the access (or visiting) parent to build a bond and establish a relationship with his or her child.

13     Thus, fighting over whether which parent should have parenting time during the hours when a school-going child is in school (or engaged in school activities) may well be a fight over who should be standing outside a school or classroom to await their dismissal. It is an unnecessary, and ultimately pointless, fight. On the other hand, if one becomes overly prescriptive, attempting to carve out every possible “activity” time (or impose requirements as to when and where a child should eat, sleep or play) to incorporate as part of an access order, the ensuing order becomes one where the Court would be effectively carving a child’s life up into blocks of hours and minutes. Such an overly prescriptive access order (which is an enforceable and binding court order) unduly restricts both the parents’ and the children’s lives. It also misses the forest for the trees as the true purpose of an access order is to allow one parent to maintain regular contact with the Children: see BG v BF [2007] 3 SLR(R) 233 at [11].

14     Ultimately, it is incumbent on the parents – being the adults – to act in a practical, sensible and fair manner to ensure that the Children spend sufficient time with both of them and to allow the Children to enjoy the love and attention which both parents want to give.

15     This leads me to the next, and equally important point – the law places an expectation that each parent endeavour to be the bigger and kinder parent for their child. This, as the High Court (Family Division) in VDX v VDY [2021] SGHCF 2 (at [42]) had observed, means that parents:

should strive hard not to mire the family, including the children, in litigation, nor should their resources and the court’s resources be spent on litigation to deal with an emotionally-driven conflict. This will involve some measure of compromise; it may involve being bigger, wiser and kinder – which must be difficult when relationship have broken down, yet this is the legal responsibility placed on all parents.

16     In the present case, it was apparent from the parties’ affidavits and submissions that there are serious trust issues between both parents. This, however, should not be a reason for them to engage in arguments which appeals to emotions rather than facts.

17     To illustrate, the Mother advanced arguments about the alleged danger which the Father might pose to the Children. While some concerns may arise from her genuinely held beliefs, many were wholly speculative.

18     For example, unfortunate arguments revolving the possible use of firearms and/or exposure to gun violence were made by the Mother, through her counsel. The picture which counsel sought to paint was one where the Father is a dangerous gun owner in the United States of America (“US”) – where he grew up with his adoptive family – and that he poses a security risk to the Children given the prevalence of gun-related violence or the accidental discharge of firearms in the US.

19     Indeed, during oral submissions, the Father was alleged to have engaged in some form of linguistic sophistry when he stated in his affidavit that “[he does] not currently own and/or possess any guns in the US”.[note: 4] The Court was then urged to interpret his statement as a tacit acknowledgment that he may own firearms “elsewhere” in the world.

20     Respectfully, these claims were largely hyperbole and not based on any actual, tangible or even admissible evidence. The Mother did not provide any proof of the Father’s alleged gun ownership. Moreover, I accept the Defendant’s counsel’s submission that to “investigate” into the matter would be to pit father against daughter as the Mother’s entire basis for raising this alleged concern arose from what were clearly hearsay statements allegedly made by 7-year-old [M] in passing.[note: 5]

21     That is not conducive to effective co-parenting nor is that reflective of a Therapeutic Justice (“TJ”) mindset.

22     Another example relates to the Father’s alleged consumption of drug substances in the US (where the Father submits is a lawful act). Once again, the Mother attempted to paint the Father as a substance abuser who may put the Children at risk. Yet, there is no tangible evidence that the Father consumed illicit drugs in the Children’s presence.

23     These allegations led to various exchanges between counsel, during the hearing of SUM 587, on politically sensitive (and divisive) issues such as gun ownership, drug abuse and the apparent clash of Western and Asian cultures or values. These exchanges similarly shed little light on the actual issue at hand, viz. what should be the appropriate access orders in this case for this family now that the Children are living in Singapore (a place where neither guns nor recreational drugs are allowed).

24     As the parties continue along their journey through their ongoing divorce proceedings, I encourage both of them and their counsel to avoid making broad or sweeping allegations against one another. The High Court (Family Division) in VYB v VYA [2022] 4 SLR 1181 (at [26] – [28]) reminds us that an adversarial approach (instead of a problem-solving one) undermines TJ, and that a TJ system “involves parties making what they may perceive to be ‘sacrifices’ – letting go of what has hurt them deeply, refraining from doing ‘inflammatory’ acts against the other party, compromising by giving in and co-operating with the other party in some issues, taking responsibility where required and finding the will to recast the future.”

25     Speaking extra-judicially, Justice Teh Hwee Hwee (in delivering Her Honour’s keynote address and CJ Koh Lecture 2024 at the Family Conference 2024) noted that TJ has been explicitly adopted by the Singapore courts and that “[o]ur family justice system aims to help parties and their children heal, enabling them to move forward with their lives despite the breakdown of the marital relationship. It is a non-adversarial, problem-solving system that allows time for grieving and supports healing, restoration, and the recasting of a positive future. [Emphasis added]”

26     More recently, the Family Justice Courts (“FJC”) have launched the Family Justice Courts Therapeutic Justice Model (“TJ Model”) in October 2024. The TJ Model, read in conjunction with the FJC’s Practice Directions 2024, requires parties to court proceedings (and their lawyers) to conduct themselves in a manner that is consistent with the principles set out therein.

27     Part 3 of the TJ Model reminds parties that they “play a central role in the TJ Model. They are to take ownership of the family’s issues and cooperate with each other to find timely and enduring solutions to these issues. Particularly where children are involved, they are to prioritise the welfare of the children above their own and focus on parties’ shared interests and future. This involves being willing to compromise in the spirit of give and take and carrying out agreed or ordered arrangements with a cooperative spirit”.[note: 6]

28     Parties are therefore expected to “[a]dopt a cooperative and constructive approach to find timely and enduring solutions; and resolve disputes as amicably as possible” and “[u]se respectful and constructive language in correspondence, court documents and courtroom communications”.[note: 7]

29     These principles should be borne in the parties’ minds as they navigate their divorce and, more importantly, when implementing the access orders made by the Court in the present application, or in the eventual ancillary matters orders.

Decision

30     I now move on to the substantive issue – ie. what access orders should be made in the present case.

31     It is trite law that when making orders in respect of the custody or the upbringing of children, the Court’s first and paramount consideration is that of the children’s welfare. That is clearly set out in s 125(1) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed).[note: 8] The Court of Appeal in BNS v BNT [2015] 3 SLR 373 (at [19]) emphasised that this principle ought to override any other consideration.

32     When considering what is in a child’s welfare (which ought to be understood in the widest sense),[note: 9] regard may be had to the various factors including inter alia, the need for stability, continuity of living arrangements, the need for both parents’ to be involved in a child’s life, the maternal bond, and the desirability of keeping siblings together: see ABW v ABV [2014] 2 SLR 769 (at [20] – [23]).

33     I wish to make two more observations in relation to the present case.

34     First, SUM 587 is framed as an application for access orders only and thus it is not necessary for the Court to make orders for the Children’s care and control. That said, it is clear that the Mother currently has de facto care and control of the Children. This is a state of affairs which I find to be appropriate for the Children at present, and nothing in my order should be taken as changing this position.

35     Second, a significant part of the Father’s case rests on the existence of an alleged Contact Time Agreement (or “CTA”) where parties had “entered” into in or around 19 October 2023.[note: 10] The Father submits that this CTA grants him the unequivocal right to have an equal split of the Children’s total time, which the Mother disagrees with, thus giving rise to the dispute referred to at [10] above.

36     While the CTA may be relevant as an expression of one or both parties’ broad intent on the issue of custody and access, it is by no means determinative or dispositive. Section 129 of the WC expressly states that:

Power of court to vary agreement for custody, etc.

129.  The court may, at any time and from time to time, vary the terms of any agreement relating to the custody, or the care and control, of a child, regardless when the agreement was made, despite any provision to the contrary in that agreement, where it is satisfied that it is reasonable and for the welfare of the child to do so.

The purport of this provision is clear – while parents may agree to how a child should be cared for, it is the child’s welfare which should be paramount. Where the terms of the agreement may no longer be suitable, the Court retains the discretion to make the appropriate orders.

37     Moreover, insofar as the Father seeks to argue that the CTA is clear with regard to how the Children’s access time should be apportioned between both parents, I do not agree with his submission. In my view, the CTA – which was, in truth, an exchange of text messages between the parents about the impending divorce – was less of a definitive agreement but a generalised idea of what the Father wanted if the Mother proceeds with divorce proceedings, to which the Mother broadly acknowledged.[note: 11]

38     Ultimately, the Court must have regard to the overall circumstances of the case when deciding the appropriate access orders for the Children, and that includes the contents of the Report which was prepared (and which I found to be highly relevant).

39     As the Court of Appeal had observed in WKM v WKN [2024] 1 SLR 158 (“WKM”) at [74]: “[i]n the process of generating their reports, the professionals would have engaged directly with the relevant persons involved in the child’s life and observed some of their interactions with the child. Their observations serve as crucial insights into the child’s world and greatly assist the court by presenting the realities of the child’s situation. Given their expertise, they are well suited to identify issues, such as excessive gatekeeping behaviour by the parents and even possible signs of abuse…[Emphasis added]”.

40     In the present case, the evaluator had the opportunity to speak with the [M]’s primary school teacher, [M]’s psychologist, and [E]’s preschool principal as well as both parents and the Children. These interactions provided invaluable insights which were immensely relevant and helpful to the Court’s determination of the disputed access issues.

41     The evaluator’s observations are consistent with my findings on the evidence presented to the Court through the parties’ affidavits, including inter alia that:

(a)     The Mother has been the children’s primary caregiver and can continue in this role with the support network she has in Singapore.[note: 12] She continues to be the Children’s care parent.

(b)     Although the Father’s private life (including concerns about possible recreational drug use overseas) may have form a central aspect of the Mother’s worries,[note: 13] I do not find that his private life has affected his ability to provide care for the Children in Singapore. For example, the Mother has not provided any evidence that the Father had engaged in recreational drug use which rendered him in a stupefied state or have caused him to act in a manner which rendered him a danger to the Children.

(c)     Both Children are bright, intelligent, and are performing well in school. Both siblings share a close bond and relationship, and I find it desirable and important that both sister and brother continue to provide support for each other, wherever possible, including when they are with the Father during his access period.

(d)     I also find that the Children share a good relationship with both parents despite the trying time for the family, and that this is heartening. Efforts should continue to be made to ensure that the Children’s relationship with both parents remain strong post-divorce.

42     With these broad observations and findings in mind, I set out below my specific orders:

Pending the full and final disposal of ancillary matters in respect of FC/D 5772/2023 (including any appeals in relation thereto), the Defendant shall have access to the Children as follows:

School Term Access

(a)     During [M]’s school term, the Defendant shall have access every Thursday, from 5.30pm to 8.30pm.

(b)     The Defendant shall have overnight access as follows:

(i)     For the 1st and 3rd week of every month, the Defendant shall have overnight access from Friday, 5.30pm to Saturday 6pm;

(ii)    For the 2nd and 4th week of every month, the Defendant shall have overnight access from Friday, 5.30pm to Sunday 10am.

School Holiday Access

(c)     During [M]’s primary school holiday period in March and September each year, the Defendant shall have access to the Children:

(i)     for the second half of the holiday period from 12 noon on Thursday to 6pm on Saturday for the school holiday in March; and

(ii)    for the first half of the school holiday period from 6 pm on Saturday to 12 noon on Thursday for the school holiday in September.

(d)     For [M]’s June and December school holidays, the Defendant shall have access to both the Children for the first half of school holidays on odd numbered years (eg. 2025, 2027, 2029) and the second half of the school holidays on even numbered years (eg. 2026, 2028, etc.) (“Holiday Access Period”).

(e)     During the Holiday Access Period:

(i)     the Defendant shall have overnight access from 9am every Thursday to 9am on Sunday; and

(ii)    regular (non-overnight access) on Mondays to Wednesdays, from 9am to 7.30pm.

(iii)    The Defendant shall not bring the Children overseas during the Holiday Access Period unless the Plaintiff consents to the said travel arrangements, or by Order of Court.

Public Holiday Access

(f)     The Defendant shall have access to the Children on gazetted public holidays or special holidays/events as follows:

(i)     For the holiday known as “Thanksgiving” celebrated in the United States of America, the Defendant shall have access to the Children from 9am to 7pm on the eve, and actual day, of the Thanksgiving holiday with the Defendant.

(ii)    For the Chinese New Year (“CNY”) holiday period (as celebrated in Singapore), the Children would spend the eve and CNY Day 1 with the Plaintiff.

(iii)    The Defendant shall have access to the Children from 9am to 7.30pm on :

(A)     Christmas eve every odd-numbered year (eg. 2025, 2027, 2029); and

(B)     Christmas day on even-numbered years (eg. 2026, 2028, etc.).

(iv)    Save as set out above, the Defendant shall have access to the Children on alternate gazetted public holidays from 9 am to 7.30pm. To avoid doubt, where a public holiday falls on a non-working day and the following working day is gazetted as being the public holiday date in lieu thereof, the Defendant’s public holiday access refers to the second mentioned date.

Other Orders

(g)     In respect of all of the Defendant’s access period set out above, the Defendant shall be responsible for picking up the Children from, and sending them home to, the Plaintiff’s residence at the beginning and/or end of the access period, save that where the Defendant’s access period starts at a time where the Children are in school or attending to after-school activities, he is at liberty to pick them up from school or class (as the case may be) directly.

(h)     The Defendant shall bring the Children to any school-related, co- and/or extra-curricular activities should they fall within his access period.

(i)     The Plaintiff shall take steps to facilitate the Defendant's aforesaid access and shall not arrange for the Children to enrol or participate in any non-school mandated extra-curricular activities which would take place during the Defendant's Holiday Access Period, without the Defendant's agreement or consent.

(j)     The Plaintiff shall not arrange any overseas travel with the Children which would fall within any of the Defendant's access period.

(k)     There shall be no make-up access if the Defendant chooses to forgo any of his overnight access to the Children.

(l)      The parties are at liberty to vary the aforesaid arrangement by mutual consent, such variation to be recorded in writing.

(m)     Liberty to apply.

43     As the above orders are made in the context of an interim access application filed in pending divorce proceedings,[note: 14] I have prefaced my orders as being applicable until the full and final disposal of the pending divorce proceedings. This is important and serves as a signal to the parties that the conversation over what would be the best access arrangements for the Children and the Father does not end with these orders. Instead, the parties should continue to discuss these matters as co-parents using these orders as a catalyst. It is also for this reason that I have provided a mechanism for the parties to adjust or change these arrangements by mutual consent.

44     For now, I have provided that there shall be no overseas travel with the Children during the Father’s access time. To be clear, and as set out above,[note: 15] I make this order not because I find the Father to be a security threat to the Children.

45     Rather, save for a single trip to the US with [M] a few years ago, the evidence suggests that the Father has not travelled with the Children alone. As I have found it in the Children’s best interests for both sister and brother to be together during access (where possible), extended periods of overseas travel with both Children should be a matter which both parents should continue to discuss and consider as they move on with the present proceedings.

46     I should add that any such further travel arrangements should take into account the Children’s readiness for extended travel and the Father’s plans as to how care would be provided to them. In so doing, the views of [M] and/or her psychologist should also be considered, where appropriate.

47     As for the regular access arrangements, in making these orders, I have – where possible provided the Father with a significant amount access time to provide the Children ample opportunity to bond with their father. I have also considered what both parents had informed the evaluator as being their proposed access plans, including weekly and public holiday access hours.

48     In some cases, such as the Children’s school holidays and public holidays, I have provided for the Father to have about half of the relevant access period (in terms of calendar days or months). This is not because I am enforcing the terms of the so-called CTA (as put forward by the Father and his counsel) nor is a 50/50 split some default position used by the Court. Rather, it is a recognition that where the Children’s time and schedule permits, it is in their interest to spend quality time with him.

49     I wish to reinforce one point – just as I had reminded the Mother not to descend into the minutiae of the Children’s schedule or the allocation of their “free time”, the Father should not be overly fixated with there being some form of overarching concept of “fairness” mandating a 50/50 split in the Children’s time.

50     In his counsel’s written submissions, the Father seeks to highlight how the Mother had sought to “commoditised” the Children’s time by requiring make-up time, or extra hours with the Children as something to be traded and/or negotiated.[note: 16] However, splitting the Children’s time and/or schedule mechanistically to achieve an “equal” division will invariably result in the same commoditisation of the Children’s lives.

51     I thus encourage the Father to use the access time he has with the Children (which is generous) in a manner which builds their relationship through father-child activities and interactions. As I had noted above, there is no real purpose of having an allocated “access” time where the parent is merely engaged in passive acts, such as waiting. The focus should be on quality, not quantity.

52     In a similar vein, I note that both [E] and [M] have additional classes and activities over their regular school curriculum. These may sometimes affect how much quality time each parent has, and an overly mechanistic allocation may affect the Children. For example, the Children’s Chinese and/or tennis class schedule have resulted in some challenges with the Father’s pick-up and return schedules. These are matters which the Mother should look into to ascertain what would be the most practical way to allow the Children more quality time with the Father while not overburdening their rest time. However, I will not be making orders to prescribe a certain schedule. These are parenting matters best left to the parents to work together and resolve.

Conclusion

53     In the circumstances, I will not be ordering any change to the Children’s current de facto care arrangements, and have provided for a more comprehensive interim access arrangement for the Father to see the Children while the divorce proceedings are underway.

54     To support the parties’ healing and to assist them to navigate their journey to co-parent the Children, I encourage them to continue to see their psychologist, Ms [S], to work on their mutual co-parenting skills and support.

55     After considering the parties’ costs submissions, I made no order as to costs.

html:
XII v XIJ

XII v XIJ
[2025] SGFC 40

Case Number:OSG 60/2023 (FC/SUM 3128/2023)
Decision Date:08 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Chia Wee Kiat
Counsel Name(s): Ms Poonam Mirchandani and Mr Ashok Chugani (Mirchandani and Partners) for the plaintiff; Mr Ivan Cheong, Mr Shaun Ho and Ms Imogen Harvey (Withers KhattarWong LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XII — XIJ

Family Law – Children – Care and control

Family Law – Children – Relocation

8 April 2025

District Judge Chia Wee Kiat:

1       The Plaintiff shall be referred to as the “Mother” and the Defendant shall be referred to as the “Father”.

2       The Mother is an Australian citizen[note: 1] and a Certified Practicing Accountant.[note: 2] She last worked as Group Financial Controller in Brisbane, Australia.[note: 3] The Father is a UK citizen[note: 4] and a practising lawyer.[note: 5] He is a senior associate with a law firm in Singapore.[note: 6]

3       The parties were married on 22 September 2014.[note: 7] They have two boys, the older child being 10 years old while the second child will turn 9 in November this year. The children are Australian and British citizens.[note: 8]

4       In May 2017, the family relocated to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia (“KL”).[note: 9] The Mother said that the Father had assured her that the move would be short term, for 2 years and no longer than 3 years, and then the Father would move back to Australia as an established partner in his law firm, in time for the older child to start school in Australia at 5 years old.[note: 10]

5       The Mother was unhappy living in KL. She said that she was wholly dependent on the Father for finances which he controlled tightly.[note: 11] On some occasions, the Father would reduce the Mother to tears when he rebuked her for not contributing financially.[note: 12] When the Mother told the Father that she wanted to return to Brisbane, the Father responded that he had started a new office and needed 3 to 4 years before he could leave for Brisbane.[note: 13] By early 2018, the Mother’s resentment in the marriage grew even more.[note: 14] The Mother felt alone, deserted and sad and had to make appointments to see a therapist in KL.[note: 15]

6       In around July 2020, the Father informed the Mother that his career required him to move from KL to Singapore as he was taking on a lead role in Asia and Singapore was the base for this role. The Father said that he needed to commit just 2 years to being in Singapore.[note: 16]

7       The Mother was reluctant to move to Singapore. She said that she had reminded the Father of the promises he had made for the family’s return to Brisbane but he ignored her and asked her to make a choice between the family moving to Singapore for 2 years and then heading home to Australia or to continue remaining in KL for another 4 years or more.[note: 17] Given the lack of options and with no money to litigate in KL[note: 18], moving to Singapore was a Hobson’s choice.[note: 19]

8       The family relocated from KL to Singapore on 30 July 2021.[note: 20] The children were enrolled in an international school since their arrival in Singapore.[note: 21] Except for the first 7 days where they stayed together in a serviced apartment, the parties lived separate residence[note: 22] as their relationship had broken down by this time.

9       On 6 April 2023, the Father commenced parenting and financial proceedings in Australia.[note: 23]

10     On 11 May 2023, the Mother filed FC/OSG 60/2023, seeking to be granted care and control of the children and leave to relocate the children to Brisbane.[note: 24]

11     On 22 August 2023, the parties recorded a consent order in the Australian proceedings for the Father to pay the Mother the sum of S$11,500 per month for spousal and child maintenance.[note: 25]

12     The Mother said that her life in Singapore was miserable as the Father had robbed her of her fulltime care of the children.[note: 26] The parties had a shared care arrangement[note: 27] which was a product of the Father’s intense bullying of the Mother into agreeing to his demands for equal time with the children.[note: 28] Not satisfied with the care arrangement he wanted, the Father continued with further litigation threats if she did not accept his financial settlement proposals.[note: 29]

13     The Mother said that she had been out of work for 8.5 years and it was crucial that she had the freedom to make her own choices.[note: 30] It was in the children’s paramount interests to return home to Brisbane and not continue to miss out more years than they already had by living transient lives in other jurisdictions.[note: 31] The Mother needed to continue to rebuild her relations with her father and the children needed to build on their relationships with their cousins and extended family.[note: 32]

14     The Mother planned to return to their family home in Bulimba and enrol the children in the Bulimba State School. While having a helper was not possible in Australia, there was the option of having Au Pairs for short periods. The Mother’s brother and partner were close by, along with her father who lived a 7-hour drive away. The Mother did not plan on taking a job that required any overtime or travels. With the availability of out-of-school-care and flexible hours, the Mother planned to rely on such care only as and when necessary. The children would have access to both public and private health care systems.[note: 33]

15     The Father objected to the Mother’s application for relocation.[note: 34] On 10 October 2023, he filed a cross-application vide FC/SUM 3128/2023 to be granted shared care and control of the children.[note: 35]

16     The Father said that the move to Singapore was mutually agreed between the parties at a time when they had already separated.[note: 36] The move was to take advantage of the better quality of life in Singapore and to create better job prospects for the Mother.[note: 37] The Father’s intentions were to continue to grow his practice and generate financial security for the family, before further plans were discussed.[note: 38]

17     The Father said that the Mother had, throughout her life, moved from jurisdiction to jurisdiction without staying too long in each location.[note: 39] The Mother was well-settled and enjoyed her time in Singapore. She spent her free time in Singapore deeply engaged in her rowing club and was part of the club’s management committee,[note: 40] and also went mountain biking and hiking with friends, and regularly attended expat get-togethers.[note: 41]

18     The Father said that the Mother had nothing to complain about as far as her living expenses in Singapore were concerned. He had agreed to pay the Mother a monthly sum of S$11,500 which had been recorded as an order of court by consent in the Australian proceedings.[note: 42] The Mother had comprehensive medical insurance that was paid for by him[note: 43] and had moved into a luxurious landed property in the Holland Village area.[note: 44] The Mother also drove a vehicle.[note: 45]

19     The Father disputed that the shared care arrangement was forced on the Mother.[note: 46] The Father said that he had been attentive to the children’s care throughout their lives[note: 47] and was capable of meeting the children’s needs.[note: 48] The Father did not dispute that the Mother was also a competent caregiver,[note: 49] but her mentality appeared to be that the children were primarily hers, and that she had greater rights over the children[note: 50] and should have control over them.[note: 51] While the Father had been facilitating the children’s relationship with the Mother,[note: 52] the Mother was lukewarm when facilitating the Father’s time with the children and showed an aversion to facilitating the children’s relationship with their paternal grandmother.[note: 53] Ever since the proceedings started, the Mother had shown that she was prioritizing the proceedings, instead of properly focusing on the children’s well-being.[note: 54]

20     The Father said that the children were thriving in the shared care and control arrangement[note: 55] and there was nothing to suggest that the children would stand to gain from a change in the arrangement.[note: 56] The Mother had not given any good reason why the status quo should be disturbed[note: 57] and why the Father’s time with the children should be reduced.[note: 58]

21     The Father disagreed with the Mother’s characterization of Brisbane as the children’s home. The Father said that the children were international in outlook[note: 59] and had stayed in Brisbane for a much shorter time than they had resided elsewhere in the world.[note: 60] They had sunk roots in Singapore, and were happy[note: 61] and thriving in school.[note: 62] The children received excellent healthcare in Singapore, with medical costs for the children being fully covered by his employer’s health insurance plan.[note: 63] The Father also paid directly for the children’s major expenses, including school fees, dental fees, extra-curricular and enrichment activities.[note: 64] The Father believed that the Mother wanted to relocate because she was bored of living in Singapore.[note: 65]

22     On 15 February 2024, the Mother commenced divorce proceedings in Australia.[note: 66] The Father did not oppose the divorce.[note: 67]

23     The Mother’s relocation application and the Father’s cross-application first came up for hearing on 22 March 2024. The hearing was adjourned to 6 May 2024 at parties’ request to file a limited reply affidavit each.

24     At the substantive hearing, counsel took pains to take the court through voluminous affidavits and written submissions, with Ms Mirchandani and Mr Chugani taking turns to make lengthy oral submissions for the Mother. After I called for a Custody Evaluation Report (“CER”) and reserved my decision on 17 July 2024, I received several letters from counsel that contained new evidence and arguments. As this was done without the leave of the court, I placed no weight on the contents of the letters in reaching my decision. It is important for counsel to bear in mind the observations of the courts in VYP v VYQ [2021] SGHCF 40 (at [36]) and VEW v VEV [2022] SGCA 34 (at [9]) on the proper conduct of proceedings.

25     That said, I noted from M/s Mirchandani & Partners’ letter dated 4 December 2024 that the Mother’s application for a Long-Term Visit Pass (“LTVP”) had been rejected by the Immigration and Checkpoint Authority (“ICA”). As this was a development that could materially affect the care arrangement for the children, I directed the CER dated 2 December 2024 to be updated so that the evidence could be properly received and considered. As noted by the Court of Appeal in Soon Peck Wah v Woon Che Chye [1997] 3 SLR(R) 430 (at [36]) and reiterated in WKM v WKN [2024] 1 SLR 158 (at [73]), welfare reports are admissible even if they may contain a certain amount of hearsay. Having received the updated CER on 30 December 2024, I rendered my decision on 24 January 2025.

26     Although parties had made submissions on care and control before relocation, I was of the view that the primary issue that had to be decided first was relocation. In my brief grounds, I referred parties to XBF v XBE [2024] SGHCF 42 where Choo Han Teck J noted (at [6]) as follows:

This case is not as straightforward as it appears. The finding that the Respondent was the primary caregiver is challenged, not without grounds, by the Appellant. The DJ, however, conflated the idea that a relocation order follows care and control because it is in the best interests of the children to be with the primary caregiver. In many cases, that might be correct, but this is not such a case. The primary issue in this case is the relocation of the children, not which parent should be granted care and control. The two issues must be examined together. It cannot be assumed, as the court below did, that relocation follows the issue of care and control. The court should consider whether it is in the best interests for the children to be relocated to Indonesia, and the question of care and control can be determined as part of that inquiry. The best interests of the children may overlap with the best interests of the mother, but they are not the same.

27     Likewise, in VPG v VPF [2021] SGHCF 18 which concerned cross-appeals involving the care and control and relocation of the parties’ 3-year old child, Debbie Ong J (as she then was) noted (at [4]) as follows:

I begin with the appeal of the Father in which he sought sole care and control of [G] and for leave to have [G] relocate to India with him. If the appeal against the DJ’s decision refusing relocation is allowed, then the other decisions on shared care and holding of the child’s legal documents will be affected and must be dealt with in that context.

28     Taking guidance from these cases, I decided that it would be more appropriate to determine the issue of relocation first. I gave careful consideration to the affidavits, submissions and the CER but was unable to find in favour of the Mother. While her wish to relocate to Brisbane was understandable and reasonable, it was incompatible with the interests of the children. Accordingly, I disallowed the application.

29     I was mindful that the Mother would likely be very disappointed by my decision. Relocation cases are never easy to decide as they involve a binary decision. Whichever way the court decides, the decision is bound to cause considerable pain and anguish to one of the parties: see BNS v BNT [2015] 3 SLR 973 (“BNS v BNT”) (at [2]). As noted in TAA v TAB [2015] SGHCF 1 (“TAA v TAB”) (at [18]):

Raising children requires heavy commitment. The law expects no less from parents in post-divorce circumstances. This is not to say that the law does not recognise the difficulties and pain parents may have to bear, but children do grow up and such sacrifice is not demanded endlessly of a parent. Sacrifices may have to be made temporarily in the years when the children require them. The law chooses to place the welfare of the child above all else.

30     My decision was not intended to deny the Mother’s wish to return to Brisbane. However, this was an application to relocate the children and a decision on relocation is based ultimately on the welfare of the children. On the facts before me, I did not find that it was in their best interests for the children to relocate at this point in time.

31     In my brief grounds, I stressed that a refusal to allow relocation at the time of application did not necessarily mean that a future relocation could never be possible: see TAA v TAB (at [20]). When circumstances have changed such that it is clear that relocation is in the best interests of the children, the Mother can always renew her application.

32     The parties agreed to have joint custody of the children but disputed care and control. While I was of the view that it would have been in their welfare for the children to continue to spend equal time with each parent should both parents remain living in Singapore, I noted that the Mother’s application for a LTVP had been rejected by the ICA. As such, the current shared care arrangement in Singapore was no longer feasible.

33     In the circumstances, I granted the Father care and control of the children with liberal access to the Mother as follows:

(a)     Liberal phone and video access

(b)     Equal share of school holidays

(c)     Mother is at liberty to bring the children for overseas holidays during her holiday access time with the children

(d)     Father is to facilitate the children’s liberal overnight access with Mother whenever the Mother visits the children in Singapore.

34     In addition to the above orders, I made the following orders:

(a)     The children to continue receiving therapy with Ms [M] or a therapist that is mutually agreed between parties.

(b)     Parties may vary the care arrangement by mutual agreement.

35     Additionally, I appointed an experienced parenting coordinator, Ms Anuradha Sharma, to assist the parties with access plans. Taking into consideration the relative financial positions of the parties, I allocated the bulk of the fees for parenting coordination (90%) to be paid by the Father and the remainder (10%) to be paid by the Mother.

36     As the Mother has appealed the whole of my decision, I now set out my full grounds of decision.

The Mother’s relocation application

37     The Mother submitted that her relocation application should be granted. A summary of the key points from the Mother’s written submissions, which I have broadly categorized for ease of exposition, is set out below:

Parties’ joint intention

(a)     It was never parties’ intention to migrate to any country or to live outside Brisbane for an indefinite period.[note: 68] The Father had assured the Mother that the family would return to Brisbane any time she wanted.[note: 69] The Father himself saw the children’s stay in Singapore as only temporary as he had told the Mother that the children would move from Singapore before they became liable for National Service.[note: 70]

Mother’s wish

(b)     The Mother had put her own life and career on hold for 6.5 years to accommodate the Father’s career advancement, to be deprived the benefit of being with family and friends in Australia and to be at the mercy of the Father for finances.[note: 71]

(c)     The Mother was dangerously exposed to a double risk of the lack of secured residency in Singapore and zero insurance coverage. These were issues she would not have to face in Australia.[note: 72]

(d)     The parties’ relationship had broken down and divorce proceedings were ongoing in Australia. It was necessary for the Mother to start rebuilding her life with the children.[note: 73]

Children’s interests

(e)     The children were living in an expat bubble with neither children having adapted to the local way of life.[note: 74] They did not have any Singaporean local friends and their friends were fellow expatriates.[note: 75] They continued to prefer Western food and sushi, which was very popular in Australia.[note: 76] The children were adaptable and would quickly settle down in Australia, their home country.[note: 77]

(f)     The family were not permanent residents in Singapore and there was no home that had been purchased in Singapore. In contrast, the parties had purchased a property in Bulimba, Brisbane as their family home.[note: 78] For their long-term stability, the children should be able to return to a home where they could feel safe and at ease.[note: 79]

(g)     By relocating back to Australia, the children and the Mother would be able to enjoy the benefits of their Australian citizenship to the fullest.[note: 80]

Children’s caregiver

(h)     The Mother had been at all times the primary caregiver of the children.[note: 81] In contrast, the Father was only capable of having the children at his house with the help of the helper and his mother.[note: 82] The children were looked after largely by the Father’s helper when they were in his house. This was not desirable for the children.[note: 83]

Father’s immigration status

(i)     The Father had not declared any intention to stay in Singapore permanently. His and the children’s immigration status in Singapore remained tenuous and hinged solely on his employment in Singapore.[note: 84]

(j)     The Father was a Permanent Residence (“PR”) of Australia. The parties’ divorce would not affect his ability to return to Australia, unlike the Mother’s status in Singapore.[note: 85]

The Father’s objections

38     A summary of the key points of the Father’s objections, which I have also broadly categorised, is set out below:

Parities’ joint intention

(a)     There was never any agreement between the parties as to a timeline within which the family would leave Singapore.[note: 86] The relocation was not intended to be temporary [note: 87] and the Mother’s own evidence showed that she herself was prepared for longer than just 2023.[note: 88]

(b)     Since the children moved to Singapore, their circumstances had changed and they were overall doing well. The parties’ stay in Singapore had become more permanent, and the Father had even considered applying for permanent residency for himself and the children.[note: 89]

Mother’s wish

(c)     The Mother had never spent very long time in one place, including Brisbane.[note: 90] It was questionable whether the Mother’s desire to return to Brisbane was reasonable, given that Brisbane could not even reasonably be regarded as home to the Mother.[note: 91]

(d)     The Mother’s complaints as to her career were not genuine.[note: 92] She was made redundant in September 2014, which was also when the parties got married, and had not worked throughout the marriage. There was no evidence of the Mother having attempted to seek work since then, until after the parties moved to Singapore in 2021.[note: 93] While the Mother did attempt to apply for jobs in Singapore,[note: 94] it was severely lacking in effort[note: 95] and not a real attempt to restart her career.[note: 96]

(e)     The Mother’s uncertain visa status was entirely of her own making.[note: 97] The Mother had refused to collect her Dependent’s Pass despite the Father’s repeated attempts to encourage and facilitate this.[note: 98] This was an entirely self-inflicted set of circumstances by the Mother to gain an advantage in these proceedings.[note: 99]

(f)     In both her employment and visa situations, the evidence pointed towards a likely attempt at self-sabotage. The Mother’s complaints on both points were thus not genuine.[note: 100]

(g)     The Mother’s needs – both social and material – were met in Singapore. Any complaints by her to the contrary must be taken with a grain of salt.[note: 101]

Children’s interests

(h)     The children had been in Singapore since August 2021[note: 102] and were very well-accustomed to life in Singapore.[note: 103]

Children’s caregiver

(i)     The children got to spend substantial time with both parents each week[note: 104] and had been thriving under the parties’ shared care arrangement.

(j)     There was no evidence that the children were affected by the Mother’s desire to relocate to Brisbane.[note: 105]

The Mother’s relocation plan

(k)     The Mother’s relocation plan did not give a good enough reason for the children’s status quo to be disrupted. The Mother did not have a concrete plan for where the children would stay in Brisbane, the children did not have confirmed places in school in Brisbane, the Mother had no job in Brisbane and the Mother’s care plan was no better than what they had in Singapore.[note: 106]

(l)     The Mother had not shown how the children would benefit from studying in Brisbane, as opposed to what they presently had in Singapore.[note: 107]

(m)     The Mother had repeatedly complained about the children being cared for by their paternal grandmother or a helper, and yet in Australia her plan was for the children to be left with third parties after school.[note: 108]

Analysis

39     The law on relocation was succinctly summarized in ULA v UKZ [2018] SGHCF 19 (at [24]) as follows:

It is well-established that the welfare of the child is paramount in relocation applications and ought to override every other consideration (BNS v BNT at [19]). There is no presumption in favour of allowing relocation where the primary caregiver’s desire to relocate is reasonable. Rather, the relocating parent’s reasonable wish to relocate is only relevant to the extent that there would be a transference of the relocating parent’s insecurity and negative feelings onto the child, since it is the child’s welfare that lies at the heart of the inquiry, and not the interests of the relocating parent (BNS v BNT at [20]; see also TAA v TAB [2015] 2 SLR 879 (“TAA v TAB”) at [17]). There is no pre-fixed precedence or hierarchy amongst the various factors to be weighed in the overarching inquiry into the child’s welfare. Where the factors stand in relation to one another depends, finally, on a consideration of all the facts of the case (BNS v BNT at [22]).

40     As noted in the more recent decision of the Family Division in WRU v WRT [2024] SGHCF 23 (“WRU v WRT”) (at [15]):

… factors that the court may have regard to apart from the reasonable wishes of the primary caregiver and the child’s loss of relationship with the left-behind parent include “the child’s age, the child’s attachment to each parent and other significant persons in the child’s life, the child’s wellbeing in her present country of residence, as well as the child’s developmental needs at that particular stage of life, including her cognitive, emotional, academic and physical needs” (UXH v UXI [2019] SGHCF 24 (“UXH v UXI”) at [28]).

41     Additionally, the court should also consider the wishes of the children. As noted by Mavis Chionh J in WRU v WRT, “research supports the view it is more often than not beneficial for the parties and the children for the children to be given a voice on arrangements that are made for them”[note: 109] and “greater focus ought to be placed on the child’s wishes and feelings in determining the welfare of the child”[note: 110]. The learned judge also noted that “the question of how much weight is to be attached to the wishes of the child is a matter that falls within the judge’s discretion. Relevant factors that the judge should consider include the age and maturity of the children and the risk that the children may have been coached and pressurised by a parent to express certain views”.[note: 111]

Reasonable wishes of primary caregiver

Joint intention of parties

42     There was ample evidence to support the Mother’s claim that the parties’ relocation, first to KL, and subsequently to Singapore, was temporary. The evidence showed that there was a joint intention for the family to return to Australia.

43     A clear example was an email dated 26 June 2021 from the Father to the maternal grandfather where the Father said so himself that “[w]e did originally plan to go to KL for three years” and that “[l]ong term, we will be living in Australia. I have committed to that.” In the same email, the Father also said that he “need a few more years to save” and the move to Singapore “was a short term solution to the long term aim of being in Australia”.[note: 112]

44     Another example was a message dated 13 July 2021, prior to the parties’ relocation to Singapore, where the Father assured the Mother that:[note: 113]

[13/7/2021, 11:03:04 am]

If at the end of 3 years it’s still no good for you, we go back to Australia in our separate ways.

45     There was also clear evidence that the Mother was reluctant to move to Singapore. This was evident, for example, in the following text messages to the Father dated 11 July 2021 and 13 July 2021:[note: 114]

[11/7/2021, 9:05:25 am]

So what happens at the end of 3 years? I have zero money, you have what a little? And then we have to come back and try start again in Australia.

[11/7/2021, 11:27:42 am].

This moving to Singapore is taking me further and further away from being able to get a job, restart life and get the kids settled.

[13/7/2021, 7:58:12 am]

Before I leave for Singapore I want either cash or bulimba transferred into my name. I’m taking a massive risk here that you are not going to destroy me when I get to Singapore. I can legally keep the kids here now, so if I give you the benefit of the doubt I expect you not to do it to me, country or money wise.

[13/7/2021, 7:58:57 am]

I will be out of the workforce for 10 years, I will be literally starting my career again, for the benefit of yours.

46     The evidence also showed that the Mother was emphatic that she would only be in Singapore for no more than 3 years. For example, in a text message dated 11 July 2021, she told the Father as follows:[note: 115]

[11/7/2021, 11.28:57 am]

I’m in Singapore for 3 years, no more.

47     In light of the contemporaneous evidence, I was unable to accept the Father’s claim that the Mother wanted to move because she was bored of living in Singapore. In my view, this was not a fair characterisation of the Mother’s reason to relocate. Given the clear evidence on the joint intention of the parties, I found the Mother’s wish to return to her home country to be reasonable and consistent with the parties’ intention.

Breakdown in relationship

48     It was not disputed that by the time the parties relocated to Singapore, their relationship had broken down. The parties lived separately and their relationship continued to deteriorate, with the Father commencing parenting and financial proceedings in Australia followed by the Mother commencing divorce proceedings also in Australia.

49     As observed in UYK v UYJ [2020] SGHCF 9 (“UYK v UYJ”):

32    In the recent decisions where leave to relocate was granted, many of the cases involved a parent returning to his or her home country after the breakdown of the parents’ relationship. On either ground, the Mother’s wish to return to Australia was eminently reasonable.

33    In UXH, the Court noted that the parties appeared to accept that the case did not involve a spouse who has no significant connection to the forum country after the divorce, feels or is isolated, and wishes to return to his or her home country (usually the country in which he or she grew up and where the extended family remains). Some lawyers have referred to this factual matrix as a case of a “trailing spouse”. In such cases, depending on the precise facts, appropriate weight may be accorded to the possibility that denying the parent’s wish to relocate may so deeply affect such a parent’s well-being that this in turn has negative effects on the child (UXH at [16] and BNS ([25] supra) at [20]).

50     In my view, the factual matrix in the present case was not dissimilar to the case of a “trailing spouse” described above. As the parties’ marriage had broken down irretrievably, the Mother’s wish to return to her home country was eminently reasonable, bearing in mind that she had been out of the workforce for a substantial period of time and had to restart her life and career.

Mother’s visa status

51     The Father said that when his OnePass was issued in December 2023, the Mother refused to collect her Dependent’s Pass, which resulted in the uncertainty over the Mother’s visa status.[note: 116] The Father submitted that the Mother’s refusal to cooperate with the Father was simply to gain an advantage in these proceedings – so that she could submit that her visa was uncertain and that she must be allowed to relocate.[note: 117]

52     I did not find any merit in the Father’s allegation. Notably, the OnePass application was made on 3 July 2023[note: 118], well after the Mother’s relocation application was filed. The grounds of the Mother’s relocation would have crystallised at the point of filing.

53     Moreover, it was difficult to see what tactical advantage would be served by the Mother jeopardising her own visa status. It must be remembered that this was an application for the relocation of the children, and not that of the Mother. The Mother did not require the permission of the court to relocate. The fact that the Mother’s visa status was uncertain did not mean that the relocation of the children would automatically be allowed. The overriding consideration in all relocation cases is the welfare of the child. This was reiterated in BNS v BNT at [19]) as follows:

… there is only one fundamental – indeed, critical – legal principle upon which everything else (including the ultimate decision of the case itself) depends. And it is this – in considering relocation applications, the welfare of the child is paramount and this principle ought to override any other consideration.

54     Although much ink was spilled by parties over the Mother’s visa status, it turned out that this consideration did not have a material bearing on the determination of the reasonableness of the Mother’s wish at the end of day. This was because there were sufficient grounds, independent of her visa status, to show that her wish to relocate was not unreasonable.

No presumption in favour of allowing relocation

55     Although the Mother’s wish to relocate was reasonable, I was mindful that there is no presumption in favour of allowing relocation even in such a case. As noted in VTU v VTV [2022] SGHCF 28 (at [12]):

The court may still disallow the application even if the relocating parent’s application is not unreasonable and done in bad faith.

56     Hence, a finding of reasonableness was not the end of the inquiry. I had to consider if the Mother’s wish was incompatible with the interests of the children. This is also clear from UXH v UXI [2019] SGHCF 24, which held (at [11]) as follows:

… While the wishes of parents may have a bearing on the welfare of the child, the court must determine if those wishes are incompatible with the interests of the child; where they may not be compatible, the law expects parents to put the interests of the child before their own (TAA at [17]).

Relevance of shared care arrangement

57     Additionally, the following observations of the Court of Appeal in BNS v BNT (at [20]) bear reiterating:

… the relocating parent’s reasonable wish to relocate is not relevant per se. It is relevant only to the extent that it is found that there will be a transference of his or her insecurity and negative feelings onto the child. It is, after all, the child’s welfare that lies at the heart of the inquiry, and not the interests of the relocating parent (or either of the parents for that matter).

58     As noted in WNO v WNP [2023] SGFC 19 (at [32]):

Where there are two primary caregivers such as the present case, the transference of the insecurity and negative feelings onto the child by the parent who is disappointed that his or her relocation application is not granted is mitigated by the presence of the other caregiving parent. It follows that in such a situation, the wishes of the relocating parent would carry less weight compared to cases where the relocating parent is the sole caregiver.

59     In the present case, the shared care and control arrangement was relevant in assessing the weight to be accorded to the Mother’s wish. To the extent that the transference of the insecurity and negative feelings onto the children by the Mother was mitigated by the presence of the Father, the Mother’s wish to relocate would correspondingly carry lesser weight.

60     The Mother’s claim that the shared care arrangement was forced on her appeared to be premised on a belief that her right to the children was superior to that of the Father. She also accused the Father of having “robbed her” of her fulltime care of the children.[note: 119] However, such a belief is contrary to the expectations of the law. As noted in s 3 of the Guardianship of Infants Act 1934:

Where in any proceedings before any court the custody or upbringing of an infant or the administration of any property belonging to or held in trust for an infant or the application of the income thereof is in question, the court, in deciding that question, shall regard the welfare of the infant as the first and paramount consideration and, save insofar as such welfare otherwise requires, the father of an infant shall not be deemed to have any right superior to that of the mother in respect of such custody, administration or application nor shall the mother be deemed to have any claim superior to that of the father.

[emphasis in bold added]

61     It is abundantly clear from the above provision that neither parent had a greater right to the children. Indeed, the law expects parents to cooperate to promote the child’s best interests: see CX v CY [2005] SLR (R) 690 (at [28]). The parental responsibility to care for a child is coequal (see VWJ v VWI [2023] SGHCF 7 at [6]) and extends to supporting the child’s relationship with both parents (see WAH v WAG [2024] SGFC 6 at [50]). As noted in BNS v BNT [2014] SGHC 187 (at [21]), citing BG v BF [2007] 3 SLR (R) 233, “a child will feel more secure if both his parents continue to be involved in his life”. Hence, a parent’s desire to play an active role in the child’s upbringing is to be strongly encouraged and commended. It ought not to be frown upon, as did the Mother in the present case.

62     The Mother seemed averse to the Father playing a coequal role in the care of the children and had even sought to reduce the Father’s parenting time.[note: 120] While it is common for a relocating parent to ask for sole care and control of the children for practical reasons, the Mother had insisted on sole care and control even if her relocation application was not allowed. I found this troubling, as it revealed a lack of insight on the importance of co-parenting to the well-being of the children. This lack of insight, coupled with her inability to move past personal grudges against the Father and belief that she was the superior parent, suggested that her co-parenting ability might be limited if granted sole care and control in the event of relocation.

63     In contrast, the Father had consistently recognised the importance of the children maintaining a close relationship with the Mother. He did not seek to reduce the Mother’s parenting time nor did he ask to have sole care and control of the children. In VPG v VPF [2021] SGHCF 18, Debbie Ong J observed (at [10]):

Parental responsibility is a legal duty to be discharged by both parents. A strong parent is one who can support the child in having a close relationship with the other parent.

In this regard, the Father was clearly the stronger parent as he was more attuned to the needs of the children in having a close relationship with both parents.

64     Notwithstanding the claim by the Mother that the shared care arrangement was forced on her and neither in the best interests nor welfare of the children,[note: 121] the children did benefit from the shared care arrangement. As noted in WRU v WRT (at [36]):

… the court is predominantly tasked with assessing the merits of the relocation application on the facts as they presently are, as opposed to the state of the relationship in the past (see ULA v UKZ at [50]).

65     While the Mother had sought to rake up the past and paint a dismal picture of the Father, it must be remembered that the paramount consideration should be the welfare of the children, and not the past conduct of a parent: see UBQ v UBR [2023] SGHC(A) 10 (at [49]).

Children’s interests

Children’s wishes

66     Children’s views may be presented in child welfare reports, including specific issues reports, which are prepared by professionals: see WRU v WRT (at [17]).

67     From the CER, I was very heartened to note that the children shared a close relationship with both parents despite the increasing tensions between the adults due to the relocation. I noted further that both children were cognisant that the Mother had been wanting to return to live in Australia.

68     The younger child enjoyed his holidays in Brisbane with the maternal family and shared extensively about their holiday farmhouse and biking adventures. However, he was concerned about leaving the Father behind, if he were to relocate to Australia with the Mother. He had no opinion whether to remain in Singapore or to relocate and would like to live in a country where he could see both parents frequently and equally.

69     The older child expressed worries about living in Australia during winter and being away from his friends. He shared that he had lived in Malaysia and Singapore most of his life and enjoyed living in the city and in the tropics. He hoped to continue living in either Singapore or Malaysia and hoped to continue with the current living arrangements.

70     Our courts have consistently recognised that siblings should not be separated: e.g. see Wong Phila Mae v Shaw Harold [1991] 1 SLR (R) 680 (at [22(d)]). In WIQ v WIP [2023] SGHCF 16, Choo Han Teck J explained the rationale (at [4]) as follows:

It is not usual for split care and control to be ordered. Keeping siblings together should be the norm for the obvious reason that the anxieties arising from their parental separation should not be increased by a further separation of a sibling. Nonetheless, this is just one of many considerations, and the weight to be given to it varies from case to case, each on its own facts: ABW v ABV [2014] 2 SLR 769 ("ABW") at [23] and [24]; IW v IX [2006] 1 SLR(R) 135 at [27].

71     Given the clear wishes of the older child to continue living in Singapore or Malaysia, the neutrality expressed by the younger child and the need to avoid separating the siblings, I found this factor (i.e. children’s wishes) to lean against relocation.

Loss of children’s relationship with the Father

72     The loss of relationship a child may experience with the left-behind parent is another important factor in a relocation application. As noted in TAA v TAB (at [19]):

A relocation of children to another jurisdiction is a serious matter. It would mean a fundamental change in whom the children would see as their close family and the children would lose the experience of hands-on parenting from both their mother and their father (see K v K [2011] EWCA Civ 793). The court must give sufficient weight to the loss of the children’s relationship with the left-behind parent …

[emphasis in bold added]

73     Having regard to the shared care arrangement, the children’s wishes and the close relationship the children shared with the Father, I found that the welfare of the children would be negatively impacted if relocation was allowed. Hence, while I was mindful that the loss of relationship in itself was not the dominant or determinant consideration (see UYK v UYJ (at [26])), it was nonetheless a significant factor in the present case.

Father’s caregiving ability

74     I noted from the CER that the Father appeared to be a highly involved parent who had demonstrated good knowledge of the children’s needs. The independent observations in the CER corroborated the evidence of the Father and third-party witnesses on his involvement in the lives of the children and his caregiving ability. The Father’s capacity to care for the children was also evident from the close relationship that the children shared with him. As admitted by the Mother herself, the children loved the Father.[note: 122]

75     Although the Mother had expressed concerns about the children’s care while they were with the Father, she had not shown how the proposed care arrangement in Brisbane would be any better.

Father’s immigration status

Father’s immigration status in Singapore

76     The Mother alleged that the Father’s OnePass application was for tactical reasons. She pointed out that the Father’s Employment Pass, the Mother’s Dependent Pass and the Children’s Dependent Passes were all valid up to 5 August 2026. There was hence no reason for the Father to have applied for the OnePass, 4 years before the expiry of his Employment Pass, save to facilitate his agenda in these proceedings. The OnePass allowed the Father to stay in Singapore until November 2028.[note: 123]

77     The Mother’s allegation raised a question of fact about the Father’s motive in applying for the OnePass. However, parties did not address how the Father’s immigration status was relevant to the inquiry. It should be noted that even a relocating parent’s reasonable wish to relocate is not relevant per se. It is relevant only to the extent that it is found that there will be a transference of his or her insecurity and negative feelings onto the child: see BNS v BNT [2015] 3 SLR 973 (at [20]).

78     While the relevance of the Mother’s immigration status could be readily appreciated within the context of ascertaining the reasonableness of her wish to relocate, the relevance of the Father’s immigration status was less apparent. It cannot be assumed that any point of contention raised by a disputing party is necessarily relevant to the inquiry.

79     Leaving aside the question of relevance, I found no merit in the Mother’s allegation in any event. The evidence showed that the Father’s employer was keen for him to obtain a OnePass even before the Mother’s relocation application was filed. However, the Father could only apply for OnePass in mid-2023 as he was required to establish a sufficient history of earnings in order to be eligible for OnePass.[note: 124] Hence, it could not be the case that the Father had applied for OnePass to thwart the Mother’s relocation application.

Father’s immigration status in Australia

80     The Mother also submitted that the Father, as a PR of Australia, would have the ability to stay in Australia, work, own properties and have banking accounts in his own name.[note: 125] The Father however chose not to move to or practise in Brisbane.[note: 126]

81     The Father explained that the travel facility associated with his Australian PR had lapsed. There was no point in holding the Australian PR without an ability to enter and leave Australia. It was meaningless, and the Mother was conveniently describing a technicality without addressing the substance.[note: 127] To obtain a new visa, he would need to prove that he had “substantial ties” to Australia that were “of benefit” to Australia. The application would require time,[note: 128] the conditions were not easily met[note: 129] and there was no certainty as to the likely outcome.[note: 130]

82     Furthermore, the paternal grandmother had relocated from the UK to Singapore on 10 December 2021 to be reunited with the Father and the children.[note: 131] The children’s bond with the grandmother was strong.[note: 132] The grandmother would similarly encounter, and probably even more challenging issues, with respect to obtaining an Australian visa.[note: 133]

83     The Father also explained that he would not be an attractive hire in Australia, especially in the context of a hastily arranged move. The absolute best-case outcome would be an Associate role, which would come with a huge reduction in remuneration and a period of operating as a trainee.[note: 134] This was not an attractive option, and would be decidedly negative to the family. The children would not benefit from a father who was suddenly earning far less, but working infinitely more hours with far less professional independence and flexibility.[note: 135]

84     In my view, it was not reasonable for the Mother to trivialise the challenges highlighted by the Father. These were real obstacles with potentially adverse consequences for the family and the children. Moreover, the marriage had broken down. The Father, unlike the Mother, was not an Australian citizen. It would not be reasonable to expect the Father to relocate to Australia, just as it would be unreasonable to expect the Mother to stay put in Singapore.

85     Hence, even if the Father’s immigration status was relevant to the inquiry, it was not a factor in favour of relocation. At best, it was a neutral factor.

Conclusion

86     In conclusion, while I was satisfied that the Mother’s wish to relocate to Australia was not unreasonable or founded in bad faith, I found her wish to be incompatible with the interests of the children. Other than the fact that the children were Australian citizens, the Mother had not shown how the relocation to Australia would benefit the children compared to the status quo. Indeed, her relocation plan appeared to serve her interests rather than those of the children.

87     While her wish to restart her career and life was understandable, this would have to be balanced against other relevant factors as the paramount consideration was the welfare of the children. The children shared a close relationship with the Father and the older child, in particular, had expressed a clear wish to continue living in Singapore or Malaysia. The younger child was neutral but would like to be able to see both parents frequently and equally.

88     The Mother’s application for a LTVP had been rejected by the ICA while there were real challenges for the Father to relocate to Australia. The stark reality facing this family was that the parents would have to live in separate jurisdictions, at least in the foreseeable future. A shared care and control arrangement was no longer feasible. Either way, there would be a loss of relationship with the other parent which would have to be mitigated by a generous access plan.

89     However, the Mother’s ability to co-parent if granted sole care and control in the event of relocation was a cause for concern. She was unable to recognise the Father’s contributions to the children’s upbringing and could only see all sorts of reasons to find fault with his parenting. Her lack of insight on the importance of co-parenting and belief that she had superior right made me doubt whether she would be able to support the father-sons bond, notwithstanding her assurance to the court that she would do so.[note: 136] She had also sought to reduce the Father’s parenting time by seeking a sole care and control order even if relocation was not granted, which only deepened my doubt.

90     In contrast, the Father had consistently demonstrated a willingness to support the children in having a close relationship with the Mother. In ABW v ABV [2014] SGHC 29, Judith Prakash J observed (at [45]) as follows:

… it would be in the children’s interests for them to be with the parent who was willing to be reasonable about access and could share them with the other.

91     As the Father was more likely to share the children with the Mother and facilitate generous access, the welfare of the children would be better served by allowing the children to be with the Father. This arrangement would also align with the children’s wishes and avoid any unnecessary disruption to their lives.

92     Balancing all factors, I concluded that it would not be in the best interests of the children to relocate to Brisbane at this point in time. Accordingly, the Mother’s relocation application was disallowed.

93     As it was important for the family to heal and move on, I made no order as to costs.
