XLB v XLC

XLB v XLC
[2025] SGFC 38

Case Number:MSS 1444 of 2024
Decision Date:08 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Mother in person and unrepresented; The Father in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XLB — XLC

Family Law – Enforcement of Maintenance

08 April 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       MSS 1444 of 2024 (“MSS 1444”) was the Mother’s application to enforce the arrears in respect of an Order of Court vide MO xxx/2016. Pursuant to that order, the Father was ordered to pay a monthly sum of $350 for the maintenance of one child. Both parties were self-represented.

2       I heard the trial on 17 December 2024 and reserved judgment. On 14 January 2025, I handed down my decision and made the relevant orders. These are the reasons for my decision.

3       The Mother confirmed, during the hearing, that she was seeking to enforce arrears from January 2017 all the way up to August 2024. The total amount which the Mother sought to enforce thus came up to $32,200.[note: 1]

4       Given the time period in respect of which the Mother was seeking to recover arrears of maintenance, the first issue I had to deal with was whether the time bar set out in s 121(3) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“WC”) was applicable. That provision states:

Recovery of arrears of maintenance

(3)    No amount owing as maintenance is recoverable in any suit if it accrued due more than 3 years before the institution of the suit unless the court, under special circumstances, otherwise allows.

5       It is clear that, s 121(3) of the WC applies to the present case. This is because s 74 of the WC states (see also VLW v VLX [2020] SGFC 84 at [19(a) and [20]):

Application of section 121

74.    Section 121 applies, with the necessary modifications, to any order for the payment of maintenance under this Part.

6       Given this, the Mother therefore had to show that there were such special circumstances which warranted her being able to recover arrears in respect of maintenance beyond the three years as provided for under s 121(3) of the WC: Koay Guat Kooi (m w) v Eddie Yeo (formerly known as Yap Ah Huat alias Yeo Ah Nee) [1997] SGHC 197 (“Koay Guat Kooi”) at [12].

7       The time bar in s 121(3) of the WC ensures that applicants seeking to enforce a maintenance order do so in a timely fashion – doing so would reflect a true need on their part. This comports with the rationale for the court’s power to order maintenance: that is to “provide for the urgent and pressing financial needs of the receiving party, and to ensure that such needs are not deferred due to a lack of assurance that sums expended would eventually be compensated”: VLW v VLX [2020] SGFC 84 at [19(d)]. This time bar also ensures that the paying party is not taken by surprise where the recipient of maintenance makes no complaint about the non-payment of maintenance for several years, but one day, decides to haul the paying party to court.

8       That said, the time bar in s 121(3) is not cast in absolute terms. The “special circumstances” exception accommodates situations where a “wife may have genuine reasons for not applying for recovery of arrears before” the expiry of the three-year period (see the Singapore Parliamentary Reports on the Third Reading of the Women’s Charter (Amendment) Bill (as reported from the Select Committee) dated 27 August 1996 at col 524).

9       There are, generally speaking, two broad situations where the court may find that there are special circumstances justifying the waiver of the three-year time bar: see UAE v UAF [2017] SGFC 46 at [21].

10     The first are situations where the circumstances are “sufficiently persuasive in themselves that to ignore them would do great injustice to the [applicant]”. Justice Choo Han Teck (“Choo J”) had made this observation in Koay Guat Kooi. That case concerned an appeal against the decision of a District Judge in respect of orders made relating to the division of the matrimonial flat and the award of past and current maintenance. The District Judge had declined to order arrears of maintenance for more than 3 years because of s 115(3) of the Women’s Charter which stated:

"No amount owing as maintenance shall be recoverable in any suit if it accrued due more than 3 years before the institution of the suit."

11     Counsel for the wife in that case had contended that while this was the provision in force at the time of the hearing, the law had changed – the words “unless the court under special circumstances allows” were added to what was then s 115(3) of the Women’s Charter. According to counsel, there were special circumstances because parties had lived apart for 14 years, and in that time, the wife did not know where the husband was, and could therefore not ask for maintenance.

12     This argument found little weight with Choo J who noted that there was no proof that efforts were “made by the wife to contact the husband but to no avail” and that given this, it could also be equally said that she did not wish to claim maintenance then.

13     The second sort of situation where special circumstances are shown involve cases where the payor of maintenance has, through their actions, frustrated attempts to enforce the maintenance order, or taken steps to avoid paying the full sums owed in maintenance: UAE at [21(b)] and [21(c)]. There are two cases which illustrate this.

14     In Meenatchi d/o Kuppusamy v Subbiah Pillai [2013] SGDC 202, the wife had sought to enforce arrears of $103,500 for the period July 2006 to 21 March 2012. The court found that there were “special circumstances” which justified the recovery of arrears beyond the 3-year time bar. The wife in that case had first commenced enforcement proceedings against the husband in 2008 – however, her application fell through as the husband’s registered address could not be ascertained for service to be effected. The reason for this was apparent from the husband’s passport which showed that he had been travelling frequently to Malaysia, India and Bangladesh, and that he had been issued visas which allowed him to remain in India and Bangladesh for a few months.

15     Second, in Lee Meng Leng v Tan Huat Soon [2014] SGDC 224 (“Lee Meng Leng”), the court had found that the respondent husband was in the habit of “unilaterally deduct[ing] monies from court-ordered maintenance” that was due to the complainant without first obtaining either the complainant’s agreement or a valid court order. The court thus considered it appropriate to allow enforcement of arrears beyond the 3-year time bar, noting that such “unilateral deductions from court-ordered maintenance by respondents c[ould] not be condoned by the courts”: Lee Meng Leng at [44] – [47].

16     Returning to the present case, I do not find that the Mother has shown that there are special circumstances which warrant allowing her to enforce the arrears beyond the three year period.

17     During the trial, the Mother gave two reasons as to why she was unable to bring an application to enforce the arrears owed earlier. The first was that she was the main caregiver for her children, and was therefore unable to find the time to come to court to file an application.[note: 2]

18     The second reason was that her ex-husband did not allow her to come to court to file an application. The Mother explained that her ex-husband was jealous of the Father. In that vein, it appears that the Mother was afraid of what might happen to her if she came to court to file an application to enforce the arrears[note: 3] – she stated that her ex-husband was a “wife-beater”. The Mother also explained that she could not contact the Father as her ex-husband had deleted all the contacts in her phone and made her replace her SIM card.[note: 4]

19     That being said, the Mother appears to have escaped the unfortunate situation with her ex-husband following their divorce in 2020. It would have been possible for her to file an enforcement application without having to live in fear of what her ex-husband might say or do.

20     During the hearing, I had asked the Mother to explain why she had waited for four years after her divorce with her ex-husband before bringing the present enforcement application.[note: 5] The Mother explained that it was only in 2024 that she discovered that she was able to make an online application to enforce the arrears. Up to that point, her hands were full from looking after her children (which included one special needs child) on her own, dealing with her own health issues, and coping with various issues arising from her divorce (which included looking for a place to stay).[note: 6]

21     I could not accept this explanation. There was nothing, apart from what the Mother had said in her testimony, which had been put in evidence before me to demonstrate that the circumstances she faced in the years following her divorce rendered her unable to file an application. It would have been a different situation had the Mother, in the years following her divorce in 2020, filed an application for enforcement but subsequently abandoned that application. This was not the case. The only other enforcement application which the Mother had brought against the Father was in 2017, vide MSS xxxx/2017.[note: 7]

22     I therefore find that the Mother is only entitled to enforce the maintenance arrears for a period of three years prior to the filing of her application in MSS 1444 (ie, 26 June 2021 to 26 June 2024). The arrears for this period comes up to a total of $12,600. In addition to this, I also take into account the arrears for the period from July to August 2024. I do so because it is undisputed between both parties that the Father had only started making payment in September 2024.[note: 8]

23     In summary, the total arrears that the Mother can enforce against the Father comes up to $13,300.

24     The second issue which I turn now to address is whether the Father had shown cause. It is hornbook law that a respondent to enforcement proceedings is to be given a chance to “show cause” – in other words, the respondent is afforded an opportunity to provide satisfactory reasons as to why an enforcement order should not be made: VUJ v VUK [2021] SGFC 87 (“VUJ”) at [20] citing Lai Ching Kin v Ng Chin Chye [2001] SGDC 228; WUG v WUH [2024] SGFC 11 at [9] . In making an order for enforcement, the court must bear in mind whether the making of an enforcement order would “lead to injustice” or whether it would be “inequitable to do so given the circumstances and facts of a given case”: VUJ at [22].

25     Cases where the court has found it inequitable to enforce the maintenance order against a respondent include those where there was a mutual agreement between the parties that the amount of maintenance payable should be reduced. It also includes cases where the respondent had either gone above and beyond what was required under the maintenance order, or where the complainant had used the respondent’s money to pay for expenses falling within the scope of the maintenance order, or where the respondent had been diligently paying maintenance but had run into genuine financial difficulties and was therefore unable to keep up with the payments: VUJ at [21].

26     I do not find that the Father had shown cause. For one, there could not have been any sort of mutual agreement between the parties that the Mother was happy to forgo the sums owed under the maintenance order. Neither party disputed that they were, in the intervening years between 2017 up till September 2024 (which was when the Mother had texted the Father to demand payment)[note: 9], in contact with the other.

27     As to why the Father did not keep up with the maintenance payments, he explained to me that after the Mother’s previous application in 2017 had been struck off, he had simply assumed that the case was closed.[note: 10] The Father did not check with anyone as to whether he had to continue paying maintenance, and simply assumed that he could stop paying the $350 owed every month.[note: 11]

28     I cannot accept that the Father had shown cause on the basis that he did not know he had to continue to comply with the order. If he was uncertain of the consequences of the Mother’s application being struck out, the onus was on him to check.

29     Finally, I would add that I do not find that the Father had gone above and beyond the maintenance order. This issue arises because it emerged from the testimony of both parties, that the Father had made payment of $500 per month for the period September to December 2024. It would thus appear that the Father had paid more than the stipulated $350 monthly sum.

30     The Father, however, had explained that he had paid an extra $150 because that sum of money was meant for a second child which he had with the Mother. To contribute this sum of $500, the Father had resorted to doing more overtime shifts at work.

31     While the Father’s efforts to provide for both his children are indeed commendable, this is not something I can give weight to in deciding whether the Father had shown cause. The facts of the present case are quite different from that in TDR v TDS [2014] SGDC 183[note: 12] (at [22] – [27]) where the court had found that the respondent husband had gone above and beyond the maintenance order. In that case, the husband had been paying the wife monthly maintenance of $6,500 although the court order only provided for a monthly maintenance sum of $5,725. In addition to that, the husband had also met the entirety of his obligations to pay for the other items under the court order as well as items which did not come within the ambit of the order. Given this, the court found that the husband had always, when he was financially able, done his part and gone beyond his legal obligations to support the wife. Because of this, it would have been inequitable to penalise the husband for falling behind on maintenance payments now that he found himself in dire financial straits.

32     In the present case, it is undisputed that the Father had not complied with the order of maintenance. The Father had admitted to this.[note: 13] And while the Father’s additional payment might have had the effect of reducing the Mother’s financial burden – it must be emphasised that a parent has the obligation to provide for their children: s 68 of the Women’s Charter 1961. The Father is simply doing what is expected of him as a parent.

33     I therefore find that the Father has not shown cause and order that the arrears, which come up to $13,300, be enforced against him. The Father shall pay off these arrears in monthly instalments of $100 with effect from 1 February 2025. This payment shall be made to the Mother’s designated bank account on the last day of each month.

XKY v XKX and another matter

XKY v XKX and another matter
[2025] SGFC 37

Case Number:SS 265 and 280 of 2024
Decision Date:07 April 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The applicant in person and unrepresented; The respondent in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XKY — XKX — XKZ

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

Family Law – Domestic Exclusion Order

7 April 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       There were two applications before me in SS 265 and 280 of 2024 (“SS 265” and “SS 280”). The parents had taken out applications for a Personal Protection Order (“PPO”) for themselves and their youngest son in SS 265 and 280 of 2024. In addition to the PPO, a Domestic Exclusion Order (“DEO”) was also sought. The respondent is their eldest son [XKX].[note: 1]

2       I heard the trial over the course of three days. Upon conclusion of the trial, I reserved judgment, after parties had made their respective oral submissions. On 21 March 2025, I handed down my judgment, allowing the applications in both SS 265 and 280, and giving the following reasons for doing so.

3       It is well-established law that an applicant for a PPO must establish the following two requirements on a balance of probabilities. First, that the respondent had either committed an act of family violence (as is defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961)[note: 2] or was likely to commit family violence. Second, that the PPO is necessary.

4       I found that XKX was indeed likely to commit family violence. It was apparent from the course of his testimony, that he bore a deep grudge towards his parents and younger brother. XKX recounted how his parents would favour his younger brother – for instance, he shared how his parents had purchased the latest gadgets for his younger brother, but neglected to do the same for him. He also recounted how he would have to shoulder the blame for the fights and scuffles that he would have with his younger brother. Whenever these fights took place, his mother would cane him, but do nothing to discipline his younger brother.

5       Naturally, XKX’s parents felt wronged by his accusation that they had especially doted on or favoured his younger brother over him. The both of them, especially XKX’s mother, sought to challenge XKX’s narrative on this point during the course of XKX’s cross-examination.

6       In assessing the merits of both applications, it is not necessary for me to decide whether XKX’s parents had indeed doted on him, nor do I need to determine whether XKX had a valid basis for holding a grudge against the rest of his family. What was abundantly clear to me was that XKX did hold this deep-seated grudge which left him feeling isolated and all alone in the world as he had no member of his family to confide in, to the point where he only had ChatGPT to turn to.

7       More importantly, however, that grudge which XKX held did lead him to lash out violently against his family members. His father bore the brunt of XKX’s wrath as was evident from the various pictures showing the extent of his injuries. Indeed, XKX did not deny hitting his father, nor did XKX deny getting into several altercations with his parents as well as his younger brother. These altercations demonstrated XKX’s proclivity for violence – for instance, XKX admitted to biting his brother. He also recounted how he had gone into “a frenzy” when his father had, in one incident, grabbed him by the collar – he lashed out blindly and kicked his mother in the leg.

8       As to the necessity of ordering a PPO, the cases tell us that once it is established that the respondent is likely to commit family violence, it follows as a matter of logic that a PPO is necessary to protect the applicant: XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [21(a)] citing Lai Kwok Kin v Teo Zien Jackson [2020] 5 SLR 389 at [39].

9       Leaving aside any presumption, on the facts before me, I found it necessary to order a PPO for the protection of XKX’s parents as well as his younger brother. Determining the necessity of a PPO is, in essence, a risk assessment: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [19]. The court must consider the likelihood of the respondent committing further acts of family violence on the applicant.

10     A PPO is indeed necessary in the present case. XKX still bears a deep resentment towards his parents and younger brother, and he has, through his own account of the incidents in contention, demonstrated a propensity for violence. These are significant red flags pointing towards the necessity of a PPO. While XKX has already moved out to live on his own, and indicated that he wished to cut off any and all ties with his family, the mere physical separation in this case does not suffice to reduce the risk of family violence. Until XKX has learnt to let go of his hate, anger and animosity towards the rest of his family, it is, in my judgment, quite likely that there will continue to be a high risk of family violence.

11     In this connection, and for the same reasons that I have already set out, I also find it necessary to grant a DEO for the protection or personal safety of the applicant. This enforced physical separation is needed to ensure that there are no further acts of physical violence.

12     In summary, both applications in SS 265 and 280 are allowed in its entirety. In addition to the PPO and DEO, I am also ordering that all parties (XKX, as well as his parents and younger brother) go for counselling.

13     On this final note, I conclude with a few words to XKX.

14     While I have made the relevant orders against you, I must emphasise that the purpose of this trial was to ascertain whether a PPO and a DEO should be granted for the protection of your family members. The orders that I have made are not meant to punish you. They are meant to ensure the protection of your parents and younger brother. That much is made clear by the relevant provisions in the Women’s Charter as well as the jurisprudence of the Family Courts (see e.g. WSD v WSE and another matter [2024] SGFC 1 at [1]).

15     I must also remind you of the effect of these orders. You are not to commit family violence on your parents or your younger brother. This includes physically attacking, or verbally abusing them. The breach of these orders is an arrestable offence, for which penalties include a fine or imprisonment: see s 65(10) of the Women’s Charter 1961.

16     In practical terms, this is effect of the DEO which I have ordered: home is now behind you – but a whole world lies ahead. I strongly urge you to use this as a fresh start. Where you go from here is entirely up to you, but nothing is impossible if you are willing to learn and to put in the hard work. Above all, you must work on laying to rest the grievances, resentment and hurt you have accrued over the years for you will not truly be at peace until you have done so.

[note: 1][XKX] had, due to his age, a litigation representative (his aunt) at the hearing before me.

[note: 2]References to the Women’s Charter 1961 in this judgment are references to the version in force before 2 January 2025.
